site_title: Wage pressure to intensify over the year
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority warns that wage pressure will intensify over the year, crimping firms' profit margins. While some companies can pass on higher costs to customers, others in logistics, shipping, and construction may struggle. Wage costs are expected to rise 3% in 2014, driven by strong hiring intentions and a tight labor market. The central bank also notes that cost pass-through will be stronger if government measures, such as the Wage Credit Scheme, are not in place.

site_title: Warnings over Korean ferry ignored, finds probe
summary: A South Korean ferry disaster probe found that warnings about the ship's seaworthiness were ignored, leading to the April 16 sinking that killed 210 people and left 92 unaccounted for. The captain, Shin, had warned the shipping company about stability problems, but his warnings were dismissed. The exact cause of the accident remains under investigation, but experts suggest a sharp turn may have caused the ferry to list and capsize. The captain and 14 crew members are under arrest, and the government has apologized for its handling of the disaster, which has sparked public outrage.

site_title: LVMH adds Crystal Jade to Singapore jewel box
summary: LVMH, the French luxury goods giant, has acquired Crystal Jade, a Singapore-based Chinese restaurant group, in a deal worth approximately US$100 million. The acquisition will give Crystal Jade access to LVMH's branding and marketing expertise, as well as its global relationships with landlords, enabling the company to expand to Europe, the Middle East, and other parts of the world. The restaurant group, which made around $250 million in revenue last year, will tap into LVMH's resources to improve profitability and product offerings, such as tie-ups with LVMH brands on wine selection.

site_title: Pteris needs more than cash from RTO to stay aloft
summary: Pteris Global, an airport logistics systems provider, needs more than a cash injection from a proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal to stay afloat. The RTO, which would merge Pteris's balance sheet with Tianda Airport Support, may provide short-term financial relief but does not address the company's deep-seated problems, including lagging technology, costly and overly long projects, and issues with compensation and foreign exchange risks. The board must prove that the RTO will drive product innovation and solve these issues, which is unclear, leaving shareholders skeptical.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to operate out of T4
summary: Cathay Pacific has confirmed it will operate out of Changi Airport's Terminal 4, set to launch in 2017. The airline's passengers will have access to a dedicated premium lounge, exceeding 800 square meters, and will also utilize self-service options such as check-in, bag drop, and immigration clearance. This move underscores the airline's confidence in the Changi brand and its commitment to a premium experience, as the airport aims to boost its capacity to 85 million annually by 2018.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: EMS Energy acquired International Offshore Equipments for $800,000 in new shares, while F&N acquired a 70% stake in Yoke Food Industries for RM54.6 million. Midas Holdings won 146 million yuan worth of high-speed train contracts. JES International Holdings received in-principle approval for listing 42 million subscription shares.

site_title: Lend Lease gets 2 more tenants for A$6b devt
summary: Lend Lease Group, Australia's largest listed property developer, has secured two major tenants for its A$6 billion Sydney harbourfront development. PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) will occupy 26,500 square meters over 12 floors, while HSBC Holdings plc will take up 8,000 square meters. This marks the start of construction on the third office tower at the Barangaroo project. The signings are a significant milestone for the development, which is expected to be completed in the future.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit Q1 DPU at 1.562 cents
summary: Soilbuild Reit posted a 1.562 cents DPU for Q1, 6.1% higher than forecast, resulting in an adjusted annualised distribution yield of 7.7%. Gross revenue was $16.8 million, with net property income at $14.2 million. The Reit maintained a 100% occupancy rate and is well-positioned to meet its FY2014 forecast, citing early renewal negotiations and low operating expenses.

site_title: Twitter stock plunges on slowing user growth
summary: Twitter's stock plummeted 11% after the company reported slower-than-expected user growth, reaching 255 million in the first quarter, a 25% increase from the previous period. Despite doubling sales to $250 million, analysts focused on the slowing user growth, which has pushed the stock to its lowest since its market debut. Twitter aims to monetize its audience and compete with Facebook and Google in the mobile ad market, where it expects to capture 2.7% of the $31.5 billion market this year.

site_title: UOB posts 9.2% rise in Q1 profit
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 9.2% increase in Q1 profit to $788 million, beating estimates. Lower taxes and strong loan growth contributed to the better performance. UOB's asset quality remained strong, with a bad loan ratio of 1.1%. The bank's liquidity and funding capabilities were also strengthened, with a 9.7% rise in customer deposits. UOB's shares rose 2.7% to $21.76.

site_title: Emaar may cancel London IPO to focus on Dubai
summary: Emaar Properties, developer of the Burj Khalifa, is considering canceling its planned London IPO to focus on a listing on the Dubai Financial Market (DFM) instead. The company had planned a 25% sale in London and on Dubai's Nasdaq exchange, but is now weighing options, including listing on the DFM, to raise up to $2.45 billion. Dubai's strong market, which has gained 52% this year, is preferred over London, and Emaar's malls and retail business has seen a 20% revenue increase in 2013.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q1 profit up 11% at 799.2m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's first-quarter net profit rose 11% to 799.2 million yuan, driven by a 24% surge in revenue to 3.55 billion yuan. The shipbuilding-related segment contributed 82.3% of the group's total revenue, with revenue from shipbuilding orders reaching US$1.07 billion. The company's shipyards are expected to remain highly utilized until 2016, based on the current outstanding order book of US$5.19 billion for 125 vessels.

site_title: Q1 unemployment edges up to 2.1%
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate rose to 2.1% in the first quarter of 2014, up from 1.8% in December. The resident unemployment rate increased to 2.9%, while citizens saw a 3% rate. Despite the rise, layoffs decreased, with 2,900 workers made redundant, fewer than the 3,660 in the previous quarter. The services sector accounted for the majority of layoffs, with 52% of affected workers. Employment growth fell to 24,900, lower than the previous quarter.

site_title: Line chats up Singapore with local office in Q3
summary: Line, a popular chat app, is opening its first office in Singapore as part of its localization strategy to become the primary messaging app in the market. The office will be operational by the third quarter of the year. Line aims to make users use the app every day and wants to be the main messenger for smartphone users in Singapore. The company plans to tie up with local firms to increase its user base and revenue, particularly from in-game purchases and virtual stickers.

site_title: Soilbuild's Q1 net climbs 4% to $3.9m
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group's net profit for Q1 rose 4% to $3.9 million, driven by revenue growth of 28% to $87.3 million. Despite higher revenue, the group's gross profit margin declined to 7.2% due to additional construction costs. The company has a strong order book of $356.3 million and plans to leverage its construction expertise to seek out additional contract prospects.

site_title: Fiscal red ink poses challenges for Canberra
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's government is expected to unveil a budget with significant austerity measures, including a $34 billion budget deficit and cuts to Medicare, industry assistance, and hospital funding. The plan aims to reduce demand for services by making patients pay for consultations. However, the government's own promises, such as a paid parental leave scheme and F-35 fighter jets, are estimated to cost substantial amounts, sparking criticism of prioritizing spending over pensioner support. The abolition of the carbon tax and mining tax is also expected to reduce revenue.

site_title: General Dynamics bags US$17b deal
summary: The US Navy awarded a $17.6 billion contract to General Dynamics Corp and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc for 10 Virginia-class nuclear-powered attack submarines, the largest-ever Navy shipbuilding contract. The deal, which funds work on two submarines per year from 2014 to 2018, is expected to net savings of over $2 billion, effectively giving the Navy 10 ships for the price of nine. The contract reduces procurement costs and operating costs, allowing for more deployments and maintenance visits, with the Navy already operating 10 Virginia-class submarines.

site_title: M'sia's new budget terminal begins operations tomorrow
summary: Malaysia's new KLIA2 budget terminal, the world's largest airport built specifically for low-cost airlines, begins operations tomorrow. The $1.2 billion facility, covering 24 football fields, features modern design and improved connectivity. Initial 56 flights will be operated by four airlines, with AirAsia to join by May 9. The new terminal is expected to handle 24 million passengers in the first year, with annual capacity of 45 million. The opening comes amid controversy over delays and rising costs, but analysts see it as a long-overdue upgrade to address the region's booming budget travel market.

site_title: General commerce helps bank lending rise 0.6% in March
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 0.6% in March, driven by a 6.9% increase in general commerce loans, which offset slower growth in building and construction loans. Total bank loans grew to $587.7 billion, with business loans expanding 0.7% and consumer loans increasing 0.3%. Manufacturing lending fell 9.6% year-on-year, while property-related loans declined 0.3% month-on-month. Economists expect growth to moderate further in April and May, but anticipate stabilizing around 10-12% year-on-year growth.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's Q1 profit plunges 92.1% to $4.1m
summary: Ho Bee Land's Q1 profit plummeted 92.1% to $4.1 million, largely due to a lack of revenue recognition from development projects. Revenue declined 71.9% to $17.1 million. Despite this, the group's commercial properties are expected to contribute significantly to earnings in the coming years. CEO Chua Thian Poh cautioned that the residential market still faces strong challenges. The company acquired another commercial building in London and reported a 93% increase in rental income from its industrial and commercial properties.

site_title: El Nino will not churn up storm in food prices: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse reports that the risk of Asia's food inflation surging due to El Nino has been overstated. Only two out of four episodes in the past 20 years have seen El Nino coincide with significant food inflation, and even those instances were partly due to other factors. This contradicts previous concerns that El Nino would lead to increased food prices in Asia.

site_title: Top consumer brands not always priciest in S'pore
summary: A government study in Singapore found that prices of branded goods under Apple, Ikea, and Zara were not always the highest, despite Singapore being considered one of the most expensive cities. The study, commissioned by the Monetary Authority and Ministry of Trade and Industry, found that prices were higher than the median for up to two-thirds of the goods surveyed, but the price premiums did not exceed 20% in most cases. Singapore was not the most expensive location in most instances, contradicting The Economist Intelligence Unit's previous report naming Singapore as the most expensive city.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group Q1 profit up 8%
summary: Raffles Medical Group (RMG) reported an 8% year-on-year increase in net profit to $14.56 million in its Q1, driven by a bigger patient load, new specialists, and higher healthcare insurance services. Revenue also rose 8% to $87.55 million, with its hospital services division experiencing a 4.8% increase. Despite a 10-15% decline in medical tourists from Indonesia, the company expects this to rebound. Construction on a new 5-storey building in Holland Village began in April, and RMG is launching a representative office in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

site_title: SpaceX challenges Boeing-Lockheed monopoly
summary: Billionaire Elon Musk's SpaceX has accused the US Air Force of giving Boeing-Lockheed a monopoly on military satellite launches, potentially funneling hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars to Russia's military industrial base. SpaceX seeks to have the Air Force cancel agreements with Boeing-Lockheed's United Launch Alliance and conduct a full and open competition for new launch services. The company claims this practice defers meaningful competition and could save taxpayers over $1 billion a year.

site_title: Returns shortfall widens for S'pore investors
summary: Singapore investors are experiencing a widening gap between their desired and actual investment returns, with an average return of 5.4% compared to a desired 8.5%. The shortfall has increased by 1.2 percentage points from last year, with many preferring a self-directed approach and a strong home bias. Only 27% of Singapore investors shifted their investments to developed markets last year, compared to 52% in Hong Kong. The primary goals of Singapore investors are retirement and wealth growth, but many are not making progress towards these goals, with only 41% and 35% respectively achieving their objectives.

site_title: Far East H-Trust posts lower Q1 DPS of 1.3¢
summary: Far East H-Trust reported a Q1 distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.3 cents, down 5.8% from the previous year, due to softer hotel performance and an enlarged stapled security base. Income available for distribution rose 4.5% to $23.1 million, with gross revenue increasing 9.1% to $30.7 million. Net property income grew 6.3% to $27.6 million. The trust's hotel portfolio average occupancy was 83.4%, 2.1 percentage points below last year's rate. Asset enhancement initiatives are underway to optimize value and competitiveness.

site_title: Improving global economy boosts sentiment
summary: Businesses across Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors have become more optimistic due to improved global economic conditions. Government surveys found that 12% of manufacturers expect better business conditions from April to September, while 5% anticipate deterioration. This shift is driven by better prospects for firms in the electronics and finance sectors. The findings suggest a positive outlook for the economy, with businesses more confident in the coming months.

site_title: Keppel FELS studying rigs with P&A jackups
summary: Keppel FELS has signed an agreement with Workfox BV to study the development of the Seafox 8, a jackup rig with plug & abandonment (P&A) features. The project aims to address the need for P&A services in the North Sea and Gulf of Mexico, where many wells are nearing the end of their productive lives. The Seafox 8 will offer P&A and well intervention services at 25-30% more economical day rates, as well as crane support services and accommodation for 282 persons. The study is expected to be completed in the second half of 2024.

site_title: First-quarter retail rents for prime spots edge up 0.8%
summary: Retail rents for prime spaces in Singapore increased 0.8% in the first quarter, led by Marina, City Hall, and Bugis. Despite a potential 3-5% decline in overall retail rents by year-end, prime space rents are expected to rise 3-5% due to increased supply. Retailers will be more selective in expansion plans, according to Knight Frank's head of consultancy and research, Alice Tan.

site_title: Sydney converting disused toilets into cafes
summary: The City of Sydney is adopting a Public Toilet Strategy, earmarking three historic facilities for conversion into cafes. The strategy aims to utilize prime locations with unique history, following the success of the Gardener's Lodge Cafe, which was converted from a 125-year-old sandstone structure that used to be a public toilet. The city expects the conversions to generate income and help boost the local economy, with experts citing Australia's vibrant coffee culture and growing demand for unique dining experiences.

site_title: Banks propel STI 26.97 points higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 26.97 points to 3,264.71 on Wednesday, April 30, 2014, after banks OCBC and DBS announced better-than-expected results. The index had lost 30 points earlier in the week. The three banks' gains contributed 16 points to the STI's rise, while the Jardine group accounted for another 5 points. Despite the index's large gain, the broad market showed a slight preference for blue chips. The STI gained 76 points for the month, a 2.4% increase.

site_title: SMRT swings back to $16.9m profit in Q4
summary: SMRT Corp reported a $16.9 million net profit for Q4 2014, reversing a $12 million loss from the same period last year. Revenue increased 2.9% to $289.5 million, driven by higher contributions from rail, bus, and non-fare businesses. The company's bus operation losses also decreased.

site_title: Economy maturing, so growth slower: PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country's growth forecast of 2-4% for this year is typical of a maturing economy undergoing a "major transition". To sustain growth, Lee emphasized the importance of developing better workers and creating better jobs, describing it as the "only sustainable way" to raise wages. The government is investing in continuous education and training, and providing incentives to boost productivity and create job opportunities, while urging employers and unions to work together to achieve this goal.

site_title: China set to overtake US as world's biggest economy
summary: China is set to overtake the US as the world's biggest economy, according to the International Comparison Program (ICP) report released by the World Bank. In 2011, China's economy was 87% the size of the US, up from 43% in 2005. India has also jumped to third place, ahead of Japan, due to changes in methodology. The report uses purchasing power parity (PPP) estimates, which take into account the price level difference between countries, and is the most authoritative estimate of what money can buy in different countries.

site_title: Companies selective on governance revisions
summary: Companies in Singapore are largely non-compliant with the Code of Corporate Governance, particularly in limiting multiple directorships and remuneration disclosure. Only 12 out of 50 surveyed companies set a limit for directors, while 30 chose not to, citing that individual assessments are more effective. Remuneration disclosure was also largely non-compliant, with 64% of Mainboard companies and 24% of Catalist companies failing to disclose the remuneration of CEOs and directors by name. The mixed compliance raises questions about the effectiveness and relevance of the Code.

site_title: S'pore remains top offshore RMB hub
summary: Singapore retained its position as the top offshore clearing centre for renminbi (RMB) outside of China and Hong Kong in March, with RMB payments rising 375% from March 2013. The value of Singapore's RMB payments accounted for 6.8% of global volume. This is the second straight month Singapore held the top spot, with RMB growth outpacing the global average 29% month on month. The growth is attributed to Chinese companies using Singapore as a hub for reaching ASEAN countries, with HSBC Singapore reporting a more than doubling of RMB trade volume over the past 12 months.

site_title: Vard's Q1 profit plunges 51.1% to 92m krone
summary: Vard Holdings, an offshore vessel builder, reported a 51.1% year-on-year decline in Q1 net profit to 92 million Norwegian krone due to lower revenue and higher costs. Revenue fell 2.7% to 2.7 billion krone, while operating margin dropped to 4.6% from 10%. However, the company secured eight new contracts, increasing its orderbook to a five-year high. Vard expects strong demand from the subsea support and construction vessel segment despite rising production costs.

site_title: What to peg Reit managers' fees to?
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has revised its performance fee structure, slashing fees by up to 50% after outperforming its benchmark by 16.9% in the first half of 2013. The revised methodology, which benchmarks against a basket of Reits, differs from Starhill Global Reit, which benchmarks against a larger sample of 30 Reits. The change follows CIT's outperformance, which led to a significant increase in fees. Analysts argue that the best fee structure is one that aligns with unitholders' interests, and that the calibre and integrity of the Reit manager is more important than the structure adopted.

site_title: Missing plane may hasten MAS break-up
summary: Malaysia's flag carrier, Malaysian Air, is facing a potential break-up due to its significant losses and declining reputation after the disappearance of flight 370. The airline has run up losses of $1.3 billion in the previous three years and is now projected to lose $346 million by the end of 2016. Analysts suggest breaking up the airline's profitable divisions and selling stakes in aviation businesses could raise $1.6 billion. The government-controlled airline's market value has fallen to its lowest level since 2001, with shares trading at 0.93 times book value.

images.alt_text: Watchful gaze: Malaysian Air missed its target to be profitable last year, as higher costs for items including fuel, maintenance and financing wiped out revenue gains. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Give better deal to POSB customers: DBS shareholders
summary: DBS Group Holdings shareholders called for better deals for POSB customers, particularly higher interest rates for their savings. POSB customers, who used to earn higher interest rates, now earn just 0.05% interest, prompting concerns that they may lose loyalty if rates remain low. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta defended the bank's decision to keep interest rates low, citing the bank's social responsibility and its ability to absorb interest rate reductions. The meeting also saw a pay hike for DBS Chairman Peter Seah, which was questioned by shareholders, but ultimately passed with a majority vote.

site_title: S'pore must press on with restructuring
summary: Singapore must continue its restructuring efforts to achieve its vision of creating "better workers, better jobs", said Acting Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin. The government will focus on continuous learning and skills upgrading, while the Workfare Training Support Scheme will support low-wage workers and older workers. Companies will receive funding support to transform their business models and create better job opportunities. A progressive wage model is being implemented for the cleaning sector, and plans are underway to introduce a similar arrangement for the security sector.

site_title: Land prices expected to ease this year, say analysts
summary: Singapore land prices are expected to soften this year due to declining home prices and sales volumes, with developers becoming more cautious. Analysts predict a 5% drop in new home prices and a 20% decline in sale transactions compared to last year. Completed condo prices fell 1.1% in the past month, and developers' net margins may stay at 9-10%, down from 24% in 2012. Foreign developers, often blamed for bidding up land prices, have a smaller margin buffer and higher winning bid premiums, contributing to the easing competition for land.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q1 earnings up 12%
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 12% rise in Q1 net profit to $231.6 million, driven by better insurance business performance and a one-off gain from divesting its stake in a Chinese joint venture. Earnings per share increased from 44 cents to 49 cents. Total weighted new sales grew 12% to $225.9 million, with gross premiums rising 14% to $1.85 billion. No interim dividend was declared, and the company plans to strengthen its professional advisory force and enhance customer experience.

site_title: Growth frozen as Q1 GDP grows just 0.1%
summary: US GDP grew 0.1% in Q1, the lowest rate in three years, due to harsh winter weather and a drop in exports. Consumer spending, however, rose 3% as households purchased services and health care, boosted by the Affordable Care Act. The growth is expected to rebound in Q2, with economists predicting a 0.5% gain. The labor market also showed signs of progress, with 220,000 new jobs added in April.

site_title: Hedge funds short small caps most in a decade
summary: Hedge funds are betting against small-cap stocks, with a $2.8 billion short position in the Russell 2000 Index, the largest since 2012. This marks a reversal from last year's bullish bets, coinciding with the index's 7.1% decline from its 2014 high. Small-cap companies, which have outperformed the S&P 500 since 2009, are now seen as expensive, reflecting a loss of faith in the five-year equity rally among professional investors.

images.alt_text: Short sales: The biggest speculators have increased short sales and bought hedges in most stocks as technology companies led a decline that erased US$1 trillion from American share values between April 2 and 12. - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Smaller, specialty restaurants in future: Ip
summary: Crystal Jade CEO Ip Yiu Tung suggests that the future of dining will focus on smaller, specialty restaurants offering simpler food options, such as Cantonese-style noodles and barbecued meats. Ip, who sold the Crystal Jade group to private equity fund L Capital Asia, attributes the trend to consumers' preference for smaller, more intimate dining experiences. He also plans to explore one-cuisine restaurants in the future, citing his own experience with his piano manufacturing business.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: LVMH buys Chinese restaurant group Crystal Jade for $100m. Acting Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin and Acting Culture, Community and Youth Minister Lawrence Wong will become full ministers. Higher wage costs will continue to affect profit margins. Investors in Singapore see a widening gap between desired and actual investment returns. Alibaba expands US patent holdings to avoid past IPO pitfalls. Bank of America discloses a significant error in its financial calculations.

site_title: Australia expands MH370 search
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott announced an expanded search area for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, covering nearly 60,000 sq km of ocean floor. The search, now in its 52nd day, has yielded no surface or underwater wreckage. It is "highly unlikely" that any surface debris will be found, with most material likely to have sunk due to waterlogging. The search will now focus on undersea efforts, estimated to cost A$60 million and take six to eight months.

site_title: Partnership is key to Changi's success, says Lui
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew emphasized the importance of partnership in Changi Airport's success, citing a need for win-win solutions and close cooperation with airlines to remain competitive. The airport handled a record 53.7 million passengers last year, with growth projected at 3-5% this year. Changi Airport Group plans to expand passenger capacity with new terminals, including Terminal 4 and Terminal 5, which will increase capacity to 135 million passengers annually by the mid-2020s.

site_title: Fragrance Q1 net jumps 38% to $24.3 million
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 38% year-on-year jump in first-quarter net profit to $24.26 million, driven by a decrease in profit contribution from its Parc Rosewood project. Revenue from its property segment grew 15.6% to $111.5 million, while hotel revenue slipped 5.4%. The company's cash and cash equivalents reached $137.24 million at the end of the first quarter.

site_title: HPH Trust's Q1 earnings up 47% at HK$558.9m
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a 47% increase in net profit to HK$558.9 million for its Q1 2014, driven by unitholder gains from the disposal of a 60% effective interest in Asia Container Terminals. Revenue rose 2.7% to HK$2.95 billion, and earnings per share increased to 6.42 HK cents. The trust is optimistic about the year ahead, citing favourable market outlook for the US and Europe, and expects growth in transshipment and niche trade routes.

site_title: MNCs shifting focus as services' share of economic pie grows
summary: Multinationals are shifting their focus from manufacturing to delivering services as the services industry grows in importance as an engine of growth. In Singapore, services now account for more than two-thirds of total output and have nearly quadrupled in exports over the past decade. The country's competitiveness in business services stems from its attractiveness as a location for regional headquarters, while the financial services sector is anchored by globally competitive clusters. This trend, known as "servicisation," is expected to accelerate in the coming years, driven by higher profit potential.

site_title: Sapphire shares soar 38% on news of steel business sale
summary: Sapphire Corp's shares surged 38% on news it's selling its Chinese steel business for $70 million, avoiding delisting from the Singapore Exchange. The sale will drive the firm into mining services and allow it to explore new engineering-related businesses. CEO Teh Wing Kwan called the deal a "light at the end of the tunnel" and aims to complete the sale and embark on new ventures within six months.

site_title: Hedge-fund startups adapt to MAS rules
summary: Singaporean hedge-fund startups are adapting to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) tightened regulations by turning to licensed platforms that provide office space and services to meet compliance requirements. The platforms offer cost-effective solutions for smaller managers to reduce costs and focus on their investment skills. Since the introduction of the new rules in 2012, 20 managers have signed up with Swiss-Asia Financial, with the number of new funds set up more than doubling to seven at Gordian Capital. The platforms provide a network of investors, reduce administrative burdens, and mitigate operational risks, making them an attractive option for smaller managers.

site_title: Lack of big-name IPOs, penny stock crash hurt SGX
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, the Singapore Exchange Limited (SGX), saw its net profits slump 22.4% year-on-year in March due to a lack of big-name IPOs and a multi-billion-dollar penny-stock crash. The exchange's total securities trading volume fell 47% during the same period. Analysts attribute the woes to soft volumes, making it less attractive for foreign firms to list on the exchange. Regulatory reforms, including minimum trading prices and collateral requirements, have been proposed to address the issues, but may deter new companies from listing.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines expects IPO nod in June
summary: Vietnam Airlines is expected to receive approval for its initial public offering (IPO) in June, with a valuation of US$2.74 billion. The airline plans to offer a "suitable" stake based on market demand, aiming to attract overseas investors. Vietnam is speeding up share sales in state-run companies to restructure the economy and lure foreign investors. The airline is valued among the largest state-owned enterprises operating profitably, making it an attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: S Korea vows to revamp shipping industry laws
summary: South Korea vowed to overhaul shipping industry regulations amid growing anger over the nation's worst maritime disaster in four decades. The ferry Sewol sank on April 16, killing 304 people, including mostly high school students. The government announced it would study structural problems and punish those involved, including crew members and regulators, with severe punishment. Prime Minister Chung Hong Won resigned amid public anger and the ruling party's declining support, while investigators are probing the cause of the disaster, including possible overspeeding and cargo overload.

site_title: UK home prices continue climb in April
summary: UK house prices increased 0.6% in April for a 15th consecutive month, with 48% of postcodes reporting an increase, the highest proportion in a decade. The momentum in the property market is driven by record-low Bank of England interest rates, a shortage of properties, and a strengthening economy. New buyers registering with real-estate agents rose 3.3%, while the time a property is on the market before it sells dropped to 6.3 weeks. Officials are monitoring the market for signs of price increases jeopardizing financial stability.

site_title: Loans, better margins lift banks' Q1 earnings
summary: Singapore's local banks, OCBC, DBS, and UOB, reported strong Q1 earnings despite challenging fixed income markets. OCBC Bank saw its net profit rise 29% to $899 million, while DBS Bank's core net profit increased 9% to $1.03 billion. Loan volumes grew in double-digit terms, driven by regional market gains. Bank stocks rose, with UOB up 2.7%, OCBC up 1.9%, and DBS up 0.6%. The banks' improved margins were attributed to higher loan spreads and increased income from money market activities.

images.alt_text: Local banks had their stars aligned in the first quarter of this year, as higher loan volumes and improved margins pushed up earnings - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Not in our cruise-ship-hub backyard
summary: A proposed US$250 million stadium for a Major League Soccer expansion team in Miami, led by soccer star David Beckham, has sparked opposition from Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd and billionaire Norman Braman, who want the land used for port-related purposes. The stadium's construction risks raising the county's borrowing costs for the port, which is already struggling with debt. Beckham's team plans to pay rent to the county for the land, but critics argue that the project could create traffic problems and strain the port's resources. A decision on the land is expected to be made by Miami-Dade County commissioners and Mayor Carlos Gimenez.

site_title: DBS Q1 earnings up 30% at $1.23b
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 30% increase in net profit to $1.23 billion in its first quarter, beating expectations. Core net profit rose 9% to a record $1.03 billion, driven by higher loan volumes and improved margins. Total income rose 6% to a new high of $2.45 billion, with net interest income increasing 2% and non-interest income rising 38%. The bank's annualized earnings per share rose to $1.78, up from $1.58 a year ago.

site_title: Creative narrows net loss in Q3
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$8.76 million in Q3 2014, down from US$10.45 million in the same period last year, due to lower turnover of 26%. Gross profit margin slipped to 22% from 25%. The company expects an operating loss for the current quarter and warns that H2 revenue may be below target, with operating loss similar to that in H1.

site_title: Mapletree in serviced apartment venture
summary: Mapletree Group has formed a joint venture with Oakwood Asia Pacific to develop and acquire over 100 new corporate and serviced apartment properties worldwide over the next five years. Mapletree will hold a 49% stake in Oakwood Asia Pacific and invest US$4 billion in Asia, Europe, and North America. The partnership aims to triple the number of branded Oakwood buildings globally, filling a gap in Mapletree's asset spectrum. The move is driven by the growing demand for serviced apartments in Asia, particularly among transient professionals and expats.

site_title: Top bid for Potong Pasir plot seen at $650-900 psf ppr
summary: A commercial and residential site near Potong Pasir MRT Station has launched for sale with a top bid forecast of $650-900 per square foot. The site, which can accommodate up to 5,000 sq m of commercial use, is expected to draw four to eight bids. The tender closes on August 19.

site_title: Small but crucial Q3 profit for Grand Banks
summary: Grand Banks Yachts reported its second consecutive quarterly net profit of $0.54 million for Q3 2014, reversing a net loss of $2.9 million in the same period last year. The company aims to meet Singapore Exchange's requirements to be removed from its watch-list by June 30, having already applied for an extension. Revenue declined 20.8% to $8.1 million, but gross profit rose 32.3% to $1.7 million. The company's cash and cash equivalents remained healthy at $22.3 million.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Palm oil firms Wilmar International and Golden Agri Resources have committed to applying their sustainability policies to suppliers. The Singapore labor market is expected to remain tight until 2020. Japan's aggressive bank lending efforts are raising concerns about rising bad debt. US stocks are expected to remain positive despite Ukraine tensions. Foreign workers' housing is a lucrative business, with Centurion Corp's stocks soaring. The 1MDB IPO is being contested by Aabar and Tanjong. China's weakening yuan may be due to policy or economic growth. The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep its stimulus taper on track.

site_title: Resignations hit Keppel T&T ahead of Reit listing
summary: Keppel T&T's CEO Pang Hee Hon plans to step down amid senior resignations at the company, which is preparing to list its data centre business as a real estate investment trust (Reit). The departures include Bruno Lopez, Jonathan King, and Nicholas Toh, who led the data centre business and were also co-fund managers of Securus Data Property Fund. The resignations raise concerns about the listing, which could impact the company's IPO plans and shareholder value. Keppel T&T's data centre segment has seen significant growth, and analysts expect it to gain more traction with the growth in cloud computing and e-commerce.

site_title: 'Pricey in Singapore' unlikely to last
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) latest review suggests that Singapore's growth profile will be affected by cyclical and structural factors, with cost pressures expected to persist. A study on consumer price differentials found that prices of internationally branded goods in Singapore are above the median level in two-thirds of products, with a price premium of up to 20% for certain items. The study attributes the higher prices to cost and demand factors, including high operating costs and a relatively high consumer market. However, with the rise of e-commerce, price differentials are expected to narrow or disappear in the future.

site_title: Results snapshot
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and People's Bank of China will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts Q1 DPU of 1.24 cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.24 cents, a 9.5% decline from the previous year. Net property income (NPI) fell 6.7% to $39.1 million, largely due to a one-time receipt of accumulated rental arrears in Q1 last year. Excluding this, revenue and NPI would have been 1.8% and 2.5% higher, driven by strong Singapore portfolio performance. The Reit's manager plans to continue active asset management efforts and source for yield-accretive acquisitions.

site_title: S'pore market cap grows 3.8% in April
summary: The Singapore stock market's total market capitalisation rose 3.8% in April to $950.7 billion, its highest value since May last year. Large caps led the growth, with the top 10% of stocks by market value increasing 3.98% and the smallest 10% growing 0.3%. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 2.39% to close at 3,264.71. Two initial public offerings boosted the market, and Telco giant Singapore Telecommunications saw its market cap grow 24.5% to $64 billion. Analysts expect some volatility in May.

site_title: OCBC reports 29% profit rise for Q1; pins China hopes on Wing Hang
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 29% profit rise for Q1, beating analyst estimates, with earnings per share reaching 26.2 cents. The bank attributes this growth to its proposed $6.2 billion acquisition of Wing Hang Bank, which could aid in expanding branches in China through a free trade pact. OCBC aims to tap into China's growing market by targeting top Chinese corporations and SME clients, with a focus on tying personal wealth to business loans to mitigate risks.

site_title: Focus on the Big Picture as the US economy gains momentum
summary: The US economy is gaining momentum, despite concerns over China's slowing economy and geopolitical risks. US monetary policy normalization is seen as a positive factor for market fundamentals. The Fed's tapering process is expected to continue, but interest rates may not rise until the economy shows signs of stronger growth. Emerging markets with strong current accounts and reserves, such as Asia and North Asia, are likely to attract interest in the long term, while Europe may outperform in the short term due to improving fundamentals and attractive valuations. Investors should focus on fundamentals and be patient, as the market is expected to experience volatility as it adapts to the normalisation of monetary policy.

site_title: Better year seen for Hutchison Port trust
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings (HPH) Trust reported a 47% increase in net income in its first-quarter results, driven by the settlement of labor problems and higher cargo volumes to the US and Europe. Analysts see this as a positive sign for the company, with Barclays Research expecting 2014 to be a turnaround year. The trust's dividend yield is also attractive, with an 8.1% yield. However, OCBC Investment Research notes risks, including rising external contractor costs and inflationary pressures, which may impact the company's expansion plans.

site_title: Some Asian bonds better than Western counterparts
summary: Asian high-grade bonds outperformed US and European bonds in the first quarter, with an average spread of 185 basis points compared to 119 and 113 basis points respectively. Asian high-grade credit also delivered higher total returns, despite a marked underperformance last year. The report, from the Asia Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, attributes the better performance to the US Federal Reserve's tapering and interest rate concerns. Total Asian bond issuance in the first quarter fell 13.7% year-on-year to $39.7 billion, with Chinese bonds accounting for half of all outstanding local-currency debt.

site_title: IndoAgri's Q1 net profit rises 70% to 182b rupiah
summary: Indofood Agri Resources' net profit rose 70% to 182 billion rupiah in Q1, driven by a 2.4% revenue increase and foreign exchange gains. The firm's earnings per share jumped to 1.4 Singapore cents from 0.8 cent last year. Despite dry weather in Indonesia affecting production, the company aims to grow 5-10% in production for the full year. IndoAgri is also positioning itself for the new law in Indonesia disallowing bulk purchase of cooking oil, and is exploring expansion opportunities outside of Indonesia.

site_title: Aspial buys third Melbourne property this year
summary: ASPIAL Corporation has acquired its third Melbourne property this year, purchasing the 54-64 A'Beckett Street site for A$26.8 million. The freehold building sits on a 1,295 square meter plot and has an active planning permit for a 49-storey tower with residential, serviced residence, and retail components. This purchase marks Aspial's continued expansion in Australia.

site_title: Tan Chuan-Jin and Lawrence Wong made full ministers
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced promotions to Tan Chuan-Jin and Lawrence Wong, making them full ministers. Tan will remain Acting Manpower Minister, while Wong will become Second Minister at the Ministry of Communications and Information. Other changes include Sam Tan becoming Minister of State in the Prime Minister's Office and Denise Phua taking over his post at Central Singapore CDC. Fellow backbencher Lam Pin Min will join the Health Ministry as a Minister of State on August 1, and Amy Khor will give up her position as Mayor of Southwest CDC.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q1 net profit up 33% at $7.7m
summary: Tuan Sing Group's net profit rose 33% to $7.7 million in Q1 2014, driven by a 49% increase in property revenue. Industrial services sales declined 6%, but investment properties grew 40% due to new bookings. The company sold 582 units with a total order book of $745.6 million, expecting significant revenue recognition in 2014 and 2015. Despite market sentiment affecting its business, Tuan Sing remains optimistic about achieving satisfactory operational performance.

site_title: Goodman suitors eye due-diligence
summary: Wilmar International and Hong Kong-listed First Pacific have decided to pursue a due-diligence process with Goodman Fielder despite being rejected by the Australian baking firm's board. The rejected bid, valued at A$1.3 billion, was a 50:50 joint venture with a 23.8% premium over Goodman Fielder's closing price. A rise in the firm's share price and investor approval indicate that the deal may not be over yet. Goodman Fielder will continue to assess other opportunities to maximize shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Wilmar said that it intended to fund its share of the cost of acquisition from existing cash resources and bank facilities - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Mostly positive signs - outside of Ukraine
summary: The global economy is showing mostly positive signs, except for Ukraine, where tensions between Russia and the West continue to escalate. The US labor market has seen a strong jobs growth, with over 200,000 jobs added in April, and average hourly wages are rising. The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its gradual approach to normalizing interest rates. In contrast, the Russian stock market has sold off due to economic sanctions, which could also affect European businesses, particularly those in the energy sector.

site_title: IMF: Adjustments of HK property prices necessary
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Hong Kong's property prices are set to see adjustments due to the expected US tapering and interest rate hike. The city's housing market has seen a significant boom since 2008, with prices more than doubling. The IMF recommends that the government consider easing cooling measures when prices fall more significantly, aiming for a "soft landing" to achieve steady growth. The IMF projects Hong Kong's GDP to grow 3.7% this year and 3.8% next year, with Asia's growth expected to remain steady at 5.4%.

site_title: Homesnap app gives house buyers instant information
summary: Homesnap, a Washington-based start-up, offers an app that provides instant information about nearby houses to home buyers. Users can snap a photo of a home and access data such as number of bedrooms and baths, tax records, and school boundaries. The app won a pitch contest at the South by Southwest conference in 2012 and received investment from Steve Case, founder of Revolution. Since its launch, Homesnap has become popular among consumers seeking transparent data in the home buying process.

site_title: CPF Board recovers $420m in employer contribution arrears
summary: The CPF Board in Singapore recovered $420 million in employer contribution arrears last year, a significant increase from $293 million in 2012. This was attributed to stepped-up enforcement efforts and increased awareness of workers' rights, generated by the WorkRight initiative. The recovered arrears will benefit 250,000 local workers, covering underpayment, non-payment, and late payment of CPF contributions.

site_title: Small investors are better off in US markets today: Citadel
summary: A top Citadel executive, Jamil Nazarali, says small investors are better off in US markets today due to a more favorable structure compared to 10-15 years ago. This comes after the publication of Michael Lewis's book, "Flash Boys," which argued the US stock market is rigged. Citadel's role in the discussion stems from its unit, which executes orders for brokerages and tends to favor individual customers. Nazarali believes the current market is one of the few where small investors receive a better deal than large ones.

site_title: Elderly suffering in NYC housing crisis
summary: New York City's housing crisis disproportionately affects its elderly population, with fewer market-rate housing options available for older adults compared to other major metropolitan areas. The city's older population is expected to grow significantly by 2030, with nearly 4,000 names on a waiting list for affordable residences. Many older New Yorkers struggle to find affordable housing, with 51% of renter households led by an older New Yorker paying at least 35% of their income in rent. The city has no comprehensive housing plan to accommodate its aging population, and advocates are urging Mayor Bill de Blasio to incorporate senior units into his housing targets.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic still undecided about A380s: CEO
summary: Virgin Atlantic Airways CEO Craig Kreeger stated that the airline still has not decided whether to operate the world's largest passenger plane, the A380, despite having options for six aircraft. Virgin last deferred A380 delivery plans to 2018 in July. The airline is instead focusing on receiving its first Boeing 787 Dreamliners in September, which will improve efficiency and enhance customer service. Virgin has ordered 16 787s, with options for five more, and is preparing to welcome passengers on its first 787 flights starting in November.

site_title: Mounting fears of rising bad debt at Japan's banks
summary: Japan's aggressive push to boost the economy through new bank loans may lead to a mounting level of bad debt. Despite the Bank of Japan's positive data on economic recovery, core profitability of banks remains on a downward trend due to narrowing interest rate spreads. This could constrain financial institutions' ability to absorb losses and take on risks, posing a challenge to the stability of the overall financial system. Analysts attribute the issue to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policy, which has not yielded the expected response from businesses and consumers.

site_title: Governments favouring indirect taxes to raise revenues: KPMG
summary: A KPMG report found that one in 10 countries increased indirect tax rates over the past 15 months, with none lowering such levies. Indirect taxes, which aren't directly imposed on income, are becoming the "tax of choice" for governments worldwide. Singapore has the fourth-lowest indirect tax rate at 7%, while its corporate tax rate remains the lowest in ASEAN at 17%. The report suggests that corporate tax rates may fluctuate due to tax transparency and morality issues, and businesses should adapt to the increasing complexities of indirect taxes.

site_title: Bringing the Game to the table
summary: Geek Crusade co-founders Gillian Ang and Nicholas Yong launched a literary supperclub, "Dinner is Coming," inspired by Game of Thrones, in Singapore. The first dinner, themed around the show, was held at Italian restaurant No Menu, coinciding with the start of the fourth season. This spin-off allows fans to discuss favorite books and shows over a meal, creating a community for like-minded individuals to share their passion for pop culture.

site_title: Preview for Sungei Ulu Pandan project today
summary: The 99-year leasehold development Waterfront@Faber in Sungei Ulu Pandan will open for preview today. Prices for units start from $863,000 for a two-bedroom dual key unit, with indicative prices ranging from $2.48 million for strata-landed units. Developed by World Class Land, the project comprises 199 units and 11 strata houses, offering proximity to various amenities such as JEM and Clementi Mall.

site_title: Smart-city ambitions interest Siemens
summary: Siemens AG, a German multinational engineering company, is closely following Singapore's efforts to become a smart city. The company's CEO, Armin Bruck, stated that Siemens' environmental portfolio generated 32.3 billion euros in revenue in 2013, accounting for 43% of the company's total earnings. Siemens is monitoring Singapore's proposed high-speed train project and has implemented mass transit implementations in the Asean region. The company also developed an Integrated Mobility Platform to facilitate multi-modal travel and reduce carbon footprint. Bruck emphasized the need for good governance, legislation, and holistic planning to ensure sustainable city growth.

site_title: Cosco Corp's Q1 profit up 30%
summary: Cosco Corp, a Chinese state-owned shipbuilder, reported a 30% increase in Q1 net profit to $12.6 million, the highest in over a year. Revenue rose 42% to $1.04 billion, driven by higher income from ship repair and marine engineering. However, the company's order book decreased to $7.6 billion, down from $7.8 billion at the end of 2013. Cosco expects difficult business conditions in 2014 due to market uncertainty.

site_title: Fitness First beefing up Asian presence
summary: Fitness First, a UK-based gym chain, plans to invest US$142 million in its Asian presence, focusing on Singapore and Thailand. The 5-year expansion program aims to grow its Asian footprint by 60% by 2018, with 50 new outlets and a 66% increase in membership to over 350,000 people. The majority of the investment, US$100 million, will fund new outlets, while US$42 million will upgrade existing facilities. Singapore is expected to see 30 of the new outlets, with revenue growth of 12% year-to-date, making the region a promising market.

site_title: ECB probes banks' risky shipping loans
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is investigating banks' risky shipping loans, particularly those with German lenders HSH Nordbank, Commerzbank, and Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale. The ECB is reviewing whether these banks have sufficient capital to absorb potential losses on these loans, which are among the riskiest assets on banks' balance sheets. German shipping banks face concerns over whether they can recover their investments and whether they need to boost capital to support their risk exposure. The ECB's review may lead to banks being forced to raise more capital to reflect the greater risk of default.

images.alt_text: As it tries to clean up the region's banks, the ECB is taking a closer look at whether they need more capital to absorb possible losses on loans like Mr Robrahn's - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: IMF sees growth across Asia at 5.5% this year
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts Asia's growth to remain steady at 5.5% this year and the next, driven by a pickup in export demand from advanced economies. However, the outlook could change if global liquidity tightens more suddenly and China's slowdown proves more serious. The IMF warns of potential risks, including a sharper-than-expected slowdown in China, Japan's slower-than-expected growth, and domestic vulnerabilities in some Asian economies. Despite these risks, the IMF notes that financial stability risks appear contained and regional integration is propelling Asia's growth.

site_title: Labour crunch will stay for many years: Swee Say
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to remain tight until 2020 and become even tighter for a decade after that, according to labour chief Lim Swee Say. The labour market's competitiveness is driven by productivity and innovation, rather than manpower numbers, leading to a faster pace of economic restructuring. The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has promised to upgrade skills and create more good jobs for workers to grow the economic pie. The government must ensure that all parties, including businesses, workers, and the government, are not stressed by this restructuring, with Lim warning that failure could lead to higher unemployment and job mismatches.

site_title: Buying sharply up from a week ago
summary: Insider buying activity in Singapore surged last week, with 12 companies recording 23 purchases worth $1.43 million, outweighing two firms with six disposals worth $0.94 million. Notable acquisitions include purchases by non-executive director Hiew Yoon Khong in Mapletree Commercial Trust and Keppel Corporation. Meanwhile, Aberdeen Asset Management Asia made significant purchases in Venture Corporation and Keppel Corporation, boosting its deemed stakes. The buying rebounded sharply after falling for two straight weeks, while the selling among directors rose sharply.

site_title: South Korean PM quits over ferry disaster
summary: South Korean Prime Minister Chung Hong-Won resigned on April 27, 2014, citing corruption and "deep-rooted evil" for the sinking of the ferry Sewol, which killed 300 people. Chung admitted he was not up to the task of directing rescue operations, and blamed the disaster on societal corruption and lax safety standards. President Park Geun-hye approved his resignation, but Chung would remain in the post until the rescue operation was completed. Relatives of the dead and missing demanded severe punishment for those responsible and urged a speedy recovery of the bodies.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Companies are largely rejecting recommendations to limit multiple directorships on their boards. The IMF forecasts Asia's growth at 5.5% this year. Land prices are expected to ease due to home prices slipping and increased supply. Governments favor indirect taxes to raise revenues. Goodman Group is pursuing due diligence with Wilmar and First Pacific after being snubbed by Australia's Goodman Fielder. Ho Bee Land's Q1 profit plummeted 92.1% to $4.1 million. Rohde & Schwarz expanded its local R&D in Singapore. US President Barack Obama signed three deals worth $1.8 billion with Malaysian firms. China's loan guarantees are sparking default risks.

site_title: Golden Agri turns over a new leaf
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR), a leading Indonesian palm oil producer, has transformed from a black sheep to a leader in sustainable palm oil policies. In 2009, GAR faced criticism from Greenpeace over deforestation and peatland clearing, prompting a pause in land clearing and a new forest conservation policy in 2011. The company has since extended its policy to all third-party suppliers and introduced a yield improvement programme. GAR now engages the Indonesian government to implement its policies, emphasizing the need for a multi-stakeholder approach to achieve sustainability.

site_title: Malaysia not ready to sign TPP yet, says Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak stated that his country is not ready to sign the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact due to domestic "sensitivities." Despite agreeing to upgrade bilateral relations with US President Barack Obama, Najib emphasized that Malaysia prioritizes economic integration within the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) bloc. The US leader acknowledged domestic opposition to trade deals and expressed willingness to be flexible on sensitive areas. The decision marks a setback for Obama's efforts to convince Asian partners of the US's strategic "pivot" to increase US influence in Asia.

site_title: Next steps: forest restoration service, changes to supply chain
summary: A company called New Forests is exploring a forest restoration service to help companies offset the environmental impact of palm oil production. Under the RSPO certification program, companies that cleared land since 2005 without assessing its conservation value must develop a compensation program or be excluded from certification. New Forests restores habitats and sells credits for environmental benefits, and sees demand for this service taking off in the US in the next 1-2 years. The industry is also expected to move towards large-scale segregated supply chains for certified and non-certified palm oil, driven by growing demand from companies and countries.

site_title: Cashless payments take flight on mobiles in Asia
summary: In Asia, mobile startups are developing cashless payment systems for those without bank accounts. Nearex offers a POS device allowing shopkeepers to accept pre-paid cash cards, while 2C2P provides a payment gateway for e-commerce sites. In countries like Thailand, where cash is still king, mobile payments are increasingly popular, with 637% increase in mobile-based sales in one e-commerce store. Mobile money services like Banko in the Philippines have also gained traction, with 561,000 user accounts created as of April 2014, and facilitating 614 billion pesos in transactions in 2012.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q1 profit down 1.7% at $182.8m
summary: CapitaLand reported a 1.7% drop in Q1 net profit to $182.8 million, with revenue decreasing 3.4% to $612.6 million. The Singapore unit was the only one to fail to record higher revenue, primarily due to sales tapering off and rental income from a divested property. The company expects demand for private homes to moderate, but the long-term residential market outlook remains positive.

site_title: China budget carrier Spring plans 2.5b yuan IPO
summary: China's budget airline Spring Airlines plans to raise 2.5 billion yuan (S$505 million) in an initial public offering to fund fleet expansion and replenish working capital. The company, which operates 64 routes and 39 Airbus A320 jets, aims to purchase up to nine A320 aircraft and three flight simulators. Spring Airlines first announced plans for an IPO in 2009, but delayed several times due to sluggish conditions. The IPO must still pass review by the China Securities Regulatory Commission before approval.

site_title: Mapping system could be Nokia's hidden gem
summary: Nokia has sold its global phone business to Microsoft for $7.5 billion, marking the end of the company's presence in the phone market. However, Nokia's mapping system, Here, which provides detailed and up-to-date digital maps, is seen as a potential hidden gem and could become a multibillion-dollar target. Here dominates the global market for built-in car navigation systems, with 80% market share, and is updated 2.7 million times a day. Despite generating only 7% of Nokia's revenue, Here's operating loss was $212 million, raising questions about the company's ability to sustain the mapping operation.

site_title: Doing more to consume less
summary: Businesses can significantly reduce their carbon footprint by implementing internal brand programs, engaging employees, and adopting sustainable practices. Companies like Opower, StarHub, and City Developments Ltd have made significant strides in reducing energy consumption and emissions through initiatives such as energy-efficient technology, paperless processes, and eco-friendly community programs. Financial benefits, such as cost savings and increased capital value, can also be achieved through sustainability efforts. A shift in consumer behavior, driven by social media campaigns and increased transparency, is also crucial in compelling businesses to adopt environmentally friendly practices.

site_title: 'No' to quotas for gender diversity: S'pore
summary: Singapore has decided against implementing quotas to increase the representation of women on corporate boards, instead opting for a softer approach that includes providing training for women and incorporating gender diversity as a best practice in corporate governance. The Diversity Task Force, established in 2012, recommends that 1,000 women be trained and board-ready by 2020, aiming for a fifth of all directorships. The approach is seen as a more effective way to address the issue, allowing companies to appreciate women's talents on their own merit.

site_title: Investors' search for yield lifts Asian bond market again
summary: Asian bond markets have seen a surge in demand, with Asia ex-Japan US dollar-denominated bond volume reaching US$26.8 billion in April, a 7.5% increase from January's record-breaking monthly figure. Investors are seeking yield, shrugging off concerns over emerging markets and China's slowing growth. State-owned Chinese companies have issued numerous bonds, attracting orders from US funds and Asian investors. Despite geopolitical uncertainties, interest rates remain low, incentivizing investors to buy credit and gain a spread over the risk-free rate.

site_title: Bezos pushes tech stocks down with his own spending
summary: Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos announced plans to continue his spending spree, causing a 10% drop in Amazon shares and an industrywide decline in tech stocks, including Facebook, Twitter, Netflix, and LinkedIn. The decline is attributed to Bezos' investments in warehouses, a grocery delivery service, and a TV set-top box, which are expected to result in an operating loss of $55-455 million this quarter. This move has led to a shift in momentum in the tech market, with investors seeking more profit-driven strategies.

site_title: Top arbitration lawyer moves to S'pore
summary: Top arbitration lawyer Lucy Reed is relocating to Singapore from Hong Kong to join global law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer. Reed, a top-tier international arbitration practitioner, will strengthen the firm's international arbitration presence in Asia. Singapore is now considered a world-class arbitration centre, with the government supporting its development through favourable legislation and the creation of Maxwell Chambers. The move is expected to grow Singapore's arbitration practice substantially over the next decade, potentially doubling in size.

site_title: Encounter of the celestial 'bling'
summary: A rare celestial event, known as a "blinking star," was spotted in the sky. The phenomenon, caused by a massive dust cloud blocking the star's light, was observed by astronomers. The star's appearance changed from a steady glow to a brief flash before returning to its normal state. This event is a rare occurrence due to the star's location and the dust cloud's size.

site_title: US committed to supporting MH370 search: Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama said the US is committed to providing resources to assist in the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in the southern Indian Ocean. The search has been ongoing for over seven weeks, with a US Navy submersible drone scanning a remote patch of the ocean seabed, but bad weather has hindered efforts. Authorities are regrouping to decide how to proceed, with a possible extension of the search area if the US Bluefin-21 drone fails to find signs of the plane.

images.alt_text: Mr Obama: 'I can tell you the United States is absolutely committed to providing whatever resources and assets that we can.' - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: More Mini
summary: The new Mini Cooper S is bigger, more refined, and lighter than its predecessor. The third generation of the modern Mini has a longer wheelbase, wider tracks, and a more spacious four-seater cabin. The car now features a 2.0-liter TwinPower Turbo engine, producing 192hp and 280Nm, and an adaptive suspension system. Despite its increased size, the Mini Cooper S is marginally lighter, weighing 1,180 kg. The car has a smoother ride, improved refinement, and a more mature cabin, while still maintaining its fun and agile handling.

site_title: Modern spin on local favourites
summary: Ujong, a modern Singaporean restaurant at Raffles Hotel, reinterprets local favorites with Japanese or Italian influences, but the execution falls short of expectations. Chef Shen Tan's enthusiasm and down-to-earth ambience are endearing, but dishes like chicken rice and bak chor mee pasta lack sophistication. The restaurant's pricing, while not high, will be a challenge for diners to overcome their preconceived notions of hawker food. The pulot hitam pudding is a standout, and tweaks to the menu are recommended to address issues with meat quality and presentation. Rating: 6.5/10.

site_title: Topless luxury
summary: The BMW 435i Convertible boasts improved agility and refinement, making it nearly indistinguishable from the coupe version. The new 4 Series Convertible features a lightweight construction concept, reducing weight by 20 kg, and a rigid retractable roof with improved acoustic insulation. The car delivers spirited performance with a 3.0-liter turbocharged engine and features a low center of gravity due to its wider track and lower stance. With its upscale cabin and dynamics, the 435i Convertible stands out as one of the most dynamic open-top cars available.

site_title: STI Reserve List: From the bench to the benchmark
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI), a composite benchmark of Singapore's 30 largest stocks, provides a stable and diverse investment opportunity. The index accounts for over half of Singapore's stock market capitalization, featuring well-known local corporations like Singapore Airlines and DBS Group. The STI's performance is seen as a proxy for the health of corporate Singapore and the global economy. The index's constituent stocks offer exposure to 14 sectors and geographic markets, with a combined market capitalization of over $25 billion. The STI Reserve List, comprising five stocks, is a buffer for index changes and includes companies like Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust and Keppel Land. Exposure to the STI can provide investors with access to the stability and diversity of its component stocks, making it a popular benchmark for managed funds.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts DPS for Q1 up 2.2% at 2.75 cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 2.2% increase in income available for distribution per stapled security to 2.75 cents in its Q1 2014 results. Net property income rose 4.1% to $36.7 million, driven by a 15.3% increase in revenue from its Maldives resorts. The group's Singapore hotels also contributed to the growth, with an average occupancy rate of 88.2% in Q1. However, the Australian hotels faced pressure due to the weakening Australian dollar and a restrained corporate travel environment.

site_title: It houses foreign workers comfortably
summary: Centurion Corp, Singapore's only listed dormitory operator, has seen its stock soar to over 70 cents a share, more than two-and-a-half times its value a year ago. The company fills a gap in liveable spaces for foreign workers, with occupancy rates almost full. Analysts attribute the stock's rise to its exposure to cashflow-generating property assets in the undersupplied foreign worker dorm segment, where rent per bed has increased 20% annually. Construction group Lian Beng also invested in the company in March.

site_title: On the corporate governance of REITs
summary: REITs have outperformed the equity and bond markets as an asset class, with Asian REITs returning 8.2% per annum from 2011 to 2013, compared to 3.8% for equities and 2.4% for bonds. Singapore's S-REITs, specifically, achieved a 13.7% return over the same period. Experts are now questioning whether the structure of S-REITs can be streamlined while maintaining their tax-exempt status. This could lead to potential reforms in the corporate governance of REITs in Singapore.

site_title: SMRT provides main talking point in ho-hum week
summary: SMRT's stock surged 19% to a four-month high, sparking a "Trade With Caution" notice from the Singapore Exchange. Brokers speculate that SMRT may be close to striking a deal with regulators to turn its loss-making units around, but Maybank Kim Eng warned against the speculation, advising investors to stay cautious. Despite the TWC notice, SMRT's shares held steady, rising 24 cents or 23.5% for the week.

site_title: Sustainability: new ball game for palm oil firms
summary: The palm oil industry has reached a significant milestone with two major players, Wilmar International and Golden Agri Resources, announcing their sustainability policies will apply to suppliers. Wilmar, which sources about half of its palm oil from third parties, and Golden Agri, which sources 7% from third parties, set a higher bar for the industry. Analysts expect this move to have a limited immediate impact, as the industry has been working towards sustainability for years. The move is seen as a positive step towards a more sustainable palm oil industry, but its full impact remains to be seen.

site_title: UOB to focus on organic growth: CEO
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong announced the bank will focus on organic growth, but will consider mergers and acquisitions to solidify its presence in South-east Asia. The bank is "still romancing" Myanmar and is also exploring opportunities in China and Greater China. Wee expects a "more moderate environment" in the coming year, with volatile markets and regional uncertainty. The bank's shares closed at $22.60, up 1.6% or 35 cents.

site_title: A man in a woman's world
summary: Ryan Sandilands, the new CEO of the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) in the Asia-Pacific region, aims to make the upcoming WTA Championships in Singapore a "knock-out success". The event, set to take place from October 17-26, will feature the world's top eight singles players and doubles teams, including Li Na, Serena Williams, and Martina Hingis. The tournament will be held at the Singapore Sports Hub and will have a total prize money of $6.5 million, making it the biggest professional tennis event in history for Singapore.

site_title: SingLand turns around as it heads for the exit
summary: SingLand, a Singaporean real estate company, reported a 10% increase in net profit to $54.5 million in the first quarter, ending six months of decline. The company's parent, United Industrial Corp (UIC), also posted a 10% growth in net profit. UIC is taking SingLand private with a $760 million offer, which could be the final set of results posted on the exchange. Both companies expect modest growth in the next 12 months, with SingLand's leasing demand expected to improve slowly and the retail rental market appearing stable.

site_title: Restructuring leaves its mark on layoffs
summary: Singapore's economic restructuring, now in its fifth year, is starting to leave a visible mark on the labor market, with layoffs due to restructuring processes rising for a third consecutive year in 2013. Higher operating and labor costs also affected a significant proportion of workers, although the impact may be more muted this year. Economists predict the trend will continue, with the labor market staying tight due to high demand and limited supply. Certain groups, such as manufacturing workers and professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs), are more vulnerable to layoffs.

images.alt_text: The share of layoffs that were due to the restructuring of business processes or higher costs - stemming in part from higher wages - rose for a third year in a row in 2013, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) said in its annual report on layoffs, released yesterday - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Hotel steeped in history
summary: The Hotel Majestic in Barcelona, a neo-classical building dating back to the early 20th century, has undergone a major renovation costing over 30 million euros. The hotel, known for hosting famous guests like Joan Miro and Ernest Hemingway, now features bright, contemporary rooms while retaining its original classical architecture. The hotel's signature restaurant, Drolma, has been re-invented as an all-day dining space, and its Majestic Bar offers modern Spanish tapas and a comprehensive wine list. The hotel's prime location on Passeig de Gracia, near Gaudi landmarks, makes it a top choice for history and luxury seekers.

site_title: Toast to culinary alchemy
summary: The No 1 restaurant on the Restaurant Guide's World's 50 Best list, El Celler de Can Roca, partners with The Macallan to create an extraordinary gastronomic experience. Six ultimate dinners featuring the Rocas' innovative Catalan cuisine and The Macallan's iconic single malts will be held in June and July, with net profits going to charity. The collaboration aims to test the depth of the Roca brothers' skills and break down classic perceptions of food pairing. A preview menu showcases the unique pairing, with dishes incorporating whisky flavors and aromas, such as vanilla notes in The Macallan 2007 and smokiness of The Macallan 1986.

site_title: HDB resale prices continue slide, down 1.6% in Q1
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore slid 1.6% in Q1, marking the third consecutive quarter of decline, amid market caution and a large supply of new flats. Resale transactions fell 5% to 3,781. Analysts attribute the downturn to government measures, including loan curbs and a minimum three-year waiting period for new residents. The subletting market, however, saw a record increase of 17% in Q1 transactions, as HDB owners opt to rent out their units instead of selling. Experts predict prices may fall by up to 2% in the next six months before stabilizing.

site_title: Experiential path
summary: Priscilla Tan, a 22-year-old associate designer at Supermama, is working on a new product label with Japanese fabric producer Maruju. The label, Ikue, will launch its debut collection Animal Camou, featuring baby items with camouflage-inspired prints. Tan's role was to create a unique print featuring animals that merge into each other, which was first exhibited at Frankfurt's Ambiente fair. Her design aims to inspire others and create products that carry intangible values, such as relating to people through content and stories. The collection will launch at the Japan Interior Lifestyle fair in Tokyo in June.

site_title: Lian Beng buys $46.2m Leng Kee plot
summary: Lian Beng Group, a Singapore-listed construction firm, has acquired a $46.2 million plot in the Leng Kee Road motor belt through a joint venture with VinCar, a parallel importer. This marks Lian Beng's entry into the automotive business. The joint venture, Wealth Assets Pte Ltd, is 80% owned by Lian Beng, with VinCar holding the remaining 20%.

site_title: Olam sells Uruguay farmland for US$53.7m
summary: Olam International has sold its 28,478-hectare dairy farmland in Uruguay for US$53.7 million, generating a one-time pre-tax gain of about US$18 million. The company will lease the land to a local farming company for two years, while selling 1,769 hectares to another firm and 6,002 hectares to an agribusiness firm. The transactions align with Olam's strategy to pursue profitable growth and generate positive free cash flow.

site_title: Fashioning spaces
