summary: Fashion brands are increasingly seeking exclusive venues for their events, with decommissioned sites and restored warehouses becoming popular spots. The Old Kallang Airport, recently used by Calvin Klein, is set to host Hermes' event, featuring installations and performances by artists Leandro Erlich and Miguel Chevalier. Over 500 guests will experience the brand's men's collections through site-specific works inspired by the airport. This trend highlights the pressure on luxury brands to create unique and Instagram-worthy experiences.

site_title: Did retail rents really dip in Q1?
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) released a comprehensive set of retail data, showing a 0.3% decline in rental rates in the Central Region for the first quarter. However, retailers and food & beverage operators expressed skepticism, citing steady rent increases in their renewal deals. The median rents may not accurately reflect the true impact of rising rents, and some retailers have had to close outlets due to soaring costs. Analysts expect a 3-5% decline in shop space rents this year, driven by consolidation and competition from new malls.

site_title: Young design-centric
summary: Singaporean designers are pushing the boundaries of design, focusing on functionality and purpose beyond aesthetics. George Soo, founder of Fliq, believes in "keeping design real" by considering the needs of users in his furniture designs. His updated range, Next, aims to create a smart and dynamic workspace. Auradee Sae-Lin, a 19-year-old student, won the Ikea Singapore Young Designer Award for her compact table that saves space. Clement Zheng, a 27-year-old teaching assistant, uses digital fabrication and algorithms to create innovative designs. Olivia Lee, a 29-year-old designer, has had success in various fields, including graphic design and product design. These young designers are redefining the role of design in Singapore, emphasizing functionality, sustainability, and innovation.

site_title: Private housing rental market seen being squeezed by 3 factors
summary: The private rental housing market in Singapore is expected to face pressure due to record home completions, a tighter inflow of expat tenants, and a stricter property tax regime. Private residential rents slipped 0.7% quarter-on-quarter in Q1 2014, with a vacancy rate of 6.6% for completed private homes. Experts predict a 4-7% decline in private residential rents this year, with a bigger fall next year, mainly in the suburbs. High-end properties are also expected to be affected by the stricter tax regime.

site_title: Tasty outing in Barcelona
summary: Two Barcelona eateries, Abac and Espai Kru, offer alternative dining experiences to the city's famous El Celler de Can Roca. Abac, run by chef Jordi Cruz, serves confident and fun Michelin-starred Spanish cuisine, while Espai Kru, located next door to Pakta, specializes in simple, unadulterated Mediterranean seafood. Both restaurants provide a welcoming atmosphere, with Abac offering a theatrical frozen passion fruit sorbet and Espai Kru featuring a large chiller display of fresh seafood.

site_title: Sale of Equity Plaza may be in the works
summary: GSH Corp, controlled by Sam Goi, is in talks to acquire Equity Plaza, a 28-storey office block, for $550-560 million. The building, completed 22 years ago, has a net lettable area of 252,600 sq ft. Potential buyers may seek steady rental income or occupy part of the building, or sub-divide it into smaller units. Authorities granted preliminary approval for strata sub-division in the building last November, and the building has approximately 15,000 sq ft of unutilized space.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: King Wan Corporation has been allotted 116.31 million KTIS shares in KTIS's IPO, representing 3.01% of the company, after agreeing to purchase 1.16 billion baht worth of shares. The IPO is set to begin trading on the Stock Exchange of Thailand on April 28.

site_title: Life-saving cancer 'avatars'
summary: Singapore now offers a life-saving cancer treatment called Champions Tumorgraft, a personalized approach that tests drugs against a patient's own tumor grafted onto mice. This method provides a 90% accuracy rate in selecting the best drug for patients, with a potential to shrink tumors in six to nine months. The process takes around three to four months and costs start at S$5,000. This technology is recommended for patients with advanced stage diseases or those at high risk of cancer recurrence.

site_title: US collateralised loan obligations' 16% returns exceed junk bonds'
summary: US collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) are attracting investors with returns exceeding 16% last year, surpassing junk bonds. The equity slices of CLOs, which receive leftover funds after senior investors are paid, yielded an average 16% in 2013, compared to 7.4% for junk bonds. Despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike warning, demand for CLO equity remains high, fueling issuance and providing financing for high-risk borrowers. The CLO market, worth approximately $300 billion, has supported record leveraged loan issuance and provided financing for notable deals like Dell's buyout.

site_title: Manufacturing surprise boosts Q1 GDP estimates
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP estimates are expected to be upgraded after the manufacturing sector grew 12.1% in March, exceeding economists' forecasts. This strong, broad-based growth now puts the economy's expansion at 5.5-6.1% for the quarter, higher than the 5.1% initial estimate. The sector's growth was driven by double-digit increases in transport engineering and biomedical manufacturing, with the biomedical cluster expanding 16.4% in March.

site_title: Affection for imperfection
summary: Italian chef Lorenzo Cogo, 27, has a one-Michelin-starred restaurant El Coq in Vicenza, where he intentionally disrupts perfect balance of flavors in his dishes. Cogo believes imperfections leave an impact and proves a point. His 17-course tasting menu featured a cardamom ice-cream with a bitter aftertaste, showcasing his unique approach to cooking. This unconventional style is a reflection of his personality and sets him apart from traditional chefs who strive for perfection.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB should change communications tack
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB sovereign wealth fund has released its 2013 accounts, revealing staggering debts of RM42 billion, more than its domestic peer Khazanah Nasional. The fund's net profit was RM778 million, largely driven by a RM2.7 billion revaluation gain in property assets. However, 1MDB also incurred a goodwill loss of RM1.2 billion for buying power plants from a Malaysian tycoon, and has US$2.3 billion in funds registered in the Cayman Islands. The fund's lack of transparency, including no official website or financial statements, has raised concerns among governance hawks, prompting calls for a change in its communications strategy.

site_title: Inflow of new money to EM funds slowing: banks
summary: Emerging-market funds received US$580 million in new money for the fourth consecutive week, but at a slower pace than the previous three weeks, according to data from EPFR Global. This marks a departure from the previous month-long inflow, where emerging equity funds lost over US$50 billion for 22 consecutive weeks. Analysts at Barclays attribute the slowdown to weak factory data from China and caution that growth has yet to recover.

site_title: S'pore eyes more listings by shipping, offshore companies: SGX chief
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) chief executive Magnus Bocker aims to attract more shipping and offshore companies to list on the exchange, citing a strong sector and supportive infrastructure. Since 2013, global shipping and offshore segments have raised nearly $20 billion, with the US and Norway leading the way. Despite trailing behind, Singapore is not far behind qualitatively, and the recent listing of PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) demonstrates the SGX's ability to attract larger IPOs. Industry professionals see potential for the SGX to become a preferred destination for maritime capital markets activity through partnerships and increased dialogue.

site_title: Servings of surprise and mystery
summary: A unique dinner-theatre event, "The Hideaway," is set to debut in Singapore, combining fine dining with an interactive storyline and mystery venue. Organized by And So Forth, the event will feature a four-course New Nordic-inspired meal and a pop-up dinner at a central Singapore restaurant. Diners will receive a text with clues leading to the venue, and will be seated at communal tables to encourage conversation. The event's plot was penned by a London-based Singaporean scriptwriter, and will feature local actors and young talents in their 20s. Dinners cost $125 per person.

site_title: Slow debut for POSH shares on SGX
summary: POSH shares, Singapore's largest stock offering of the year, debuted slowly on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard, closing 1 cent higher than its IPO price of $1.15. The shares were 1 cent higher than the IPO price at $1.13. The company's total offering of 252.02 million shares was approximately three times subscribed, with strong institutional support and retail investors participating. The IPO raised $388.3 million for the company, with its market capitalization growing to about $2.1 billion after the listing.

site_title: Composition of industrial space counts: consultants
summary: Singapore's industrial space supply is expected to double to 2.1 million square meters annually over the next three years, but consultants warn of a potential supply glut. The government should realign industrial space usage to include more companies involved in manufacturing, rather than simply increasing supply. Experts suggest a targeted approach, including regulating rent increases and adapting industrial definitions to accommodate emerging industries. However, the government is hesitant to redefine zoning, citing implications for land values. A 'rifle' approach is needed to address the current shortage in niche areas, such as food factories and chemical processing units.

site_title: Stamford Tyres opens $25m tyre centre
summary: Stamford Tyres has opened its $25 million warehouse and truck tyre centre in Jurong, Singapore, with a 22,591 sq m facility that can store up to 600,000 tyres. The centre, which cost $20.5 million to build, features a tyre retreading plant and optimises land use for its tyre and wheel distribution, truck centre, and retread plant operations. Stamford Tyres, Singapore's largest independent tyre and wheel distributor, plans to rent out 50% of its spare capacity, valued at $150,000 per month. The company aims to support its expanding "total tyre management" businesses in South-east Asia.

site_title: StarHub gets downgraded back to 'hold'
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded StarHub to "hold" from "buy" after the telco backpedged on plans to charge for 4G services, citing regulatory intervention. Existing customers won't be charged more, reducing the proportion of postpaid subscribers paying extra to 25% from 75%. The analyst also lowered StarHub's target price to $4.30 from $4.50. Regulatory activism may impact telcos' plans for priority data services, potentially leading to further scrutiny.

site_title: Pop-ups that spin a yarn
summary: A new pop-up dinner series, "Stories," is launching in Singapore, combining vivid storytelling with specially crafted dishes. Hosted by private dining outfit My Private Chef, the series will feature five-course meals based on historical events and iconic sites in Singapore. The first dinner, set for June 26-29, will be held at Tanjong Pagar Railway Station and will be followed by future chapters. The event aims to celebrate Singapore's heritage and food culture, with a focus on local chefs and their connection to the country. The series is supported by the Singapore Tourism Board's Kickstart Fund.

site_title: US-Japan trade pact fails to materialise at summit
summary: US President Barack Obama and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe failed to reach a bilateral trade deal during their Tokyo summit, despite efforts to accelerate the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations. The deal was expected to open the door to a swifter conclusion of the TPP talks. Chinese officials reaffirmed their claim to the disputed Senkaku Islands, stating they consider them part of their sovereign territory. The US and Japan offered assurances on the issue, but no new "red line" was drawn. The summit marked a missed opportunity for the two countries to strengthen their economic ties.

site_title: Mitsui pays China to free ship caught in 1930s row
summary: Japan's Mitsui OSK Lines paid approximately $29 million to China for the release of a ship seized over a 1930s dispute. The ship, Baosteel Emotion, was seized due to alleged failure to pay compensation for lease agreements on two Chinese ships broken in 1937. Mitsui paid 2.92 billion yen in leasing fees, including interest and damages, and 2.4 million yuan in legal fees. The case has become a cause célèbre for activists in China seeking redress from Japan.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings' $388.3 million IPO was 3 times subscribed, trading begins today. Asiasons Capital chairman Mohammed Azlan Bin Hashim sold his stake in the firm, leaving him with 3.8% direct interest. Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired a Sydney building for A$90.2 million in cash, financed by internal funds and bank borrowings. HPL appointed CIMB Bank as independent financial adviser for a $3.50 per share privatisation offer by Ong Beng Seng and Wheelock Properties.

site_title: OCBC takes long-term view of Wing Hang deal: chairman
summary: OCBC Bank's chairman, Cheong Choong Kong, stated that the bank takes a long-term view of its acquisition of Wing Hang Bank, despite short-term challenges. CEO Samuel Tsien assured shareholders that the bank will maintain the quality of its loan portfolio, citing Wing Hang's low non-performing loan ratio of 0.44%. OCBC expects to expand other business activities to offset weakness in the property loans segment. All resolutions were passed at the shareholders' meeting, including re-appointing Dr. Cheong and Mr. Tsien.

site_title: S'pore returns to Venice Biennale in '15
summary: Singapore will re-enter the Venice Biennale in 2015, with Charles Lim's artwork "Sea State" curated by Shabbir Hussain Mustafa. After pulling out of the 55th edition last year, the National Arts Council has decided to return, aiming for a long-term lease of a pavilion space. The ministry plans to allocate $20 million over five years for international exchanges, including the Biennale. Lim's previous works have received critical acclaim, including a prize at the 2011 Venice Film Festival.

site_title: Debris found on Aussie beach not from MH370: authorities
summary: Australian authorities have ruled out a link between debris found on a beach in south-western Australia and the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, MH370. The ATSB examined photographs of the material, described as sheet metal with rivets, and determined it was not a lead in the search. The search for MH370, which was carrying 239 people, remains ongoing, with an underwater search almost complete and a new phase likely to require bigger equipment. No contacts of interest have been found so far.

site_title: Ascott Trust Q1 DPU falls 22% on rights issue dilution
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 22% year-on-year drop in distribution per unit to 1.75 cents for Q1 2014 due to dilution from a one-for-five rights issue. Adjusting for the rights issue, the DPU was up 5% year-on-year. Revenue rose 16% to $80.4 million, driven by acquisitions and stronger property contributions. The trust's net asset value per unit fell to $1.36, and unitholders' distribution slipped 3% to $26.7 million. ART plans to pursue acquisitions and expects stable property performance.

site_title: Firefly Airlines plane turns back after landing gear fails to retract
summary: A Firefly Airlines plane turned back after its landing gear failed to retract, forcing the aircraft to make an emergency landing in Penang, Malaysia. The ATR 72 plane, carrying 64 passengers and four crew members, departed Penang at 6:55am but returned 15 minutes later due to the malfunction. The plane landed safely, and passengers disembarked without incident. The incident occurred just days after another Malaysia Airlines plane made an emergency landing due to a burst tyre, raising concerns about the airline's safety image.

site_title: Better passenger, cargo load expected next year
summary: A quarterly survey by the International Air Transport Association (Iata) shows a pick-up in both passenger traffic and freight volumes expected in the next year. Passenger traffic is expected to rise, with 76% of respondents anticipating an increase, while cargo volumes are also expected to grow, with 56% expecting an increase in demand. However, cargo yields are expected to ease, while passenger yields are expected to edge upwards. Profits are also expected to improve, with 60% of respondents expecting increased profitability over the next year.

site_title: Clarification
summary: UOB has clarified that its gold and silver savings accounts are backed by physical bullion, meeting regulatory requirements. Initially, the accounts were described as not backed by physical bullion, and investors would have to sell holdings at a discount. However, customers can now sell back at prevailing market bid rates found on the bank's website. This correction aims to alleviate concerns and provide transparency to investors.

site_title: SMRT shares shoot up to 4-month high of $1.215, prompt SGX query
summary: SMRT Corp shares surged 19 cents, or 18.5%, to a four-month high of $1.215, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange, with speculation of an impending fare hike or nationalization. However, broker CIMB suggests that SMRT is working with regulators to establish a sustainable financing model under the new rail-financing framework, which could lead to predictable cash flows and improved margins, potentially reversing bus losses and improving earnings.

site_title: Consumption tax hike lifts Tokyo consumer prices 2.7%
summary: Tokyo's core consumer prices rose 2.7% in April, the largest increase in 22 years, due to a consumption tax hike implemented on April 1. However, underlying inflation remained at 1%, the same level as in March. This suggests steady price rises in Japan, leaving open the question of further monetary easing by the Bank of Japan, which is due to meet next week. The increase in prices is largely driven by import prices, which are expected to stabilize in coming months, potentially forcing the BOJ to ease policy further.

site_title: Memorable tunes in screen-to-stage adaptation
summary: Jack Neo's box office smash "Ah Boys To Men" has been adapted into a musical, condensed into a 2-hour stage production. The musical features original songs by Don Richmond, which blend genres and languages, including English, Singlish, and Mandarin. The show retains the original's chemistry among actors, who have improved their performances on stage. While character development is sacrificed for a compact script, the musical offers a good mix of humor and drama, making it a "guilty pleasure." The production will run at Resorts World Theatre in Sentosa until May 4.

site_title: Crouching Tiger, hidden metaphors
summary: Hybrid artist Ho Tzu Nyen's theatre production Ten Thousand Tigers features a large assemblage box, a sculptural art piece inspired by artists like Joseph Cornell and Louise Nevelson. The box, designed by Ho, Andy Lim, and Jed Lim, contains symbolic objects and is illuminated to reveal secrets and surprises. The production includes "wax figures" played by actors who move in a controlled manner, adding to the surreal experience. Ten Thousand Tigers explores themes of storytelling, identity, and the blurring of reality and fantasy, showcasing Ho's unique blend of art and performance.

site_title: IDA launches two innovation initiatives
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) launched two initiatives to boost innovation in Singapore, including the IDA Labs initiative and the Accreditation@IDA programme. IDA Labs is a place for experimentation, collaboration, and innovation, while the Accreditation@IDA programme aims to help small but innovative technology startups build credibility to handle government projects. The programme is open to Singapore-based startups with a turnover under $10 million and will provide an assurance on the companies' products and ability to deliver. The initiatives aim to support the growth of tech-product companies in Singapore.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q1 earnings jump 19.3%
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket chain, reported a 19.3% year-on-year increase in net profit to $12.5 million in the first quarter. Revenue rose 5.7% to $189.7 million, driven by marketing initiatives and longer operating hours. Gross margin improved to 23.8% due to lower input costs and higher selling prices. Despite expansion challenges, CEO Lim Hock Chee expressed optimism for future growth, citing cost savings and plans to leverage technology to reduce labor costs.

site_title: Spanish wines are challenging the French - and winning
summary: Spanish wines are gaining recognition and challenging French wines, with several high-quality reds and whites on the market. The article highlights four exceptional Spanish wines: Riesling Schlossberg Grand Cru, Valbuena 2003, Mas La Plana 2002, and L'Ermita 2000. These wines have complex flavors, rich textures, and excellent balance, with some even rivaling French wines in quality. With prices significantly lower than comparable French wines, Spanish wines are becoming increasingly attractive to wine enthusiasts, solidifying their position as a major player in the wine industry.

site_title: Highlighting the struggles of aspiring musicians, singers
summary: Award-winning singer-songwriter Eric Moo's musical "Innamorati" is set to debut, based on his compositions. The musical's director, Allan Moo, is his younger brother, who is "messing" with Eric's music. The show highlights the struggles of aspiring musicians and singers, a theme Eric Moo experienced during his own rise to fame in the 1980s and 1990s xinyao movement in Singapore.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Local photography exhibition "Spurious Stories from the Land and Water" by Sherman Ong is now open at the Art Plural Gallery's Third Floor until May 31. The exhibition features two series of photographs, Monsoon and Spurious Landscapes, and a short film, aiming to raise awareness about human interaction with the land. Meanwhile, a play "Decimal Points 810" and a musical "Grease" are running at The Substation and the Grand Theatre, respectively, until May 18 and May 18. The annual festival "A Tapestry of Sacred Music" runs until this Sunday, featuring over 20 programmes from 10 countries.

site_title: Chinese cinema's eclectic appeal
summary: Chinese cinema showcases its eclectic appeal at the 2nd Singapore Chinese Film Festival, with films like Namewee's "Kara King" and Adam Wong's "The Way We Dance" offering a mix of comedy, dance, and music. In contrast, Yang Li Chou's documentary "The Long Goodbye" tackles the sensitive topic of dementia, highlighting the importance of discussing this issue as Asia's ageing population rises. These films demonstrate the diversity and creativity of Chinese cinema, from slapstick comedies to heart-wrenching documentaries.

site_title: Les Amis grooms its own talent
summary: Les Amis, a Singapore-based restaurant group, has successfully groomed its own talent by offering scholarships and training programs for students in the hospitality and tourism industry. Over the past 10 years, the group has provided scholarships to students at Temasek Polytechnic and the Institute of Technical Education, resulting in a steady pool of talent. The group's efforts have not only benefited its own staff but also led to a significant donation of $1.08 million to support the scholarship programs, with the aim of building a sustainable talent pipeline for the F&B industry.

site_title: HK firm's first S$ bond issue 10 times subscribed
summary: FAR East Horizon Ltd, a Hong Kong-listed Chinese financial services company, successfully launched its maiden SGD $400 million 31/2-year bond issue, priced at 4.25%. The final order book was $3.8 billion, almost 10 times subscribed. The bond was heavily subscribed by Asian investors, with 98% coming from the region, and was allocated to private banks (52%), fund managers (24%), and life insurers (17%). The bond has a BBB-stable rating from Standard & Poor's.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The Ministry of Manpower reported a third consecutive year of rising layoffs due to restructuring and higher costs. Businesses may face fewer industrial price and rent increases until 2016. The IDA launched two innovation initiatives, while the US-Japan trade pact failed to materialize. The government unveiled a $30 million program to help workers with disabilities and employers. Proton is exploring production partnerships in China, and Facebook's Q1 earnings exceeded analyst estimates.

site_title: LinkedIn to fully lease tower in San Francisco
summary: LinkedIn Corp agreed to fully lease a 26-storey office tower in San Francisco's South of Market area, occupying 450,000 square feet of space. The building, being constructed by Tishman Speyer Properties, will also have 2,200 square feet of retail space. This deal is part of LinkedIn's expansion efforts in the city.

site_title: Breaking the 'blokey' culture in boards
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is set to add two female directors, including Singaporean Euleen Goh, to its board at its annual general meeting on May 20. The move aims to improve the diversity of the board, with Shell chairman Jorma Ollila stating that the company intends for a quarter of its board to be female by 2015. This targets 3 women out of 14 directors, surpassing its rival ExxonMobil, which has a 17% female board representation. The addition of Goh, who has Asia-Pacific experience, also meets Shell's target for an Asia-Pacific director.

site_title: Exec condos helping people meet their housing aspirations: Khaw
summary: Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan reported that 86% of executive condominium buyers in the last three years are HDB dwellers, helping Singaporeans meet their private housing aspirations. Between Q4 2010 and Q4 2013, 11,000 Singaporean families bought ECs, with 55% being second-timer households and 80% earning $10,000 or less. This data suggests the EC scheme remains effective in providing affordable private housing options for eligible families.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: COE premiums for goods vehicles dropped $16,613 to $32,890, anticipating a larger quota next month. A bullion retailer introduced a savings program, encroaching on UOB space. Wages are driving inflation, pushing prices up, and expected to continue. StarHub reversed its 4G fee decision after regulators intervened. Singapore Exchange's Q3 earnings slumped 22.4%, while Capitamall Trust's distributable income rose 4.5%. The government allocated $63 million for nuclear safety research. India's gold imports may decrease due to election restrictions, and Yingluck Shinawatra has until May to defend herself against charges.

site_title: Moderating prices, rents for industrial space offer relief
summary: Businesses in Singapore may face slower increases in industrial prices and rents, with a large supply of completed industrial space expected to enter the market until 2016. According to JTC Corporation, transaction prices increased 3.8% quarter-over-quarter and 2.5% year-over-year, while industrial rentals rose 0.4% quarter-over-quarter and 4.9% year-over-year, slower than average annual growth in the past four years. This could provide relief for businesses facing sharp price and rent increases in recent months.

site_title: Unearthing pristine nature
summary: Documentary photographer Sebastiao Salgado's latest exhibition, Genesis, features 245 pristine nature images from over 30 countries. The exhibition, which premiered at the Natural History Museum in London and is now at the National Museum of Singapore, took Salgado eight years to complete and aims to raise awareness about the importance of preserving untouched natural environments. Salgado hopes his photos will inspire people to care for the planet and its natural resources, as he believes that if we don't, we will "pay the bill" for our actions.

site_title: CapitaRetail China Trust's Q1 DPU up 3.9%
summary: CapitaRetail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 3.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.4 cents for the first quarter, driven by strong organic growth from existing assets and contributions from CapitaMall Grand Canyon. Gross revenue jumped 15.5% to $231.7 million, with net property income growing 25% to $32.3 million. The trust's malls saw a 23% rental reversion and 7.3% increase in shopper traffic. CRCT expects to capitalize on expected domestic consumption in China, with occupancy at CapitaMall Grand Canyon at 99.8%.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance Q1 profit dips
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 5.4% decline in net profit to $14.43 million for the first quarter of 2014, citing a tough macro environment in Singapore due to property curbs and shrinking car market. The company attributed this to progressive regulatory action and its impact on the economic data. Despite this, it expects yields on assets to rise as interest rates transition to higher levels. The group's net loan assets increased 1.3% to $9.13 billion, while net interest income dipped 0.5%.

site_title: Orchard Towers, Marine Parade units for sale
summary: Three commercial units in Orchard Towers and Marine Parade Central are up for sale. The Orchard Towers units have a total strata area of 8,105 sq ft and are located at the junction of Orchard Road and Claymore Road. The Marine Parade Central unit spans 25,833 sq ft and has 62 years remaining on its lease. Sale prices will be determined via an expression of interest closing on May 30, 2014. CBRE expects interest from local and overseas investors seeking units with potential rental and capital appreciation.

site_title: Macro-hedging accounting rules overhaul proposed
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) proposes an overhaul of macro hedging accounting rules, aiming to better reflect dynamic risk management in financial institutions' financial statements. The new approach, a portfolio revaluation method, would revalue exposures managed dynamically and recognize fair value changes from derivatives in profit or loss. The IASB hopes to simplify the current complex rules and provide a clearer picture of an entity's profit or loss. The public has until September 5 to submit comments on the proposals.

site_title: Results snapshot
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing outgoing DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: The story of Little Voice in S'pore setting
summary: The Pangdemonium Theatre Company is adapting the 1992 play "The Rise & Fall of Little Voice" into a Singaporean setting, set in 1974. The show's director, Tracie Pang, aims to recontextualize the timeless story of a shy young girl finding her voice as a metaphor for Singapore's journey as a young nation. The adaptation will include time, place, and name references that will resonate with Singaporeans, while maintaining the essence of the original story.

site_title: Changi passenger traffic in March down 2.5%
summary: Changi Airport handled 4.49 million passengers in March, a 2.5% year-on-year decrease due to reduced long-haul capacity and Bangkok's socio-political factors. Aircraft movements rose 2.5% to 29,100, while cargo shipments fell 1.3% to 169,800 tonnes. The airport's passenger growth was impacted by the cessation of Singapore Airlines' non-stop flights to North America. In contrast, Kuala Lumpur International Airport saw a 16% increase in passengers, driven by low-cost carriers AirAsia and AirAsia X.

site_title: Results snapshot
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology and OCBC warned of lower-than-expected revenue and operating losses. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case and MAS and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Kuwaiti developer does U-turn as Dubai real estate booms
summary: Kuwait-based developer Al Mazaya Holding Co is reversing its strategy to shrink activities in Dubai's real estate market, citing a surge in prices. Property prices in Dubai rose 43% last year, enabling developers to repay debt ahead of schedule. Al Mazaya may issue Islamic bonds, or sukuk, to diversify funding sources. The company plans to launch new projects in Dubai, Bahrain, and Oman, and is studying a project in Turkey. Demand for properties is shifting from investors to locals, with the market becoming more regulated.

site_title: Thakral to refocus its distribution business
summary: Thakral Corporation, a Singapore-based conglomerate, plans to reposition its distribution business over the next three years to focus on lifestyle and environmental products, aiming to bring positive returns to shareholders. The company expects growth in Asia, particularly in China, and plans to expand its presence to 300 cities from 120. The distribution business will focus on lifestyle accessories, air purifiers, and eco-friendly home appliances. Despite recording a net loss in its fiscal year 2013, Thakral's investment division has delivered strong performance, with a 30% compounded annual growth rate.

site_title: Temasek's Olam offer turns unconditional
summary: Temasek Holdings has declared its offer for Olam International unconditional after receiving over 50% of the maximum potential share capital in acceptances. The offer period has been extended to May 23. Temasek's independent financial adviser, Rothschild, described the offer as "fair and reasonable" for shareholders and warrant holders, but not for convertible bond holders. The company's independent directors recommend shareholders and warrant holders to accept, but convertible bond holders to reject. Analysts predict meaningful savings on interest expense and potential earnings lift of 13-16% for Olam.

site_title: Gold for the masses: bullion retailer starts savings programme
summary: A Singaporean bullion retailer, the Singapore Precious Metals Exchange (SGPMX), has launched a savings program allowing investors to buy as little as 1g of gold or 10g of silver, targeting retail investors. The program, backed by physical bullion, enables customers to arrange for monthly deductions from their bank accounts to accumulate precious metals in small denominations. This move encroaches on the space previously occupied by local bank UOB, which launched a similar gold and silver savings account program in 2013.

site_title: Raising crowdfunding's appeal
summary: Singaporeans are increasingly turning to crowdfunding to support local startups, with the country ranking 10th in the world for crowdfunding activity. Platforms such as Crowdonomic, Pozible, and Haystakt are helping entrepreneurs and small businesses raise funds and gain exposure. These platforms aim to bridge the gap between Asia and the West, offering a unique opportunity for local creators to showcase their ideas and connect with potential investors. By providing mentorship, access to technology and infrastructure, and a more comprehensive road map for turning ideas into viable businesses, these platforms are poised to revolutionize the way Singaporeans approach crowdfunding.

site_title: SIAS: Minority interest addressed in CMA offer
summary: Singapore's retail investor watchdog, SIAS, is satisfied with the independence of the review of CapitaLand's privatisation offer for CapitaMalls Asia (CMA). The offer price of $2.22 per share is at a premium to book value, and minority shareholder interest has been addressed sufficiently. SIAS notes that the review is conducted by an independent board committee, excluding non-independent directors with ties to CapitaLand. The watchdog advises shareholders to wait for the independent financial advisor report before making an informed decision.

images.alt_text: Singapore's retail investor watchdog has weighed in on the heated debate surrounding CapitaLand's privatisation offer for CapitaMalls Asia (CMA) - PHOTO: CAPITALAND

site_title: Obama could strike a 'political deal' with Abe
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Tokyo, with a possible "political deal" on a bilateral trade agreement that could pave the way for a wider Trans-Pacific Partnership pact. Tokyo is seeking more overt US support on its claims to the Senkaku Islands, and Japan may offer increased market access to the US in return. The agreement could also involve Japan agreeing not to push for the elimination of vehicle tariffs in the US. The deal would benefit both leaders, with Obama needing kudos for his TPP push and Abe bolstering Japan's defenses against China.

site_title: SMEs call for fair tenancy legislation
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are calling for fair tenancy legislation to address rising industrial and commercial rents. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) polled corporate leaders and found that 73% had been affected by rental rates and lease terms negotiations. SMEs advocate for measures such as fair tenancy legislation, fair consideration lease frameworks, and effective rent reporting to promote transparency and reduce rental pressures. The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) president, Kurt Wee, believes that such legislation would bring full transparency to the market and manage unreasonable rent increases.

site_title: Hotels share space amid high land prices
summary: Hotel companies are sharing spaces to cut construction costs and increase efficiency due to high land prices. Dual-brand hotels, where two or more brands share facilities like laundry and pools, are becoming increasingly common. This trend is driven by the economics of high-priced downtown areas, where developers aim to reduce operating costs and maximize room space. However, maintaining separate identities and dealing with logistical challenges, such as free breakfasts for some guests but not others, pose difficulties for hotel companies. Executives acknowledge the tensions and debate about what elements make up the total brand experience for customers.

site_title: S&P reaffirms AIMS AMP Reit's BBB- credit rating
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has reaffirmed AIMS AMP Reit's BBB- credit rating, considering it one of the strongest Singapore-based industrial Reits. The trust has expanded its portfolio and increased geographic diversity while maintaining financial discipline. S&P categorizes the trust's business risk as satisfactory and financial risk as intermediate. The trust manager welcomed the S&P report, highlighting its proven performance in growing the portfolio through selective acquisitions and developments.

site_title: Cost of searching not a concern: Australia
summary: Australia says the cost of searching for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 is not a concern, despite the expensive mission. The search, led by Australia, has scoured over 80% of its target zone using a mini-sub, but found no wreckage. Australia is committed to finding the plane, which vanished on March 8, carrying 239 people, and will continue the search even if the mini-sub fails to spot debris. The search area is 400 sq km, and a surface search involving 10 military aircraft and 12 ships is also underway.

site_title: Pirates raid Japan oil tanker off Malaysia, kidnap 3 crew
summary: Armed pirates raided a Japanese oil tanker off Malaysia's coast, abducting three crew members. The incident occurred in the Malacca Strait, a major shipping route, and has raised concerns about piracy in the area. Six pirates boarded the tanker, pumping out diesel and taking three Indonesian crew members. Regional security officials believe the hijacking may be linked to a syndicate with inside knowledge of the ship and cargo. This incident is part of a growing trend of attacks on shipping in the Malacca Strait, with most incidents involving theft and assault.

site_title: Muppets sequel has a tough act to follow
summary: The Muppets Most Wanted, a sequel to the 2011 big-screen reboot, follows Kermit and the gang as they're lured into a transcontinental tour by a dodgy promoter. However, their identities are switched with a Russian frog, and they must navigate a series of heists across Europe while trying to escape their captors. The film maintains the Muppets' signature humor, wit, and charm, with standout performances from Ricky Gervais and Tina Fey. Despite not living up to the original's high standards, the sequel remains an entertaining romp with plenty of slapstick comedy and musical numbers.

site_title: Keep closer eye on late large cap trades
summary: The Straits Times Index closed at an eight-month high, but 47% of the market was still in negative territory, with only 12 of 30 components in the red for the year. The index's gain was largely due to Olam International and the Jardine group, but this doesn't accurately represent the local market. The article raises concerns about manipulation and rigging in the market, citing an Australian study that found frequent dramatic price spikes before market closures. Until a better means of devising market benchmarks is agreed upon, regulatory action is needed to minimize distortions and create a fair market.

site_title: Wages lead costs in pushing inflation up
summary: Singapore's inflation rebounded to 1.2% in March, driven by higher domestic costs, particularly rising wages and healthcare expenses. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport, rose to 2% from 1.6% in February, marking a fourth consecutive month it surpassed overall inflation. Economists attribute the increase to a tight labor market and expected further rises in labor costs due to upcoming foreign worker levy hikes.

site_title: S'pore developer sentiment cools: poll
summary: Sentiment among Singapore developers has cooled due to rising costs and slowing sales, according to a survey by the National University of Singapore and the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore. The Current Sentiment Index fell to 3.7 in the first quarter, while the Future Sentiment Index dipped to 3.9. Developers are concerned about higher interest rates and are re-examining pricing strategies, with 67.7% expecting market sentiment to be impacted by rising construction costs and inflation.

site_title: Airbnb challenges NY rental probe in court
summary: Airbnb has challenged a New York state demand for information on whether its home rental service violates housing and occupancy tax laws. The company, valued at $10 billion, argues that the request is a "government-sponsored fishing expedition" and claims that most of its hosts are "regular people" renting out their homes to travelers. The dispute pits Airbnb against housing advocates who argue the service is driving up rents and turning affordable accommodation into illegal hotels. The judge did not issue a decision on Tuesday, with the case highlighting tensions between existing regulations and the growing "sharing economy".

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) has secured enough acceptances to raise its shareholding in Singapore Land to 90.15%, allowing for privatization. Sunpower Group plans to sell up to 65.8 million new shares at 14 cents apiece to raise $9.2 million. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed five new lease agreements totaling 155,000 square meters in China.

site_title: Higher ratio of HDB dwellers goes for small private units
summary: In the first quarter of 2014, a higher proportion of HDB dwellers bought smaller private units of up to 800 sq ft, accounting for 51% of their purchases, compared to 29% of buyers with private addresses. This trend is attributed to affordability and managing risks, with HDB dwellers often opting for smaller units due to lower investment sums. Developers have responded by building more smaller units, which are seen as more affordable and attractive to buyers. Market watchers expect this trend to continue, with demand for small private apartments/condos expected to remain high among HDB dwellers.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Foreigners' share of home purchases increased in Q1, despite a decline in private home purchases. IDA may revive its mobile service reseller concept, while CFOs cite currency volatility as their top concern. US home sales fell to their lowest level in 1.5 years in March, while Mercedes-Benz topped the Cat A brand list. China is reforming its state-owned industry, and Chinese property shares surged on reports of a meeting to revive the sector.

site_title: CapitaMall Trust DPU for Q1 at 2.57 cents
summary: CapitaMall Trust (CMT) reported a 4.5% year-on-year increase in distributable income to $89.1 million in Q1, driven by high occupancies in its malls. Gross revenue grew 5.8% and net property income rose 5.3% due to contributions from Westgate, which commenced operations in December. The trust's portfolio of 16 shopping malls has a committed occupancy of 98.8% and is exploring greenfield development projects and asset enhancement works.

site_title: China's factory activity in April shrinks for 4th month
summary: China's factory activity shrank for the fourth consecutive month in April, according to a preliminary survey, with the HSBC/Markit PMI rising to 48.3 from 48 in March. The decline eased due to government policy tweaks, but analysts expect more support may be needed as structural reforms put pressure on the economy. The pace of contraction still indicates economic weakness in the second quarter, with the PMI below the 50 line separating expansion from contraction.

site_title: Relatives reject KL's conclusions on plane
summary: Relatives of MH370 passengers reject the Malaysian government's plan to issue death certificates without conclusive proof of the plane's crash and no survivors. They claim the government is playing a "cat-and-mouse game" and demand an independent peer review of satellite data. The families, who have accused the government and airline of botching the response to the plane's disappearance, also expressed outrage and shock over the proposed financial assistance. The Malaysian government denies withholding information and says satellite data indicates the plane crashed in the Indian Ocean.

site_title: Australand 'no' to Stockland's stake proposal
summary: Australand Property Group rejected a $1.95 billion proposal from Stockland Group to increase its stake, calling the deal undervalued and not compelling. The offer, which valued Australand at $2.43 billion, was seen as a discount to the company's closing price. The board decided to deny Stockland access to due diligence and recommended shareholders take no action. Australand shares rose 0.2%, while Stockland fell 0.8%.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust Q4 DPU up 12.4%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 12.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for its Q4 2014, reaching 1.953 cents, driven by positive contributions from VivoCity, PSA Building, and Mapletree Anson. Gross revenue rose 12.9% to $68.6 million, with net property income increasing 15.2% to $50.8 million. The Reit's full-year DPU grew 13.6% to 7.372 cents, exceeding its forecast. VivoCity's revenue and net property income grew 8.9% and 11.1% respectively, with shopper traffic recording a new high of 54 million.

site_title: Singapore still second-most networked economy
summary: Singapore remains the world's second-most networked economy, according to the Networked Readiness Index (NRI), trailing Finland. The country's strong digital ecosystem, pro-business environment, and high-quality education system contribute to its ranking. To improve its position, Singapore needs to increase Internet users and households with a personal computer and Internet access, as well as reduce the cost of accessing fixed broadband Internet. The report highlights the growing digital divide between emerging and developed nations, with less-developed economies potentially missing out on ICT benefits.

site_title: Oon's one-woman show
summary: Local theatre actress Oon Shu An has created a one-woman show, #UnicornMoment, based on interviews with people from her life, including ex-teachers, colleagues, and friends. The show explores universal issues such as happiness, self-esteem, and the effects of the education system. Oon's research revealed that many people hide painful emotions, and she aims to create empathy through the play. Directed by Huzir Sulaiman and Shiv Tandan, #UnicornMoment will run at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from May 8 to 10.

site_title: Divers feel with their hands for corpses in sunken Korean ferry
summary: South Korean divers searched the sunken Sewol ferry for missing children, feeling for bodies with their hands in dark, cold waters. The ferry sank a week ago, killing 146 confirmed dead, with 339 on board. Only 174 have been rescued, and hundreds are presumed drowned. Prosecutors raided the home of the ferry's owner, Yoo Byung-un, and his son's home, investigating the disaster. Divers work for nearly an hour at a time, and have retrieved 14 bodies so far. Ferry captain Lee Joon-seok and crew members have been arrested on negligence charges.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust's Q2 DPU rises 3% to 2.05¢
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.05 cents for its Q2 2014, driven by the conversion of 0.8 million Series A Convertible Perpetual Preferred Units. Distribution to unitholders rose 5.6% to $13.789 million, despite a 10.3% decrease in income available for distribution. Gross revenue fell 3.7% to $28.6 million, mainly due to the weaker Australian dollar and lower occupancy at Central Park office tower in Perth.

site_title: Govt investors fret about rates, emerging market volatility
summary: Government-linked investors are concerned about higher interest rates and emerging market volatility, according to a State Street study. The top concerns include managing complexity, volatility, and currency risk in emerging markets and alternative investments. Operational risk and data management are also significant priorities. The study, which surveyed 62 senior executives, reflects the growing complexity of portfolios as investors seek to balance returns with risk management. Central banks and sovereign wealth funds are particularly vigilant, with a heightened sensitivity to potential market downturns.

site_title: S'pore office rents seen rising up to 15% this year
summary: Singapore's office rents are expected to rise up to 15% this year due to increased demand and a lack of new developments. Global companies, including Cargill and Bordier & Cie, are driving the recovery by setting up offices in the central business district. Office rents have already increased by 5% in the first quarter compared to last year, with occupancy rates reaching 95.1% in the March quarter. The trust manager, CapitaCommercial, expects rents to accelerate in the second half of the year as new supply is not expected until 2016.

site_title: Economics should be the thrust of Obama's Asia tour
summary: US President Barack Obama's Asia tour, starting this week, aims to reassure the region of the US's top priority in its foreign policy. To achieve this, economics could be the key, rather than security, given the US's recent failures in intervening in Syria and Ukraine. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a comprehensive trade and economic pact covering 40% of world trade, could provide a platform for this. However, negotiations have stalled due to differences on tariffs, particularly between the US and Japan, with a key meeting between Obama and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe scheduled to determine the outcome of the trip.

site_title: StarHub back-pedals on 4G fee as IDA steps in
summary: StarHub has reversed its plan to charge $2.14 per month for 4G access, following intervention from the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) of Singapore. The IDA had clarified with the three telcos that existing customers with minimum-term contracts would not be charged. M1 and SingTel are also reviewing their pricing plans, but will not charge 4G fees to existing customers. The IDA expressed concerns over consumer confusion and the need for clearer communication of key terms and conditions before service sign-up.

site_title: SGX's Q3 earnings slump 22.4% to $75.8m
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 22.4% decline in Q3 net profit to $75.8 million, with operating revenue down 13.1% to $165.6 million. CEO Magnus Bocker attributed the slowdown to thinner retail investor activity, despite a growth in retail participants. Bocker emphasized the need for sweeping changes to improve liquidity and market quality, including reduced fees for market makers and liquidity providers. SGX plans to introduce new China products, including yuan futures, and remains optimistic about the recovery of its securities market.

site_title: S'pore CFOs polled say currency volatility key concern this year
summary: Singapore's Chief Financial Officers (CFOs) have cited currency volatility as their primary concern for this year, with 55% of those polled citing forex volatility. This is attributed to the wider-than-usual swings in the Singapore dollar against the US dollar in recent years. CFOs are also less likely to engage in merger and acquisition activities, with only 45% planning to do so, with the focus being on deals within Asia.

site_title: Human biases that lead to investment missteps
summary: Investors often make missteps due to human biases, which can lead to irrational decision-making. These biases include overconfidence, overtrading, loss aversion, and the tendency to rely on past performance rather than objective analysis. Additionally, investors may fall prey to heuristics such as anchoring and recency, causing them to freeze or procrastinate on investment decisions. Behavioral finance suggests that investors need guidance to overcome these biases and make informed decisions, highlighting the importance of seeking the advice of a financial adviser.

site_title: COE premiums fall ahead of new quota
summary: COE premiums in Singapore have fallen ahead of the new quota, with Category C premiums decreasing by 33.6% to $32,890 and Cat A premiums falling by 8.5% to $71,335. The Cat D premium for motorcycles rose to a record $4,502, while Cat B and Cat E premiums also decreased. The new COE quota, which will be released in May-July, is expected to have 32.1% more COEs than the previous quota, leading to a decrease in prices and a decrease in bids from distributors.

site_title: The Chosen One turns out to be The Wrong One
summary: Manchester United manager David Moyes has been sacked after a disastrous first season in charge, with the team languishing in seventh place in the league. Moyes, who was dubbed "The Chosen One" after taking over, was unable to live up to expectations and was exposed as out of his depth. The Glazer family, who own the club, had no intention of following Alex Ferguson's orders to give Moyes time to adapt, and the decision to sack him comes as a surprise to few. Moyes will move on, but his tenure at Manchester United has been a failure.

site_title: Thuraya sets its sights on maritime sector
summary: Thuraya Telecommunications Company, a Dubai-based mobile satellite services operator, aims to capture 10% of the maritime market share within two years. The company has seen a 15% increase in FY2013 revenue to $122 million and expects it to exceed $200 million by 2018, driven by its maritime business. Thuraya offers more affordable and portable solutions compared to its competitor Inmarsat, with cost savings of up to 40% for shipowners. The company is targeting private yachts and partnering with fixed satellite services fleet operators to expand its reach.

site_title: Privatisation unhappiness: market is to blame
summary: A flurry of privatization offers in Singapore's market have sparked unhappiness among minority shareholders, citing "low" offer prices that misprice good quality companies. Despite the offers being the highest in about 15 months, minority shareholders feel undervalued. Offerors aim to balance between the market and other valuation benchmarks to secure a margin, often at the expense of minority shareholders. The article argues that the market's efficiency is questionable, and minority shareholders should weigh their options, considering whether to wait for a market correction or take the current offer.

site_title: Japan's HIS considers buying island for casino project
summary: Japan's HIS Co, a travel agency and theme park operator, is considering buying a deserted island to expand its Huis Ten Bosch theme park and potentially host a casino resort. The project, estimated to cost 100 billion yen ($1.23 billion), aims to boost the park's appeal and generate US$40 billion in annual revenue, rivaling China's Macau. HIS plans to lease land to casino developers and partner with video game makers to create an interactive "Game Kingdom" at the park. Preliminary legislation to legalize casinos in Japan is expected to pass in coming months.

site_title: Politics clouds Japan's investments in China
summary: Japanese investments in China declined 18% in 2013, while those in Asean almost doubled, according to the Japan External Trade Organisation. China's economic growth is slowing, and high wage costs are a concern, while weak intellectual property rights are a risk. Political tensions between Japan and China, including disputes over the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands and anti-Japanese demonstrations, are also driving the decline. In contrast, Asean's unified single market and lower wage costs are attracting Japanese companies, with Indonesia taking the top spot as a medium-term investment destination.

site_title: Shandong Air orders 50 Boeings for US$4.6b
summary: Shandong Airlines, a Chinese carrier, has ordered 50 Boeing planes for $4.6 billion, including 16 737-800s and 34 737 MAX planes. The deal represents a vote of confidence in Boeing's newest planes, which promise greater fuel efficiency. The order is part of Shandong Airlines' plan to double its fleet to over 140 aircraft by 2020, and comes as the Chinese airline industry experiences growth. The deal is a win for Boeing in the giant Chinese market and reflects the country's rapidly expanding domestic airline sector.

site_title: XMH eyes acquisitions, seeks growth in Vietnam
summary: XMH Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, aims to expand through acquisitions and grow its presence in Vietnam. The company's CEO and chairman, Elvin Tan, stated that acquisitions will add to the group's top and bottom lines, targeting related businesses or industries. XMH has already made a successful acquisition in Singapore, and the company plans to open a new facility in Vietnam in 2015, which will boost its capacity and enable the development of a logistics services business line.

site_title: Tragedy in South Korea
summary: A South Korean ferry, Sewol, sank in April 2014, resulting in the loss of nearly 300 lives, mostly school children. An investigation is underway to determine the cause of the tragedy. The incident has raised concerns about ferry safety, despite South Korea's good safety record and adherence to International Maritime Organization regulations. The global ferry industry association, Interferry, has expressed condolences and offered assistance to the investigation, emphasizing the need for continuous enhancement of operational requirements for crews and land-based organizations.

site_title: Results snapshot
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit raised SGD 1.05 billion in its public offer, 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks fell amid fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC will deepen green finance cooperation. Singapore stocks rose for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Gas producers exploring coal gasification
summary: Industrial gas producers Soxal and Linde Gas, along with Keppel Corp's genco unit, are exploring a coal gasification project in Singapore. The project aims to produce synthetic gas for petrochemical plants and refineries on Jurong Island, offering an alternative to traditional feedstocks. Discussions with authorities are ongoing, but approval has not been granted yet. The project's focus is on producing synthetic gases like carbon monoxide and hydrogen, rather than utilities like electricity and steam.

site_title: UK investment house plans 3 Asia-themed funds
summary: London-based investment house Threadneedle Investments plans to launch three Asia-themed funds, citing the region's growing efficiency and eventual stability. Head of Asian equities Ng Soo Nam believes listed firms in Asia are consolidating operations and becoming more cost-efficient, driving improved profitability. Funds will be based on three themes: equity income, sustainable growth, and contrarian strategy, with an emphasis on companies like CapitaLand and BHP Billiton that are adapting to slower growth. Asia's growth potential remains strong, with sectors like e-commerce and insurance showing resilience.

site_title: China to drive demand for corporate jets
summary: China is expected to drive demand for corporate jets, accounting for a third of Airbus's orders, driven by the country's high GDP growth and increasing number of billionaires. Currently, 20 of the 170 Airbus corporate jets sold are based in China. Airbus aims to sell 15 business jets a year, with the new ACJ319 Elegance model, priced under $80 million, being launched to cater to the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: ACJ319 Elegance: Unlike the current fully customisable version, Elegance will offer a range of lounge, office, dining and conference modules for customers to choose from

site_title: US airlines at bottom of satisfaction index
summary: US airlines scored 69 on a 100-point scale, ranking below hotels and online travel agencies in customer satisfaction. The annual American Customer Satisfaction Index found that airlines received high marks for check-in procedures but low marks for in-flight service, including beverage quality, bathroom cleanliness, and seat comfort. Airlines with the highest satisfaction scores were JetBlue Airways, Southwest Airlines, and Delta Air Lines, while Spirit Airlines, American Airlines Group, and United Continental ranked worst.

site_title: IDA mulls over more mobile competition and spectrum allocation
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) is considering reviving the niche mobile service reseller concept, dubbed "mobile virtual network operators" (MVNOs), to boost competition in the mobile market. IDA plans to support smaller players if there is demand, potentially leading to lower prices and more innovative services. The regulator is also exploring the allocation of up to 450 Megahertz of spectrum for mobile broadband, which could lead to deeper competition in both fixed line and mobile broadband markets.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: SEMBCORP Industries revived its property unit Sembcorp Properties to develop residential and commercial projects, starting with China. Japan's trade deficit reached its worst-ever level in March, growing 69% for the year to March 31. The US leading index increased in March, indicating a strengthening economic expansion. Global food prices pose a low inflation risk, according to HSBC. Meanwhile, Transcu Group signed a deal on a reverse takeover, and Public Bank posted a 5% rise in Q1 net profit to RM1.02 billion.

site_title: Wall Street whipped by resilient treasuries
summary: Wall Street firms have suffered significant losses after betting against US government debt for the first time since 2011. Primary dealers, including JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, amassed $5.2 billion in net short positions on government debt in March, but yields have since fallen as Fed Chair Janet Yellen signaled a delay in lifting interest rates. The surprise resilience of treasuries has made the business of trading bonds less profitable, with yields on 10-year notes declining to 2.72%. Economists predict 10-year yields will increase to 3.36% by year-end, but some forecasters, such as Joseph LaVorgna, predict yields could reach 4%.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q4 DPU up at 2.51 cents
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust posted a 5.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.51 cents for Q4 2014, driven by higher occupancies and rental rates. Distributable income rose 9.5% to $42.6 million, while net property income increased 7.5% to $53.3 million. The trust's DPU rose 7.4% to 9.92 cents for the full year. Units ended one cent lower at $1.425, despite JTC's expected release of more industrial land supply, which may moderate rents.

site_title: China Sky owners approve accounts
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co's shareholders approved accounts and audited reports for the past three financial years at its annual general meeting. The company, suspended from trading since 2011, announced a trading resumption plan to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) last year. Shareholders passed resolutions to receive and adopt the directors' reports, paving the way for potential trading resumption. The company posted consecutive net losses in 2012 and 2013, but narrowed losses in 2013. SGX should expedite trading after shareholder approval, according to investors.

site_title: Why a core/satellite approach pays
summary: Investors can minimize regret by adopting a core/satellite approach to portfolio management, which protects against common human foibles such as fear, greed, and overconfidence. A core portfolio typically consists of a diversified mix of fixed income and equities, while a satellite portion may include actively managed funds or alternative investments. Key misconceptions include home bias, where investors favor local markets, and misunderstanding bond returns, which are finite and different from equity returns. Overtrading, chasing performance, and concentration risk are also common pitfalls, while the power of compounding can lead to substantial gains over the long term.

site_title: Bid to unseat Pteris directors falls through
summary: Pteris Global director Winston Tan withdrew from an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove five directors, citing inability to obtain enough proxies to vote on behalf of shareholders. Tan resigned from the board, stating his intention to raise matters that would be difficult to discuss while remaining on the board. The EGM, aimed at removing directors opposed to Pteris's proposed reverse takeover deal, was deemed a non-event. Tan will continue to seek better terms for the deal as a shareholder.

site_title: CCM unit's condo contract terminated
summary: CCM Group's subsidiary, CCM Industrial, has had its contract to construct a 23-storey residential flat in Balestier terminated due to alleged breaches of contract. The $32.3 million contract was awarded in August 2011 and was set to be completed by the loss-making subsidiary. The termination notice was issued by CCM Group, which is now seeking legal advice and evaluating the financial impact of this development.

site_title: First sign of ferry disaster was call from frightened boy
summary: A South Korean ferry, Sewol, sank on a routine trip, resulting in 174 confirmed dead and 339 presumed drowned. The first distress call was made by a 15-year-old boy, who reported the ship was sinking, but his voice was not recognized as the captain's until he mentioned "teacher." The crew's actions were criticized, with some leaving the ship as it sank and others unable to deploy lifeboats. Captain Lee Joon-seok and other crew members have been arrested on negligence charges, with President Park Geun-hye calling the instruction to stay in cabins "an act of murder."

site_title: AsiaPhos mines gains, expands exploration area
summary: AsiaPhos, a phosphate miner, has entered into agreements to take over the economic benefits of its existing mines and expand its exploration area in Sichuan, China. The firm has cooperation agreements with Mianzhu Dashan Mining Co Ltd and LY Resources, which will allow AsiaPhos to benefit from cost savings and higher profit margins. AsiaPhos will subscribe for $10-$15 million of convertible loan notes, which can be converted into ordinary shares, and will gain equity control of LY Resources if the options are exercised. The agreements are expected to improve AsiaPhos' financial performance and position the company for better capital-raising terms.

site_title: Foreigners' share of home purchases creeping up
summary: Private home purchases in Singapore fell to 2,076 units in Q1 2014, the lowest since Q1 2009. Foreigners' share of transactions increased, while Singaporeans' share dropped to 70%, the lowest since ABSD introduction in Q4 2011. Permanent residents and foreigners also saw the lowest absolute numbers since the 2009 market trough.

site_title: Manhattan Resources woos spurned JES partner
summary: Manhattan Resources has entered into a three-month call option agreement with Starsmind Capital to acquire up to 60% of its enlarged share capital. The deal would value Mineriver at $169m, significantly lower than the $225m Mineriver was spurned by JES International for. Mineriver's CEO, Ho Sing Ming, hopes the new deal will alleviate concerns about the mine's quality. Manhattan sees the investment as an opportunity to expand its earnings base and venture into the resources market.

site_title: No bleeding heart for open-source code
summary: The Heartbleed bug, a vulnerability in the secure sockets layer (SSL) code, has highlighted the risks of relying on open-source programs. The bug, which compromised sensitive information, took two years to detect due to the lack of accountability in open-source maintenance. As companies react to the bug, they must weigh the benefits of open-source collaboration against the potential costs of proprietary systems, including lost innovation and increased costs. The incident also underscores the need for governments and corporations to consider the worst-case outcomes of security breaches, which can be financially devastating and expose sensitive information.

site_title: StanChart goes the whole distance for Singapore marathon
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has extended its sponsorship of the Singapore Marathon for three years until 2016, increasing the deal value to $10.5 million. The bank has sponsored the event for 12 years, starting in 2002, and has seen significant growth, with over 54,000 participants at the most recent race. The extension is seen as a significant boost to the event, with Sport Singapore praising StanChart's support for promoting a healthy lifestyle through sports. The marathon remains one of 10 events sponsored by the bank worldwide.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Food Empire Holdings expects a net loss for Q1 due to unrest in Russia and Ukraine affecting currencies and debt. Chemoil Energy shares will be suspended after a successful privatisation bid by Glencore Xstrata. Cosco Corp won US$100m contracts for shipbuilding. Rowsley received approval to develop a 500-apartment condo project in Malaysia.

site_title: SMEs less bullish about business outlook: study
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are less bullish about their business outlook, with a score of 54.4, down 1.1% from the previous quarter. However, those in industries linked to the international economy are more optimistic. The manufacturing and transport/storage sectors showed gains in turnover and profitability expectations, with scores of 5.62 and 5.43, respectively. Experts attribute the dip in SMEs' outlook to ongoing economic restructuring and the manpower crunch, but also highlight potential opportunities for growth through innovation, financing, and internationalization.

site_title: Uncertain markets outpace stock-pickers' talents or luck
summary: Randy Kurtz, a 30-year-old stock picker, had a remarkable track record for nine years, beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in six of the next eight years. However, he recently shifted his strategy to index and exchange-traded funds, citing the limitations of his previous approach, which included a reliance on individual stock picks and high fees. Kurtz's decision follows that of other investment advisers, including Dimensional Fund Advisors' head Dave Butler, who also abandoned stock picking in favor of a more diversified approach. Kurtz's new strategy aims to provide fair returns with lower fees, ranging from 0.50% to 0.95% annually.

site_title: India waiting for a decisive vote
summary: India's upcoming parliamentary election is expected to shape the country's economy, which has struggled with stagflationary conditions. A decisive vote could signal a sea change, potentially leading to sustainable 7-8% GDP growth. The election outcome is seen as crucial, with four scenarios predicting varying growth outcomes: 6.5-7.25% with an absolute majority, 5.0-5.5% with a fragmented coalition, and 5.0% with a broad fragmented coalition. Markets appear optimistic, with the Sensex pushing into record territory, and investors positioning themselves for a cyclical recovery, with a focus on cyclical businesses and growth-at-a-reasonable-price stocks.

images.alt_text: India's equity and currency markets appear optimistic about the country's election outcome and, therefore, about policy action and growth implications in the coming 12 months. In the run-up to the nationwide parliamentary elections, the Sensex has pushed into record territory - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Ferry crew's actions 'like murder': Park
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye has called for a thorough investigation into the sinking of the Sewol ferry, which killed over 300 people. The crew's actions, described as "like murder," are under scrutiny, with four crew members arrested for abandoning passengers and violating maritime law. The investigation is focusing on why the vessel turned sharply before sinking, and modifications made to expand passenger capacity are also being examined. The president has vowed to uncover the truth behind the tragedy, which has sparked widespread shock and rage.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Qantas' relocation of its European flights hub from Changi Airport to the Middle East resulted in a 6.7% increase in flights handled by SATS for Q4 FY13/14. Despite this, passenger numbers remained nearly flat at 10.53 million, while gross and unit meals produced declined 8.2% and 6.3% respectively.

site_title: Is internal audit losing value?
summary: Internal audit is losing its value, with 55% of senior managers worldwide saying it doesn't add much value to their companies. The business environment has become increasingly complex and risky, but internal audit lacks resources to meet rising expectations. However, internal audit functions that rise to meet expectations are seen as adding great value, with 67% of stakeholders rating its performance higher when it's seen as a trusted adviser. To regain value, internal audit must focus on business objectives, understand the company's vision, and demonstrate credibility to management.

site_title: Japan's March trade gap swells to biggest-ever 1.45 trillion yen
summary: Japan's trade deficit surged to a record 13.75 trillion yen in fiscal 2012/13, a 69% increase from the previous year, due to rising import costs and a 21st consecutive monthly shortfall. The March trade deficit alone reached 1.45 trillion yen, with exports failing to keep up with the increase in import costs. Economists attribute the issue to the economic slowdown in China, Japan's largest export destination, and the need for the government to address downside risks and boost exports.

site_title: Courts' O'Connor supporting charity drive
summary: Courts' regional CEO Terry O'Connor is leading a charity drive, "The BT-Coca Cola World Cup Charity Drive," to raise funds for the BT Budding Artists Fund and Singapore Sports Council's SportCares. The initiative, co-organised with Coca-Cola, encourages CEOs to adopt a World Cup finalist and compete in a betting system, with the losing CEO donating $2,000 to charity per match. The charity drive aims to raise $130,000 and features participating CEOs in BT's daily World Cup page, with donations from corporate funds being tax-deductible.

site_title: SQ322's tyre deflation no compromise to safety: SIA
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) clarified that the safety of passengers was not compromised after SQ322, a London-bound flight, returned to Changi Airport due to a faulty air-conditioning system. The plane landed with a full load of fuel, causing several tyres to deflate. However, the tyres are designed to deflate at certain brake temperatures, and the pilot landed the plane safely. The aircraft was delayed and eventually operated using a replacement plane, departing for London at 11am. There was no damage to the aircraft, and it has since returned to service.

site_title: US drone to continue search for MH370 after its current mission
summary: A US submarine drone, Bluefin-21, will continue its search for the missing Malaysian jetliner MH370 in the Indian Ocean after completing over 80% of its targeted search area. The drone has been scouring the ocean floor since April 14, but a tropical cyclone has suspended the air search. No wreckage has been found, and the search is expected to continue with further missions planned. The search is being led by the Joint Agency Coordination Centre and involves international partners, with daily flights continuing despite the cyclone.

site_title: Rising global food prices a low inflation risk, says HSBC
