summary: HSBC says rising global food prices are unlikely to pose a significant risk to inflation, citing steady prices for staples and a lack of strong global growth. The food price index, the highest since May last year, was driven by unfavorable weather conditions and geopolitical tensions. Despite record highs in milk and pork prices, HSBC economists believe that food prices would need to climb sharply to drive up consumer price indices. The bank expects prices for certain agricultural commodities to reach a higher plateau, reflecting structural changes in global supply and demand.

site_title: Singapore the 4th most connected country: McKinsey study
summary: Singapore ranks 4th globally in terms of connectedness, according to a McKinsey study, behind Germany, Hong Kong, and the US. The country's high ranking is driven by its trade intensity and role as a major waypoint for goods and financial flows. Singapore's connectedness in people and data flows is also above average, with its cross-border Internet traffic growing at 1.5 times the global average over the past five years. The study highlights the importance of connectivity in driving economic growth, with cross-border flows accounting for 15-25% of global GDP growth.

site_title: Rolls-Royce holds first public exhibition
summary: Rolls-Royce held its first public exhibition in Singapore, showcasing its brand, design, and bespoke services. The ultra-luxury brand revealed that Singapore is its third-largest market globally for customized cars, with 90-95% of its sales being bespoke. The Icon Tour features artisans from the Goodwood factory demonstrating their craftsmanship, including the creation of a diamond-studded Extended Wheelbase Phantom. The exhibition also unveiled the Ghost V-Specification, a limited series of saloons with 593 hp and exclusive features. The Icon Tour will move to Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul after the Singapore event.

site_title: Pteris owners urged not to jeopardise RTO deal
summary: Pteris Global's board of directors urged shareholders not to vote to remove directors or jeopardize the proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal with China International Marine Containers Group (CIMC) until all details are available. The RTO offers Pteris synergy with CIMC's parent company, parented by Tianda Airport Support, and could provide substantial financial resources and leverage in the logistics industry. Shareholders will decide the fate of the RTO and the five directors at the extraordinary general meeting on Friday.

site_title: Grand Banks makes sale of luxury yacht
summary: Grand Banks Yacht has sold a 54-foot luxury yacht to David Loh, owner of KME Transport, for an undisclosed price, reportedly similar to a yacht priced at US$1.73 million. The sale occurred during the Singapore Yacht Show, marking the company's first sale since 2011. This deal follows Grand Banks' acquisition of an Australian yacht maker and its first quarterly profit since 2009, indicating a possible turnaround for the luxury yacht maker. The yacht will be constructed in Johor and delivered later this year.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust posts Q2 DPU of 2.88 cts
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.88 cents, a 6.7% increase from last year. Income available for distribution rose 1.4% to $23.8 million, while net property income rose 2% to $29.3 million. The trust's gearing level was 27.7% and its weighted average debt maturity was 2.5 years. FCT's year-to-date DPU is 5.38 cents, with a 3.9% increase in gross revenue to $80.9 million.

site_title: MGCCT beats own income prediction for Q4
summary: MAPLETREE Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported distributable income per unit of 1.587 cents in Q4, beating its forecast by 15.9%. The trust plans to distribute 3.099 cents per unit, resulting in a full-year payout of 6.265 cents. MGCCT's full-year distribution yield is 6.7%. The company's retail mall, Festival Walk, has seen 100% occupancy and 5.8% increase in shopper traffic. MGCCT expects steady growth in Hong Kong's economy and a balanced pace of growth in China in 2014.

site_title: Qatar to build fewer World Cup stadiums
summary: Qatar has reduced its World Cup stadium plans from 12 to eight, amid rising costs and delays. The country, which won the right to host the 2022 soccer World Cup in 2010, aims to build eight stadiums, including 92 training sites, with a budget of $4 billion. The decision was made to cut costs following a review of the real needs on the ground, and comes as the country faces delays and escalating costs related to the event, including a six-year delay in opening a new airport.

site_title: New launches send Q1 condo sales in Toronto up 68%
summary: Toronto condominium sales surged 68% in Q1, driven by new launches, reaching 4,962 units sold. This is the best March on record, more than doubling from last year. New condo projects are expected to increase supply, with 4,614 high-rise units launched in the first quarter, and prices may rise as developers pass on costs. The average unit size is expected to shrink, putting pressure on project design.

site_title: Scibois deal no panacea for JES's troubles
summary: Chinese shipbuilder JES International has acquired a controlling stake in Scibois Co Limited, which owns a licence to harvest 229,400 hectares of forest area in the Democratic Republic of Congo for up to $65 million. The move comes as JES seeks to diversify its business and pull itself out of financial troubles. However, the investment also raises concerns over security and environmental impact in the region, where sporadic violence and rampant illegal logging are prevalent. JES's decision to terminate its earlier mining investment in Mineriver also raises questions about the company's ability to turn profitable.

site_title: Transcu signs RTO deal with Straits Construction
summary: Transcu Group, a struggling biotech firm, has signed a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement with Straits Construction to undergo a reverse takeover (RTO). The deal, valued between $325m and $338m, will see Straits Construction inject its paid-up capital into Transcu, increasing its share capital by 79.9%. The acquisition is expected to give Transcu a new lease of life, with Straits Construction having an established business in Singapore and China. The deal must meet Straits Construction's consolidated net profit after tax of at least $42 million for 2013.

site_title: Shanghai court seizes Mitsui OSK vessel
summary: A Shanghai court has ordered the seizure of a Japanese iron ore carrier, the 226,434-tonne Baosteel Emotion, from Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd as compensation for the loss of two ships leased from a Chinese company before the 1972 Japan-China joint communique. The seizure reflects strained China-Japan ties amid a territorial dispute over an island chain. Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary described the seizure as "regrettable" and is working with Mitsui OSK on a response. The case dates back to 1988 and a 2007 court ruling ordered Mitsui to pay 2.9 billion yen in compensation.

site_title: Index of leading indicators up 0.8% in March
summary: The US index of leading indicators rose 0.8% in March, the largest increase in four months, indicating economic expansion will strengthen after harsh winter weather. The labour market, consumer sentiment, and demand are boosting consumption, with wage gains needed to sustain spending growth. The labour market added 192,000 workers to payrolls, while initial jobless claims fell to near 7-year lows. However, the housing market recovery faces challenges from higher interest rates and tight credit.

site_title: Search for MH370 into 44th day
summary: The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 entered its 44th day, with Australian officials stating that crucial sonar scans of the Indian Ocean floor may be completed within a week. The Bluefin-21 autonomous underwater vehicle has spent a week scouring the remote ocean floor for signs of the plane, which disappeared on March 8 with 239 people on board. The search is at a "very critical juncture," with hopes for further black box signals dwindling due to the batteries' expected life span expiring two weeks ago.

site_title: MLT Q4 DPU up 9.2% at 1.89 cents
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust reported a 9.2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.89 cents for its fourth quarter, driven by a 10.1% increase in distributable amount. Net property income rose 4.3% to $68.3 million, and gross revenue increased 5.7% to $80.1 million, primarily due to contributions from new developments and positive rental reversions. The trust's full-year DPU was 7.35 cents, up 8% from the previous year.

site_title: CMA shareholders should stand their ground against 'fair offer'
summary: CapitaLand's offer for 35% of CapitaMalls Asia (CMA) shares is deemed undervalued, with the company being a cash cow worth more than the proposed price. Despite CMA's strong post-IPO performance, including a 44% increase in completed projects, a 55% rise in profit, and a 30% increase in total equity, the offer is only a 4.7% premium to the IPO price. CMA shareholders should stand their ground to maximize value, as the offer is seen as an asset trade rather than a strategic investment, and the majority of the board has ties to CapitaLand.

site_title: No sign of MH370 despite underwater search
summary: Australian officials reported that two-thirds of the planned underwater search for missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 has been completed, with no signs of the jet. Ten military aircraft and 11 ships are participating in the search, focusing on an underwater autonomous vehicle (UAV) Bluefin-21 that has made eight missions to the Indian Ocean seabed without finding any debris. Acoustic signals picked up from the seabed are the best lead in solving the mystery, and authorities are scouring the seabed in the vicinity of the transmissions.

site_title: China plans bad debt fund for foreigners
summary: China Orient Summit Capital, a unit of China's largest bad-debt bank, plans to launch a $1 billion fund for foreigners to invest in soured property loans and distressed real estate assets. The move aims to attract foreign investors to China's market, which has slowed down due to an 18-month low economic growth and a weakening housing market. The fund will help investors navigate the attractive but sometimes treacherous market for distressed assets, with CEO Lijian Chen stating that the company "sees the cycle coming" and is prepared to capitalize on it.

site_title: Analysts point to new phase of bull market
summary: Analysts say the US stock market has entered a new phase of the bull market, characterized by a shift from growth stocks to more defensive stocks. The S&P 500 has made its biggest gain of the year, but momentum stocks such as biotech and tech companies have taken a hit. The market is expected to remain volatile, with traders rotating into companies with steadier growth and investors hoping for strong economic data. Despite concerns over geopolitical shocks, the market has found a "floor" at current levels, driven by low interest rates and ongoing economic growth.

site_title: Obama's legacy in Asia rests on TPP
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to Asia aims to revive support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a key economic deal. The talks have stalled, with disagreements over agriculture and auto sectors between the US and Japan. Despite challenges, analysts see optimism in the air for a breakthrough, crucial for Obama's foreign-policy pivot to Asia and Japan's economic growth. The TPP, involving 12 Pacific Rim countries, is envisioned to be the largest free trade agreement, benefiting 40% of global GDP and 500 million middle-class consumers in Asia.

site_title: 2 Pteris Global directors support RTO plan
summary: Two Pteris Global directors, Low Kok Hua and Soon Kong Ann, have expressed support for a proposed reverse takeover (RTO) plan, while warning that removing five existing board directors could force a $90-million loan to come due, putting the company's operations at risk. The RTO, proposed by Tianda Group, aims to undervalue the airport logistics services company. A separate EGM is scheduled to take place in Q3 to vote on the RTO, with Pteris' largest shareholder China International Marine Containers (CIMC) also expressing opposition to the removal of the five directors.

site_title: Sembcorp revives property unit
summary: Sembcorp Industries is reviving its dormant subsidiary Sembcorp Properties to develop residential and commercial properties in its existing industrial parks, starting with China. The company aims to generate a three-digit net profit from its urban development segment by 2020. Sembcorp Properties will focus on building mid- to high-end residential developments in China, with the first projects planned in the Singapore-Sichuan Hi-tech Innovation Park and the Sino-Singapore Nanjing Eco Hi-tech Island. The move is part of Sembcorp's strategy to build up urban development as a third pillar, alongside its utilities and marine operations.

site_title: S Korea to extend detention of ferry captain
summary: South Korean prosecutors are seeking to extend the detention of the Sewol ferry captain and two crew members by 10 days as they investigate the cause of the accident that likely claimed over 300 lives. The ferry was on a routine voyage when it capsized in calm weather, with passengers and crew ordered to stay put in their cabins. The captain, who feared passengers would be swept away by currents if they leapt into the sea, was not on the bridge when the ship turned and navigation was in the hands of a 26-year-old third mate.

site_title: Riau's economic loss from forest fires in March hits 20t rupiah
summary: Riau's economic loss from forest fires in March has reached 20 trillion rupiah ($2.18 billion), approaching the damage caused by the 2004 tsunami in Aceh. The fires, largely concentrated on the island of Sumatra, have disrupted local businesses and incomes, with 500 billion rupiah set aside to fight blazes in May-August. The region's forest cover has lost almost 200,000 hectares since 2010, and unsustainable forest management and climate change are linked to the prevalence of fires.

site_title: Should failing to act diligently be a crime?
summary: Singapore's regulatory framework for directors has been criticized for being overly harsh, with penalties for failing to act diligently potentially leading to criminal charges and fines. The cases of Chuan Soon Huat Industrial Group Limited and AirOcean Group Limited demonstrate the application of Section 157(1) of the Companies Act, which holds directors to a high standard of governance. The writer argues that this provision should be revised to strike a better balance between deterrence, compensation, and punishment, and that civil penalties and disqualification from directorship roles could be sufficient alternatives to criminal sanctions.

site_title: Chef of the century
summary: French culinary icons Joel Robuchon and Alain Ducasse continue to defy the notion that French food is fading in popularity. Despite rumors of their restaurants closing, Robuchon has signed a six-year lease extension and sees increased covers at his high-end restaurant. He attributes Singapore's unique cultural landscape as a challenging environment for foreign chefs, citing Guy Savoy's closure as an example. Robuchon maintains that consistency and quality are key to success, and he believes that French cuisine will endure, especially in emerging markets. He also emphasizes the importance of protecting local talent and adapting to local cultures.

site_title: Curved beauty from Samsung
summary: Samsung has launched the world's first curved UHD TV, combining its curved design with ultra-high definition technology. The 55-inch model costs $6,499 and the 65-inch model costs $9,499, with discounts available for early registrants. The TV's optimal curvature of 4200R provides a panoramic effect, accentuating width and depth, and features four times the resolution and pixels of Full HD. Additionally, Samsung has introduced improved smart TV functions, including a friendlier remote control system and faster search.

site_title: Premature to define areas of tie-up with Ezion: AusGroup
summary: AusGroup, an Australia-based offshore & marine services provider, will provide initial help to Ezion Holdings to develop its capabilities, including fuel pump development and project management support. The collaboration, announced in a non-legally binding memorandum of understanding, aims to augment Darwin Port with increased regional capacity for oil & gas and resource industries. AusGroup CEO Stuart Kenny stated that the scope of their partnership is preliminary and unclear, with further discussions needed to identify opportunities beyond these initial areas.

site_title: Rising property taxes filling US cities' revenues
summary: US cities are experiencing a surge in property tax collections, the fastest pace since the 2009 housing market crash. Revenue from real estate levies has set records or is poised to in cities like San Jose, Nashville, Houston, and Washington, helping local governments rebuild after years of budget cuts. This increase in revenue has boosted collections by 3% over 2012, the biggest gain since 2009, easing the risk of credit-rating cuts for local governments and resulting in gains in local government bond yields.

site_title: Tougher for shipping banks to refinance debt
summary: Shipping banks face significant challenges in refinancing debt, with 35 billion euros (S$60.57 billion) at risk over the next two years. European banks, led by Germany's HSH Nordbank and Commerzbank, are struggling with rising losses on shipping loans due to the prolonged container industry crisis. The crisis is expected to have a long-term impact on shipping banks, with a history of default making it harder for lenders to trust their assets. The European Central Bank is also scrutinizing the finances of major banks ahead of taking over as regulators in November.

site_title: What's in store for Lock+Store
summary: Lock+Store, a self-storage solutions provider, is expanding its operations in Singapore and Malaysia, with plans to double its facilities to eight in Singapore and introduce its first overseas facility in Temasya Industrial Park, Malaysia. The company aims to target small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and start-ups, which currently make up 57% of its corporate users. Lock+Store plans to open four more facilities in Kuala Lumpur and two in Penang, with online payment options and a regional presence on social media. The company's CEO, Helen Ng, believes the self-storage industry will face another round of consolidation in the coming years.

site_title: Apps that nudge, nag and manipulate you into financial health
summary: Financial apps are using insights from behavioral finance to help investors overcome bad habits and achieve financial goals. Apps such as StickK, Opower, and Level Money use techniques like peer pressure, social proof, and gamification to motivate users to save, spend, and invest wisely. These apps have shown promising results, with StickK users achieving 75% of their goals and Opower reducing energy usage by 1-3.5%. The future of financial apps may also be in artificial intelligence, which can track and analyze transactions to provide personalized recommendations and insights.

site_title: 2 new awards for those who hire disabled
summary: The Enabling Employers Awards, organized by SG Enable, recognized employers who hire disabled individuals. The first two awards honored champions in various categories, and this year's event introduced two new awards: Leading Employer and Individuals for Commendation. Eight winners were selected from 18 employers for the Leading Employer award, which highlights employers who consistently help the disabled. The award's goal is to enable more handicapped people to become self-reliant through employment, with SG Enable taking a two-pronged approach to achieve this through training and work exposure.

site_title: 4 fun
summary: The Mercedes-Benz C400 4Matic is a high-end variant of the new C-Class line-up, offering a sporty performance despite being a family sedan. Equipped with a 3.0-litre twin-turbo V6 and all-wheel-drive system, the car achieves increased traction and stability. Its 333 hp and 480 Newton-metres of torque enable fast response to pressure from the gas pedal, while its new four-link front suspension and five-link rear suspension improve handling and stability. The C-Class is also more luxurious, with a spacious cabin and advanced safety equipment, making it a surprisingly athletic alternative to drive.

site_title: Chocolate to cost more this Easter
summary: Global demand for chocolate is driving up prices ahead of Easter, with the cost of cocoa beans reaching a 30-month high in March. Rising demand, coupled with lower output, has led to a surge in prices, with cocoa butter increasing 86% in the past year. Global bean production is expected to rise, but still falls short of demand, fueling concerns about supply shortages. Confectioners are passing on the increased costs to customers, with prices expected to rise further by the end of the year.

site_title: Goodbye Grid Girl, hello S'pore Girl?
summary: Singapore Airlines has signed a two-year agreement to become the title sponsor of the Singapore Grand Prix, replacing SingTel, which held the title for six years. The airline plans to promote its brand through the event, leveraging its network and affluent client base. The move may also involve introducing the Singapore Girl, a mascot, to the event, potentially with a male counterpart, the Singapore Boy, to promote gender equality. The change is expected to take effect for the 2014 season.

site_title: Buyback activity stays high
summary: Buyback activity in Singapore remained high in the week ending April 17, with five companies making purchases worth $500,000. Popular Holdings, GP Industries, Soup Restaurant Group, OCBC Bank, and Samko Timber bought back shares at an average price of 24.4 cents, 48.1 cents, 24.9 cents, $9.66, and 12.6 cents, respectively. The total value of repurchases was $3.53 million, down from $19.26 million the previous week.

site_title: Ascendas Reit posts Q4 DPU of 3.55 cents
summary: Ascendas Reit posted a Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.55 cents, a 16% increase from the previous year, driven by a 23.9% increase in distributable income to $85.3 million. The Reit also benefited from a $131.1 million revaluation gain for its 105 properties. Net property income rose 12.2% to $112.3 million, and earnings per unit rose 31.9% to 7.11 cents. The Reit's DPU for the full year was 14.24 cents, higher than the previous year.

site_title: Pro-apps get consumer touch
summary: Companies are investing heavily in user interface design to improve employee productivity and create a more user-friendly experience, bridging the gap between consumer and enterprise apps. Large enterprises are recognizing the importance of a strong user experience, with 56% of companies willing to pay up to 30% more for a positive buying experience. This shift is driven by the growing demand for mobile versions of enterprise software and the need for more intuitive designs, with many companies opting for smaller, single-purpose apps. As a result, companies like Avanade are expanding their user interface departments to meet this demand.

site_title: Satisfying aficionados
summary: The European Tour will return to Singapore in May after a two-year hiatus, co-sanctioning The Championship event with the Asian Tour. The tournament will be played on Laguna National Golf and Country Club's Masters Course from May 1-4, featuring a field of 156 players from Europe and Asia. This marks the first men's golf competition in Singapore since 2012, with the event aiming to raise the country's international standing in golf and bring it closer to becoming a Sports Hub. The tournament will also coincide with the grand opening of Laguna's new Dusit Thani resort hotel in 2016.

site_title: The booming business in behavioural finance
summary: Financial apps are using behavioural finance techniques to "nudge" people into better financial behaviors, but their effectiveness is unproven. While some interventions work, others can fall flat or backfire, and may not address deeper structural issues like stagnant wages. Emotional triggers, such as fear and greed, can be detrimental to investment decisions, and apps are using a mix of encouragement, incentives, and design to combat these issues. However, the field is also raising concerns about manipulation and the potential for products to fail to make a dent in the vast apparatus distracting people from their best intentions.

site_title: For the Jubilee baby
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore is celebrating its 50th anniversary of independence, and a Jubilee Baby Gift pack has been proposed for children born in 2015. Various individuals and companies have suggested items for the pack, including locally designed artwork, practical items like baby products and clothing, and unique commemorative items such as a Singapore 50 coin and a commemorative edition of The Straits Times. Some suggestions also include sentimental items like a personalized photo album and a digital storage medium loaded with documentaries about Singapore's history. The goal is to create a meaningful gift that celebrates the child's heritage and Singapore's history.

site_title: Slick Salves
summary: Aromatherapy has made a comeback, with essential oils being adopted for various purposes including counselling sessions, concentration, and treating conditions like depression and anxiety. Companies like Young Living and Mt Sapola have seen significant growth in sales, with Young Living's sales increasing 816% since starting its office in Singapore. While conclusive studies on aromatherapy's effectiveness are limited, some studies suggest its benefits, such as reducing symptoms associated with dementia and Alzheimer's disease. Aromatherapy is also being incorporated into beauty products and medicine cabinets, with some devotees swearing by its benefits for their health and well-being.

site_title: Fusing three major cuisines
summary: Chef Jean-Philippe Patruno's new restaurant Una in Singapore attempts to fuse Italian, French, and Spanish cuisines, but the result is inconsistent. The menu highlights regional origins, but dishes often lack harmony of flavors. Standouts include the day's special fish soup and squid plancha, but the slow-cooked octopus and pork belly fall short due to texture issues. The restaurant shows promise, but Patruno may benefit from focusing on a single cuisine to excel. With generous servings and a pleasant atmosphere, Una is a promising addition to Singapore's dining scene, but it needs refinement to reach its full potential.

site_title: Record-breaker
summary: Record Store Day returns this year with a record-breaking number of collectible limited-edition vinyls, with Singaporeans among the first in the world to access these exclusive titles. The event celebrates indie record shops and features rare vinyls pressed in limited quantities, often selling out quickly and reselling on auction sites. This year, 608 releases worldwide will be available, with Singapore retailers expecting a big turnout. Despite some titles being in short supply, prices are surprisingly affordable, with most albums priced between $35-$40 and 7-inch singles starting from $15.

site_title: Teaching codes, changing lives
summary: A Singaporean startup, Brackets For Change (BR4C), aims to bridge the gap between technology and education among pre-university students by teaching coding skills for free. The youth-led initiative, founded by 21-year-old Chan Wen Tjun and three peers, will host its first event, Technovation Youth 2014, a workshop and ideation competition, to promote technopreneurship. The event will provide participants with programming and coding skills, and the goal is to encourage the next generation of tech entrepreneurs and contribute to Singapore's startup ecosystem.

site_title: Indulging in France's best hotel
summary: The Hotel Bristol in Paris, a "Palace Hotel" since 1925, has been voted the best hotel in France by TripAdvisor Traveller's Choice 2014. Located on Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore, it has long been a favorite among the discreet elite and celebrities such as Kim Novak and Charlie Chaplin. The hotel has undergone several makeovers and extensions, with a current mascot being the pampered house cat Fa-raon. It also features three Michelin-starred restaurants, Epicure and 114 Faubourg, offering refined dining experiences.

site_title: Etihad hardens position on Alitalia deal: sources
summary: Etihad Airways has hardened its stance on investing in Italy's struggling Alitalia, seeking 2,000 job cuts and a 49% stake in the airline. The Gulf airline's demands have stalled talks on a potential investment, which would require a cash-rich partner to revamp Alitalia's flight network. A government source believes Etihad's tougher position can be overcome, while Italian Infrastructure Minister Maurizio Lupi stated that the decision is up to Alitalia's private shareholders.

site_title: Southern retreat
summary: The Great Southern Region in Western Australia, particularly Albany and Denmark, is emerging as a gourmet and wine-tasting destination, rivaling Margaret River. The region boasts picturesque wineries, artisanal stores, and a strong emphasis on local, homemade products. Visitors can enjoy wine tastings, farm-to-table experiences, and outdoor activities like hiking and exploring natural wonders. The area's rural charm and relaxed atmosphere make it an ideal retreat for those seeking a slower pace of life.

site_title: At home with Calvin Klein
summary: Calvin Klein Home, a home furnishings line, has been a part of the brand since 1995, offering a range of products including bedding, bath, and furniture. Creative Director Amy Mellen oversees the designs, focusing on timelessness and long-lasting quality. New product ranges are introduced twice a year, with a focus on understated luxury and elegance. The brand's designs have become iconic, such as the bamboo flowers pattern, which remains popular even after being featured on TV's "Sex and the City." Calvin Klein Home products are sold in Asia and are available in select retailers, with Mellen's own home serving as a living showroom for the brand.

site_title: Japan Inc investing less in China now
summary: Japan's business investment in China has plummeted 18% to 887 billion yen (S$10.9 billion) due to deteriorating relations between the two countries over territorial issues. In contrast, Japanese foreign direct investment (FDI) in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) almost doubled to 2.33 trillion yen (S$28.5 billion), with major investments in Thailand and Singapore. Asean has emerged as a more attractive investment destination, with Indonesia taking first place for the first time. Rising labour costs in China and heightened risk awareness are cited as reasons for the shift.

site_title: Needed urgently: venue for 2019 Asian Games
summary: The 2019 Asian Games, originally awarded to Hanoi, Vietnam, have been pulled out due to concerns over lack of preparation and high costs. The Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) is now seeking a replacement city, with time running out as the event is only five years away. Vietnam's government cited a need to focus on other urgent tasks, while Indonesia has expressed interest in potentially hosting the event, but has not committed to doing so. The OCA is working to find a new host city, with the event previously held in Incheon, South Korea.

site_title: China's home price rise cools to 8-month low
summary: China's home price inflation slowed to an 8-month low in March, with average new home prices rising 7.7% from a year earlier, down from 8.7% in February. Analysts expect the easing trend to continue, citing reduced developer price cuts and local government easing of restrictions. The cooling property market is seen as a stabilisation sign, but concerns remain about potential bad debt and its impact on the economy, which marked its slowest growth pace in 18 months in the first quarter.

site_title: CIMC stands its ground on Pteris RTO
summary: China International Marine Containers (CIMC) has rejected claims by Pteris Global director Winston Tan that the proposed reverse takeover (RTO) is unattractive, stating that the terms have been negotiated carefully. CIMC, the largest shareholder, will not engage in further negotiations and will take steps to protect its interests if the existing directors are removed. The RTO, which involves injecting CIMC's subsidiary into Pteris, is expected to make CIMC the controlling shareholder with 75% ownership.

site_title: London calling for mid-sized homegrown developers: OCBC
summary: Singaporean mid-sized property developers are expanding overseas, particularly in London and Australia, to pursue better margins amid stiff competition at home. Since 2010, OCBC's loan book in London has grown five times, driven by attractive yields of 5% and longer leases of up to 15 years. This trend is expected to continue, with more construction loans allocated to these markets this year. Smaller developers can access funding through joint-venture deals with Asian lenders, including OCBC, when Western banks are hesitant.

site_title: Startup peers into data crystal ball for fashion trends
summary: A Singaporean startup, Lift12, has developed a methodology to predict and capitalize on fashion trends by analyzing data from catwalks, social media, and buyer behavior. The company collects and refines data to identify products with high potential for sales, allowing it to release new collections at a faster pace than traditional fast fashion giants, such as Zara and H&M. Lift12's fast-release cycle enables it to beat the market pace by two to three times and has helped the company achieve a 50% net profit margin. The startup aims to raise $300,000 in a smaller round before a larger Series A fund-raising effort at the end of the year.

site_title: GlobalFoundries ramping up S'pore chip operations
summary: GlobalFoundries, a subsidiary of Mubadala's Advanced Technology Investment Company, is ramping up its 300mm silicon wafer production capacity in Singapore, expanding its semicon chip production by a third compared to 200mm wafers. The facility has acquired 1,000 leading-edge tools from ProMOS DRAM fab and is running both 200mm and 300mm production lines in parallel to ensure business continuity for its 200mm customers. The expansion is part of ATIC's US$9 billion investment plan to boost semicon operations.

site_title: Eating seafood responsibly
summary: Singapore is set to host its first Sustainable Seafood Festival in June, with eight restaurants serving seafood from certified distributors. The event aims to raise awareness about the threat of overfishing and promote responsible seafood consumption. Participating restaurants include Absinthe Restaurant Francais and Gattopardo Ristorante di Mare, which will serve MSC-certified seafood from suppliers like Indoguna and Lee Fish. The festival highlights the importance of sustainable seafood practices to prevent the extinction of species like red snapper and tiger prawns.

site_title: Vitamin D keeps the doctor away
summary: Research studies have found that Vitamin D deficiency is common among adults, particularly those living in modern cities with limited sun exposure, despite the fact that they live in tropical regions. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in maintaining bone health, lowering the risk of diabetes and heart attacks, and regulating blood pressure and blood sugar levels. Adequate Vitamin D intake can reduce the likelihood of fractures, increase muscular strength, and lower the risk of heart disease. The recommended daily intake is around 800 IU, with higher doses providing additional benefits.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Japan Inc is shifting its investment focus from China to ASEAN, amid territorial disputes. Meanwhile, mid-sized Singapore property developers are expanding overseas, particularly in London and Australia. Analysts predict a new phase of the US bull market, with the S&P 500 reaching a record high. GlobalFoundries is ramping up its Singapore chip operations, and Pteris Global's directors support a proposed reverse takeover. The US and China are set to meet as President Obama tours Asia, while Russia faces recession due to the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: Addressing cloud adoption issues
summary: Cloud computing has gained mainstream acceptance, but only 38% of organizations use cloud services. Experts cite concerns about security, reliability, and control as major barriers to adoption. Corporate IT departments often hinder cloud adoption, and the process can take months, while departments like marketing and sales bypass IT to use cloud services. Key drivers of adoption include application usage, cost savings, and improved efficiency. The public cloud services market is expected to grow at a 17.4% CAGR through 2017, but concerns about privacy, security, and ownership persist. To overcome these issues, experts recommend changing thinking around infrastructure, adopting a pay-as-you-go model, and leveraging government incentives to encourage cloud adoption among small and medium-sized businesses.

site_title: Asian push towards in-house M&As forces big banks to adapt
summary: Asian companies are increasingly relying on internal teams to handle mergers and acquisitions, forcing global investment banks to adapt. Recent deals, such as Temasek's acquisition of AS Watson and Citic Pacific's assets, show Asian acquirers are using internal talent to get deals done, often sidelining international banks. However, big banks can still play a role in complex deals or those with regulatory issues, and may provide value-added services such as distribution and idea generation. The shift is a marked contrast to the market for initial public offerings (IPOs), where Asian companies are seeking less banking support.

site_title: Japanese car sales accelerate in Q1
summary: Japanese car sales accelerated in Q1 2014, with Toyota and Nissan rising to second and fifth spots, respectively. Mercedes-Benz remained the top brand with 1,225 cars registered, followed by Toyota and BMW. Japan's second-largest carmaker, Nissan, surpassed BMW, while Mazda retained its seventh place. The total number of new cars registered in Q1 increased by 10.7% compared to the previous year, with Mercedes-Benz increasing its market share to 20.5%. The surge in Japanese sales is attributed to cyclical trends and the re-classification of COE Category A in February.

site_title: Chongqing's charms
summary: Chongqing, a 12-million-population city in southwestern China, offers an underrated weekend destination with its natural wonders, fiery cuisine, and ancient towns. The Banyan Tree Chongqing Bei Bei resort, located in the northern part of the city, features private hot spring jacuzzis in each of its 107 suites and villas, as well as a range of activities such as hiking, cave exploration, and river cruises. The resort also offers tours of downtown Chongqing, including visits to ancient towns like Pianyan Old Town and Hongya Cave, and access to luxury boutiques and high-end department stores.

site_title: The perfect proposition
summary: The BMW 420i, an entry-level 4 Series Coupe, offers a more refined and engaging driving experience compared to the 220i, despite having the same powertrain. Its lower weight and modified suspension allow for a more dynamic drive, with improved balance and fluidity at high speeds. The 420i's cabin is also quieter and more spacious, making it a more grown-up alternative to the 2 Series. With a starting price of $244,800, the 420i is a premium option in the 4 Series lineup.

site_title: Living the high life
summary: Dalat, a town in Vietnam's Central Highlands, has become a popular destination for those seeking a temperate climate. Le Ngoc Khanh Tam and her husband Barry Israel, a native and American lawyer respectively, have built a luxurious villa in the town, La Vallee de Dalat, which showcases French colonial architecture. The villa features large verandas and windows, offering stunning views of the surrounding pine forests and mountains. The couple, who also own the Dalat Palace Hotel and Golf Course, enjoy spending time in Dalat and appreciate the town's romantic atmosphere, earning it the nickname "La Petit Paris".

site_title: The iconic godfather of French cuisine
summary: French chef and entrepreneur Alain Ducasse continues to expand his culinary empire, with over 20 Michelin stars and 25 years of experience. Despite being labeled a businessman, Ducasse prioritizes food and cooking, while his ventures, such as his chocolate boutique and restaurants, demonstrate his commitment to excellence. Ducasse aims to promote French culinary know-how, not only domestically but also abroad, through his cooking school, Le Collège Culinaire de France. He believes that French cuisine's image abroad needs improvement, but with international chefs working together, they can boost its reputation. Ducasse remains focused on quality over quantity, with plans to open restaurants in London and Beijing in 2015.

site_title: CMA posts 2.8% rise in Q1 profit
summary: CAPITAMALLS Asia (CMA) posted a 2.8% increase in Q1 profit to $75.3 million, driven by higher property income from Olinas Mall in Japan and operating malls in China. Revenue rose 4.8% year-on-year to $125 million. The group also recorded a portfolio loss of $1.9 million, despite earnings per share remaining unchanged at 1.9 cents.

site_title: Correction
summary: The Straits Times corrected an error in a previous article stating the government's GDP growth projection for 2014 should be 2-4%, not 2-3%.

site_title: Societe Generale poised for another Asian push
summary: Societe Generale is expanding its presence in Asia, despite selling its Asian private bank business to DBS Group Holdings for $220 million last month. The bank is increasing its corporate and investment banking and markets business, as well as commodities trade finance. This move suggests Societe Generale is focusing on other revenue streams in the region.

site_title: Vapores, Hapag-Lloyd strike merger deal
summary: Compania SudAmericana de Vapores and Hapag-Lloyd have signed a merger deal to create the world's fourth-largest container shipping company. The deal includes two capital increases totaling 740 million euros, with Vapores contributing 259 million euros and ending up with a 34% stake in Hapag-Lloyd. The agreement is subject to approval by April 30 and includes a provision for annulment if more than 5% of Vapores' shareholders exercise withdrawal rights by April 20. The merger aims to help the struggling shipping industry cope with low freight rates and overcapacity.

site_title: Drone completes first full seabed scan in jet hunt
summary: A deep-sea drone, Bluefin-21, has completed its first full scan of the seabed in the Indian Ocean, 2,000 km west of Perth, in search of the missing Malaysian jetliner MH370. The drone, deployed at a depth of 4.5 km, has searched approximately 90 square kilometers and its data is being analyzed. Authorities are relying on the drone as the air and surface search becomes less likely to yield results, with the black box's battery now 10 days past its expiry date. The search operation is expected to shift focus to the largely unmapped area of ocean floor.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Singapore's Esplanade presents various events, including a stand-up comedy show "Happy Ever Laughter" with 13 local comedians, running until April 27. An exhibition "Fragment...Plus" featuring award-winning photographs by Kristin Man runs until May 11. The "Around the World" music festival will take place from April 20, and White Rabbit restaurant hosts an Easter buffet on April 20. The Peranakan Museum showcases "Auspicious Designs" with 36 altar cloths and other objects until December 28.

site_title: Growth in premium air travel slows in February
summary: Growth in premium air travel slowed to 4.1% in February, down from 6.1% in January, primarily due to a decline in the Far East, likely caused by China's economic slowdown. However, mature economies like Europe and the US helped offset this decline. The North Atlantic market expanded by 3.8%, while the North and Mid Pacific market rose 5.6% due to improving trade growth. Iata warns that if trade expansion slows, so could growth in business-related air travel.

site_title: CCT renews Robinsons, M&S lease at Raffles City
summary: CapitaCommercial Trust (CCT) has renewed a 100,000 sq ft lease at Raffles City Shopping Centre with a major retail tenant, as the trust posted a 7.2% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit to 2.08¢ in Q1. The trust's distributable income grew 7.6% to $59.9 million, driven by higher net property income from its wholly owned properties and income from Raffles City Singapore. CCT expects Grade A office rental rates to increase due to limited new supply, benefiting its portfolio.

site_title: 286 people still missing in Korea ferry disaster
summary: Rescuers in South Korea continue searching for 286 people missing after a ferry capsized 24 hours ago, killing 10 and rescuing 179. The vessel, carrying 475 passengers and crew, capsized on its way to the holiday island of Jeju. Despite efforts to find survivors, no official explanation has been given for the sinking, and authorities are investigating the cause. President Park Geun-hye promised to make every effort to rescue those still trapped, but grieving parents have accused rescue teams of being slow to react and for lack of information.

images.alt_text: Rescuers fought rising winds and waves yesterday as they searched for hundreds of people, mostly teenage schoolchildren, still missing after a South Korean ferry capsized more than 24 hours ago - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Serving the Queen, and now Singapore
summary: British wine and spirits merchant Berry Bros & Rudd (BB&R) has set up shop in Singapore, offering over 4,000 bottles of wine, including those served at Buckingham Palace. Chairman Simon Berry believes the Singapore market is the most sophisticated in Asia, with consumers seeking niche and rare wines. BB&R plans to introduce customers to rare wines through educational seminars and affordable bottles starting from S$25. The company aims to increase its revenue from Asia to 50% in the next few years, with Singapore and South-east Asia contributing 30% of that revenue.

site_title: New SAT gets real, ditches obscure words
summary: The College Board has announced a redesign of the SAT, shifting from a vocabulary-based test to an achievement test that assesses students' mastery of concepts taught in high school. The new test, set to be implemented in 2016, will focus on "real-world applications" of math, reading, and science, and will require students to cite evidence to support their answers. This change aims to make the test more relevant to college work and to identify students ready for higher education.

site_title: Competition panel clears proposed SIA-Air NZ tie-up
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore has cleared a proposed strategic alliance between Singapore Airlines and Air New Zealand, citing net economic benefits to Singapore despite potential competition concerns. The tie-up will expand capacity between Singapore and New Zealand, giving each carrier access to specific destinations in the other's network. The joint revenue-sharing agreement will also enhance competition on a route operated by Qantas. Regulatory approvals in both Singapore and New Zealand are required for the alliance to proceed.

site_title: Low China exposure makes UOB best S'pore bank stock
summary: UOB has become the best-performing local bank stock in Singapore, reaching a multi-year high of $22.23 due to its low exposure to China, a country experiencing slowing growth. The bank's Greater China loans account for 6.8% of its group loans, compared to 16% for OCBC and 19% for DBS. Analysts attribute UOB's success to its defensive stance and constant focus on liquidity, making it a safe bet for investors.

site_title: García Márquez, conjuror of literary magic
summary: Colombian novelist Gabriel García Márquez, known for his magical realism and influential works like "One Hundred Years of Solitude," died at his home in Mexico City at 87. He was diagnosed with lymphatic cancer in 1999 and developed senile dementia. García Márquez received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982 for his universal appeal and mastery of the magical realism genre. His writing often incorporated Latin American history, politics, and culture, and he was a vocal left-wing advocate. García Márquez's legacy includes numerous bestselling novels, including "Love in the Time of Cholera" and "The Autumn of the Patriarch."

site_title: Fermented chocolate heaven
summary: Cacao Barry has released a new line of premium chocolates called Purity from Nature, consisting of dark chocolates and a milk chocolate variety. The chocolates undergo a seven-year Q Fermentation process, which involves isolating beneficial micro-organisms from the beans to ensure purity and higher yield. This process is patented by the company and has been developed in collaboration with 8,000 farms in the Ivory Coast. The result is a higher-quality chocolate with a purer taste, suitable for premium bakeries, hotels, and confectioners, as well as consumers.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines should not be privatised
summary: Malaysia Airlines should not be privatized, as taking the airline private without a well-thought-out strategic plan could worsen its financial woes. The airline's financial issues are not solely due to its public listing, and privatization will not magically solve its problems. The airline's union and previous failed turnaround plans demonstrate that privatization alone is not the solution. Instead, Malaysia Airlines should rebuild itself as a proud flag carrier, leveraging its strong brand equity and 40-year history to recover from the current crisis.

site_title: Signature Leibovitz
summary: Renowned portrait photographer Annie Leibovitz's exhibition "Annie Leibovitz A Photographer's Life 1990-2005" is now open at the ArtScience Museum, showcasing almost 200 of her pictures, including both celebrity and personal works. The exhibition spans a 15-year period, covering major life events such as the birth of her daughters and the death of her father and long-time companion Susan Sontag. Leibovitz reveals that her favorite photograph is a black-and-white portrait of her mother, taken in 1997, highlighting the importance of capturing intimate moments.

site_title: SGX, Taiwan mull cross-trading of shares
summary: Singapore and Taiwan are discussing potential cross-trading of shares on each other's exchanges, with the goal of reducing brokerage fees and increasing market efficiency. The two exchanges may shortlist high-quality stocks for the cross-trading system, which could be implemented by the end of the year. This move aims to boost Taiwan's capital market, which has struggled to attract foreign investors, and to strengthen ties between the two countries.

site_title: Championing the 'rights of things'
summary: Chinese artists Wu Shanzhuan and Inga Svala Thorsdottir have developed "Things Rights," a concept inspired by the Human Rights Charter, which challenges the status quo and questions belief systems. Their work, which includes 30 new prints, layers concepts from the past 20 years into complex geometrical formations and philosophical insights. The artists, who met in 1991, have created a peculiar brand of logic and language that merges language-based practices with historically informed art. Their work is a maze of strange ideas and a powerful concept that opens new attitudes, available in over 10 languages.

site_title: STI in positive territory, thanks to Jardine stocks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) finished 0.6 of a point higher at 3,253.8 on Thursday, supported by Jardine Cycle & Carriage's 2.8% jump to $48.23. Jardine Matheson and Jardine Strategic also contributed to the gains. Despite this, Keppel Corp's shares fell 20 cents, and Genting Singapore's slipped half a cent. Analysts remain bullish on Keppel Corp, citing its robust balance sheet and undervalued stock price. The market saw limited retail participation, with brokers noting that major positive news is needed to drive prices higher.

site_title: Malaysia opposition stalwart Karpal Singh dies in truck collision
summary: Karpal Singh, a prominent Malaysian opposition leader and lawyer, died in a truck collision on the outskirts of Perak. He was 73, not 74 as mentioned in the article, and was instantly killed along with his assistant. Singh was known for his courage and principle in championing unpopular cases and defending individuals charged with drug offenses. He continued to practice law and politics despite being a tetraplegic after a near-fatal accident in 2005. Tributes poured in from politicians across the political divide, with many lamenting his loss and praising his contributions to Malaysia.

site_title: Highfaluting stuff
summary: The sci-fi thriller "Transcendence" fails to entertain due to poor pacing, a script with untidy narrative threads, and a lack of emotional response. The film, directed by Wally Pfister and written by Jack Paglen, explores the theme of humanity versus technology after a brilliant scientist's attempt to create a self-aware computer goes horribly wrong. The movie's ambitions are hampered by the performances of its A-list cast, including Johnny Depp, and its inability to effectively convey the stakes of the apocalypse. The film receives a rating of C.

site_title: European property-loan sales seen rising 65%
summary: European property-loan sales are expected to rise 65% to a record 50 billion euros in 2014, driven by improving economies and investor appetite. Transactions so far this year have reached 29.8 billion euros, surpassing all of 2013. The increase is attributed to the liquidation of the Irish Bank Resolution Corp and investor capital deployed to European real estate and credit linked to property, totaling 125 billion euros. This year may mark a peak for loan sales, with major buyers such as Lone Star Funds and Cerberus Capital Management LP.

site_title: Elder statesmen of entertainment
summary: Singers Lionel Richie and Andre Rieu performed at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, despite lower-than-expected attendance. Richie, 64, played a 100-minute set featuring over two dozen of his hits, while Rieu, also 64, wowed the audience with his classical concert, incorporating pop tunes and cracking jokes. Both performers showcased remarkable showmanship, with Richie keeping energy high through banter and Rieu making classical music accessible to a broad audience.

site_title: Aquino sorry about fresh airport mess
summary: Philippine President Benigno Aquino apologized for the failures in air conditioning at Manila airport, named the world's worst by an online travel guide. The airport's Terminal 1, used by foreign airlines, experienced inadequate air conditioning during the Easter holidays. The transportation ministry also issued a public apology, citing that the air-conditioning system was undergoing rehabilitation and replacement parts had not been delivered yet. The apology came amid numerous complaints from irate travelers, who criticized the airport's "dilapidated facilities" and long waiting times.

site_title: Temasek's Olam offer fair but not to all
summary: Temasek has launched an offer to acquire Olam International for $5.33 billion, valuing the agri-commodities firm at $2.23 per share. Rothschild, the independent financial adviser, has deemed the offer fair and reasonable for shareholders and warrant holders, but not for convertible bondholders, who would receive $850.37 for every $1,000 principal amount. Olam's independent directors recommend that shareholders and warrant holders accept the offer, while convertible bondholders reject it due to its "see-through" price basis not being fair and reasonable.

site_title: China firm buys Danga Bay land for RM600m
summary: China's Greenland Group has acquired 13.96 acres of land in Danga Bay, Malaysia for RM600 million, in a 90:10 equity partnership with Iskandar Waterfront Holdings. The development, valued at RM2.2 billion, is expected to commence work by the end of the year and complete within five years. Despite a softening property market, Greenland is prepared to invest US$3.3 billion in the project, confirming reports of Chinese developers targeting Iskandar. The move is seen as a strategic investment, with the development expected to offer good returns.

site_title: T+3 settlement period should remain: remisiers
summary: The Society of Remisiers (SOR) has submitted feedback to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding proposed changes to the settlement period for trades. SOR recommends retaining the current T+3 settlement period and requiring collateral only for trades above $50,000, citing concerns that reducing the settlement period would harm the local market's participation of speculators. They also propose raising broking fees for trades below $50,000 and removing penalties for short-selling trades under $50,000.

site_title: Why I like the wines I like
summary: A wine critic shares his criteria for enjoying a fine wine, prioritizing freshness, followed by taste, weight, and balance. He emphasizes the importance of a wine's mouthfeel, which he considers the first attribute to look for. If a wine lacks freshness, it is considered drinkable only if other attributes like sweetness and ripeness are present. The critic's preferences are exemplified by his enjoyment of two wines, La Fleur de Gay 1990 and Chateau Latour 2003, both of which exhibit high levels of freshness and complexity.

site_title: iPhone update may feature song-ID
summary: Apple is set to unveil a song-discovery feature in its upcoming iOS 8 update, allowing iPhone users to identify a song and its artist using an iPhone or iPad. The feature will be integrated into the mobile software, leveraging technology from Shazam Entertainment Ltd, which can quickly spot what's playing by collecting sound from a phone's microphone and matching it against a song database. The move aims to bolster Apple's music offerings, despite slowed song-download sales.

site_title: Japan mulls cable car for Olympics venues
summary: Japan is considering building a cable car to connect 2020 Tokyo Olympics venues with the Ginza shopping district, estimated to cost 21.5 billion yen (S$262 million). The proposed gondola lift would link Shiodome to Toyosu, benefiting from the expected 10.1 million visitors and staff during the Games. Mayor Takaaki Yamazaki sees the cable car as a positive for tourism and a resource for Koto ward, where half of the competition sites will be located.

site_title: Sabana Reit's DPU falls 22% to 1.88¢ in Q1
summary: Sabana Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 22% to 1.88 cents in Q1, due to a 9.2% decline in net property income to $18.4 million. The decline reflects challenging market conditions, with lower occupancy rates for multi-tenanted properties at 76.9%. The company plans to intensify marketing and leasing efforts to improve occupancy and recycle capital by divesting underperforming assets.

site_title: Maybank suggests that ailing MAS be taken private
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) is under financial pressure, with a net loss of RM1.2 billion in 2013 and an oversold stock. Maybank Investment Bank suggests the airline be taken private to cost major shareholder Khazanah RM1.18 billion, with potential returns of RM1.25 billion if profitable businesses are spun off. The airline's financial woes are exacerbated by the ongoing hunt for Flight MH370, which could lead to further financial losses. Maybank believes privatization and restructuring could lead to better performance by 2015.

site_title: Stooping to new comedic lows to get a laugh
summary: A comedy film "The Other Woman" fails to deliver laughs, relying on predictable cliches and crude humor. The story revolves around a woman who discovers her husband is cheating with two other women, leading to a series of revenge plotlines. Despite featuring comedic actresses like Cameron Diaz and Leslie Mann, the film lacks a decent script, resulting in a formulaic and unsophisticated comedy that fails to engage the audience.

site_title: China Q1 home sales down on tight credit
summary: China's home sales declined 7.7% to 1.1 trillion yuan in the first quarter, as credit remained tight, contributing to a slowdown in the country's economy. New property construction dropped 25% to 291 million square meters, and money supply grew at the slowest pace on record. The country's economic expansion slowed to its weakest pace in six quarters, raising concerns about missing its annual growth target of 7.5%. The main reason for the decline was tight credit, with less money flowing into the market, according to analysts.

site_title: March non-oil exports weaker than expected
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 6.6% in March, beating market expectations of a 0.5% growth, but the country's official GDP growth estimate for the first quarter may not be revised downwards. The NODX decline was largely due to a dip in non-electronics shipments and a bigger drop in electronics exports. Despite this, economists believe the official GDP growth estimate of 0.1% for the first quarter may not be revised down, with some predicting a possible upgrade to 2.5-4.5% for 2014. The NODX may not give the whole picture of external demand, and re-exports have provided a "cushion" to overall export growth.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) for March were weaker than expected, but it doesn't necessarily mean the official estimate for the first quarter's economic growth will be adjusted down further - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: 'KOP in due diligence on Prudential Tower'
summary: KOP, a private equity group, is conducting due diligence on a potential purchase of Keppel Reit's majority stake in Prudential Tower, valued at nearly $520 million. The pricing is estimated to be around $2,340 per square foot of net lettable area, comparable to the sale price of Capital Square in 2011. The asset is fully let, making it an optimal stage for sale, and analysts expect the deal size to be within expectations given the relatively large quantum involved.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust to slash performance fees
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has reduced its performance fees by up to 50% effective immediately. The trust's manager, in response to unitholder feedback, lowered its Tier 2 performance fee from 15% to 5%, cutting the fees by about half. This change aims to prevent a significant drop in Distribution Per Unit (DPU). The revision is a result of the trust's unique method of pegging performance fees to its share price, which was criticized for its subjective nature.

site_title: Value hunters move from developed to emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets, such as Indonesia, India, and Brazil, are making a comeback after an intense sell-down in 2013, with investors seeking value and lower earnings multiples. However, risks remain, including political instability, current account deficits, and credit growth problems. Despite this, analysts, such as Russ Koesterich of BlackRock and Peter Sartori of Nikko AM, say emerging markets offer compelling long-term value and are outperforming developed markets. Notable outperformers include Thailand and China, which have risen 8% this year, while the US and Japan are in negative territory.

site_title: Ezion raising $194m from share placement
summary: Ezion Holdings, a liftboat developer and offshore logistics support service provider, has raised $194 million from a share placement by two companies linked to Malaysian tycoon Quek Leng Chan. Asia Fountain Investment Company Limited and GuoLine Capital Limited are subscribing for a combined 7.7% stake in Ezion, with the price representing an 8.9% discount to the closing price on April 15. The company plans to use the funds to buy offshore and marine assets and balance its capital structure, allowing it to continue growing without raising additional equity for at least the next 12 months.

site_title: Keppel Corp posts 5.1% drop in Q1 net profit
summary: Keppel Corp reported a 5.1% drop in Q1 net profit to $338.7 million, down from $357 million last year. Excluding one-off gains, the group's net profit was largely in line with last year. Revenue grew 8.6% to $2.99 billion, driven by higher revenue recognition from offshore & marine projects. The O&M business generated the largest profit share, followed by property and infrastructure divisions. The group's CEO attributed the growth to global energy demand and stable oil prices, despite slower E&P spending growth in 2014.

site_title: Mercantile relevance
summary: The Singapore Repertory Theatre (SRT) presents "The Merchant of Venice" for a full month in Shakespeare in the Park, attracting an expected 30,000 attendees. The production, directed by Bruce Guthrie, is a physical and visual spectacle, combining movement, design, music, and text. The play, set in a contemporary context, explores the theme of power and its effects on individuals, particularly Shylock's greed and sense of betrayal. The show features a diverse creative team, including Tony and Olivier award-winners, and is performed at Fort Canning from 7.30pm daily, with tickets starting from $45.

site_title: Wealth of art not to be sniffed at
summary: A snuff bottle, once exclusive to Chinese emperors and nobles, has gained recognition as a collectible in the Asian art market. The value of snuff bottles is mainly aesthetic, with appreciation based on individual taste rather than antique qualities. Victor Mun, a collector, notes that Westerners were the first to appreciate the delicate art of snuff bottles, with many now held in Western collections. The art form originated during the Qing dynasty and became more "democratic" as artisans shared their skills with the general Chinese market. Today, snuff bottles are valued for their cultural, historical, and artistic significance, with prices determined by factors such as craftsmanship, materials, and rarity.

site_title: S Korean ferry carrying 462 sinks
summary: A South Korean ferry, Sewol, carrying 462 people, including 174 confirmed rescued and 4 confirmed dead, sank off the country's south-west coast, with over 280 missing. The cause of the disaster was unclear, and officials admitted to a miscalculation in the initial rescue figures, leading to a potentially major disaster. Most on board were children and teachers on a field trip to Jeju island. The ferry capsized in calm conditions, with rescuers using life vests, helicopters, and boats to try to save those on board.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: US and Japanese markets are in negative territory in 2014, while emerging markets like China are seeing growth. China's Q1 GDP grew 7.4%, exceeding expectations. StarHub has started charging for its 4G service, and Singapore remains the most attractive destination for foreign direct investment. Ezion Holdings is raising $194m, and Indonesia may ease monetary policy in 2015. Yahoo reported better-than-expected Q1 results, and US industrial production rose 0.7% in March.

site_title: China Southern may report Q1 loss
summary: China Southern Airlines Co, the nation's third-largest carrier, is expected to report a loss of 300-350 million yuan (S$60 million) in the first quarter, down from a 57 million yuan profit last year, due to weaker yuan causing foreign-exchange losses. A slowing Chinese economy and increased foreign-currency debt costs also contribute to the estimated loss. The airline's shares have slid 18% this year, with the Shanghai-listed stock dropping 7.3% in 2014.

site_title: Obama can ward off potential N-E Asia crisis
summary: US President Barack Obama's upcoming visit to North-east Asian nations may help ward off a potential crisis between Japan, China, and South Korea. A recent briefing by former Japanese deputy foreign minister Hitoshi Tanaka revealed that 50% of South Korean audience members expected conflict between Japan and China in the future. The US can play a key role in calming tensions, and Obama's visit offers a chance for him to intervene and prevent a calamity, especially by addressing Japan's aggressive nationalism and the US's defense commitments.

site_title: Singapore is most attractive destination for FDI in region
summary: Singapore ranked first in the Asia Pacific Investment Climate Index for 2014, maintaining its top spot for the past two years despite tightening its foreign manpower policy and financial barriers to entry for foreign labor. The Republic remained the most attractive destination for foreign direct investment in the region, with New Zealand and Hong Kong taking the second and third spots.

site_title: Asia fund managers step closer to offering cross-border funds
summary: Asian fund managers are closer to offering cross-border funds with six nations releasing a joint consultation paper on the Asia Region Funds Passport (ARFP) rules. The ARFP will allow fund managers from member economies to offer funds in other member economies under a streamlined authorisation process. The proposal aims to simplify the process for fund managers operating in a member economy to expand their offerings across borders. Implementation is expected to pave the way for increased investment and financial cooperation in the region.

site_title: CapitaLand, CMA soar on delisting offer for latter
summary: CapitaLand and its subsidiary CapitaMalls Asia (CMA) surged after the parent company announced a $3.06-billion delisting offer for CMA. CMA shares rose 21% to a 52-week high, while CapitaLand shares jumped 6.5%. Analysts deem the offer price as fair, but minority shareholders may feel it's insufficient. The delisting is seen as a positive move for CapitaLand, allowing it to leverage CMA's retail expertise and pursue integrated projects, but may impact CMA's minority shareholders.

site_title: StarHub first to announce end to free 4G promotion
summary: StarHub becomes the first telco to end its free 4G promotion, charging $2.14 per month from June. Existing users can opt out by responding to an SMS notification. Other telcos, SingTel and M1, are reviewing their charges, with SingTel citing a "usual price" of $10.70 per month and M1's promotional rate set to end on December 31, 2014. The move follows the upgrade of M1's nationwide 4G network and SingTel's plan to enhance mobile data experience.

site_title: CapitaLand acquiring another 80% stake in CBKH
summary: CapitaLand is acquiring an 80% stake in CapitaLand (Beijing) Kai Heng Holdings Pte Ltd (CBKH) from a China development fund for $45 million. CBKH, a Beijing residential development site, will become a fully owned subsidiary of CapitaLand after the transaction. This acquisition comes after CapitaLand's $3.06 billion delisting offer for CapitaMalls Asia.

site_title: Pteris director explains call for EGM on RTO deal
summary: Pteris Global director Winston Tan has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to review the company's proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal, citing concerns over the removal of a promised profit guarantee. Tan believes his new team can push for better terms and prepare alternatives, and proposes reviving Pteris' old subcontractor business model and re-hiring past management personnel if his ouster proves successful. Shareholders will vote on Tan's proposal at the EGM next Friday.

site_title: Air Arabia to begin flights from UAE sheikdom on May 6
summary: Air Arabia, the only listed airline in the UAE, will begin flights from Ras Al Khaimah on May 6, offering eight routes from the emirate. The airline secured the status of official carrier from aviation officials in February after local carrier RAK Airways suspended operations due to tough market conditions. Air Arabia will operate two Airbus A320 jets from the new hub, linking it with Cairo, Jeddah, Muscat, Islamabad, Lahore, Peshawar, Dhaka, and potentially Kolkata. The move aims to tap into Ras Al Khaimah's growing tourism potential.

site_title: Cambridge trust's Q1 DPU rises to 1.251¢
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) reported a Q1 distribution per unit of 1.251 cents, a 1.4% increase from the previous year, driven by a 3.3% increase in distributable income to $15.6 million. However, turnover and net property income fell 5.1% and 11.1% respectively due to divestments and increased "other property expenses". The trust expects to refinance its $50 million debt ahead of maturity and plans to convert some properties to multi-tenancy.

site_title: Accor to manage Royal's hotel on Sentosa
summary: Royal Group has appointed hotel operator Accor to manage its Sentosa hotel under the Sofitel brand, the group's second Sofitel in its portfolio. The hotel, undergoing a $20 million renovation, will be unveiled as Sofitel Singapore Sentosa Resort & Spa in Q3 2025. Existing staff will be trained to meet Sofitel's standards, and the resort will feature 215 keys, including suites and villas. This marks the second Sofitel in Royal Group's portfolio, following the Sofitel So Singapore, expected to open at the end of May.

site_title: Duty bound to help abandoned sailors
summary: The International Labour Organization (ILO) has agreed on amendments to the Maritime Labour Convention, 2006, to protect abandoned seafarers and provide financial security for compensation in cases of death or long-term disability due to occupational injury or hazard. The amendments, which were developed by the ILO and the International Maritime Organization (IMO), establish mandatory requirements for shipowners to have financial security to cover abandonment, as well as death or long-term disability of seafarers. The new provisions will require ships to carry certificates or documents to establish financial security, and failure to provide this protection may result in detention in a port.

site_title: SIA's March passenger load factor fall to 75%
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger load factor fell to 75% in March, a 4.3 percentage point decline, due to a 5.4% year-on-year decrease in systemwide passenger carriage and a 3.8% decrease in passengers carried. The airline attributed the decline to Easter demand shifts and soft demand to Bangkok. SIA Cargo's load factor inched up 0.8 percentage points to 68% despite a 2% decline in cargo traffic. The airline warned that yields will continue to be impacted by efforts to boost loads in a challenging operating environment.

site_title: China Q1 growth slows but analysts unfazed
summary: China's economy grew 7.4% in the first quarter, the slowest pace since 2012, but still above analysts' expectations of 7.3%. The slowdown is attributed to weak external demand, a struggling real estate market, and structural changes. Despite this, analysts expect further weakness, with some predicting GDP growth could slow to 7.1% by the end of the year. Officials attribute the slowdown to a growth model transformation, allowing for structural reforms, and policymakers appear comfortable with the current pace of growth, ruling out further significant measures to support growth.

site_title: QT Vascular plans to raise $55m in Catalist IPO
summary: QT Vascular plans to raise $55 million in an initial public offering (IPO) on Catalist, valuing the company at $211.6 million. The offer includes 196.4 million new shares priced at 28 cents each. The company expects net proceeds of $50.3 million, with $30.3 million for general working capital, $15 million for product development, and $5 million for commercial expansion. QT Vascular posted a net loss of $27.9 million for the nine months ended September 2013 and expects sales to pick up in the coming years.

site_title: SIA goes full throttle with Formula 1
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has signed a two-year deal to become the title sponsor of the Singapore Grand Prix, taking over from SingTel. The partnership is expected to benefit both SIA and the local tourism scene, with the airline seeking to ride the popularity of the iconic event. The deal is seen as a strategic move to boost tourism and provide a global brand presence for SIA. The partnership is also expected to generate around $150 million in incremental tourism receipts per year.

site_title: Ascott makes foray into Tokyo
summary: Ascott, a subsidiary of Capitaland, has signed a master lease agreement with Mitsubishi Estate Company to provide serviced apartments in Tokyo's prime commercial centre, Ascott Marunouchi Tokyo. The 129-unit development is set to open in 2017, ahead of the 2020 Olympics, which is expected to have an economic impact of about 3 trillion yen (S$36.9 billion) on Japan's GDP. The move aims to capitalize on Japan's recovering economy and growing demand for quality accommodation, as the country attracts multinational companies and investors.

site_title: High speeds, high stakes
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to introduce changes to its securities trading fees regime in June, aiming to boost liquidity with lower fees and new discounts and rebates for market makers and liquidity providers. However, the impact of high-frequency trading on the market is uncertain, with concerns about policing new players and preventing unfair practices. SGX has implemented rules to address these issues, but the effectiveness of regulation in a fast-adapting industry remains a challenge.

images.alt_text: Tough call: The challenge for the exchange is to allow players to make money by exploiting market inefficiencies but to do so without damaging the integrity of the market or hurting retail players. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Quek Leng Chan boost for Ezion
summary: Veteran Malaysian businessman Quek Leng Chan has become Ezion Holdings' second top shareholder, boosting the company's confidence. Chan's connections in the oil and gas sector, particularly with Petronas, have helped Ezion secure a higher charter rate for a liftboat contract. He also owns stakes in other Malaysian-listed firms. Ezion's CEO Chew Thiam Keng, who owns 50% of the company, welcomed Chan's investment, which will give him a 7.7% interest in the firm, second only to Chew's holdings.

site_title: Asia airlines hedging major part of fuel use
summary: Asian airlines are hedging a significant portion of their jet fuel usage for 2014, expecting prices to remain firm due to the Ukraine crisis and geopolitical tensions. Top airlines such as Japan Airlines, ANA Holdings, and Korean Air are hedging around 40-45% of their fuel consumption, aiming to reduce the risk of volatile and rising fuel costs. Despite sufficient jet fuel supply in Asia, airlines are unlikely to benefit from lower prices, with jet fuel prices averaging $121.20 a barrel this year compared to $126.62 last year.
