summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has signed a 30-year agreement to manage the Quanzhou shipyard in Fujian province, China. The shipyard, owned by Titan Petrochemicals Group, will have four dry docks and capabilities for ship repair, conversion, and offshore rig construction. The agreement is conditional on Titan's financial restructuring and resumption of trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Keppel O&M sees growing demand for high-specification rigs and production vessels in China, driven by increasing domestic energy demands and China's dependence on oil-and-gas imports.

site_title: Noir outing delves into a twisted mind
summary: Denis Villeneuve's film "Enemy" is a mind-bending psychological thriller that explores the depths of a man's shattered psyche. Based on the novel "The Double" by Jose Saramago, the movie follows college professor Adam Bell (Jake Gyllenhaal) as he becomes obsessed with a lookalike, Anthony St Clair, and delves into the darker aspects of his own mind. The film's deliberate pace, gloomy atmosphere, and recurring themes of spiders and voyeurism make it a challenging but thought-provoking watch. Villeneuve's unconventional style and Gyllenhaal's performance make for a complex and unsettling cinematic experience.

site_title: Romance of shape-note music
summary: American musicologist Tim Eriksen discusses the lesser-known folk music of the Appalachian mountains, characterized by shape-note music, which dates back to the 1600s. This social singing tradition, often sung a cappella, is a living legacy in the region, with influences from European, African, and Native American cultures. Eriksen, who has studied music in India, Europe, and the US, will perform with Trio de Pumpkintown at The Esplanade's Sacred Music Festival in Singapore, showcasing unique songs like Wayfaring Stranger and Amazing Grace.

site_title: Programming flaw calls for new passwords, experts say
summary: A programming flaw in the Heartbleed coding issue has forced numerous websites to make security fixes, exposing sensitive consumer information. Experts disagree on whether users should change their passwords immediately or wait for sites to address the issue. Changing passwords now may make them vulnerable, but experts warn that not changing them could lead to stolen personal information. Users should consider changing their passwords to protect their information, but may need to pick a new password once the issue is fixed.

site_title: UK's Manchester airport to start flights to HK
summary: Manchester Airport in northwest England will begin direct flights to Hong Kong in December, operated by Cathay Pacific, marking the first time British passengers can travel directly to China on a scheduled service from outside London. This move is seen as a response to Heathrow's near-full capacity and competition for lucrative routes to emerging markets. Manchester Airport Group, which owns the airport, is also in talks with Air China and Hainan Airline to open more routes to China, including a potential direct route to Beijing.

site_title: Savouring off-the-beaten-track wines
summary: Wine connoisseurs are discovering the richness of Rhone wines, which are often overlooked in favor of Burgundy. Chateau Rayas' Pignan 2003, a Grenache-based wine, is an excellent example, offering a youthful and complex taste profile at an affordable price. In contrast, Egon Muller-Scharzhofberger's 1999 Riesling Spaetlese is a German white wine that pairs well with spicy dishes like pepper crabs. Meanwhile, a magnum of Domaine Leflaive's 1988 Puligny-Montrachet 1er Cru Clavoillon is a rare find, offering a rich and honeyed flavor. Lastly, Chateau Haut Brion's 2002 is a classic Bordeaux wine that showcases elegance and refinement, despite a less-than-stellar vintage.

site_title: GIC to buy Tokyo property for 134b yen
summary: Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd to purchase Tokyo property, Meguro Gajoen, for 134 billion yen (S$1.6 billion), marking the highest price since Japan's real estate market recovery. The 96 billion yen initial asking price was reduced from Lone Star Funds, with GIC chosen from three final bidders. The property, comprising office towers, is home to Amazon's Japanese unit.

site_title: American Airlines says bad weather hurt Q1 results
summary: American Airlines reported Q1 results were hurt by bad weather, with over 34,000 flight cancellations reducing quarterly revenue by $115 million and operating profit by $60 million. The carrier cut its operating margin forecast to 5-7% and eliminated free checked bags for full-priced economy tickets. Five US carriers collectively cancelled 78,000 flights due to winter storms, affecting passenger revenue per available seat mile.

site_title: KOP buys majority stake in Victory Hill Exhibitions
summary: KOP Group, a Singapore-based company, has acquired a majority stake in US-based exhibition production and distribution company Victory Hill Exhibitions. The acquisition aims to bring Marvel's The AVENGERS S.T.A.T.I.O.N exhibition to Asia, following its launch in New York on May 23. The exhibition combines education and entertainment, featuring original movie props and interactive demonstrations. KOP Group plans to expand the exhibition to 12 other US cities and Canada, with the goal of creating a robust portfolio of contemporary lifestyle assets globally.

site_title: New signals revive confidence in MH370 search
summary: Australian officials detected two new "ping" signals from the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, boosting confidence in the search, but caution remains as the task is enormous. The signals, possibly from the plane's black box recorders, bring to four the number of overall "pings" detected in recent days. The search area is being narrowed down, and an autonomous underwater vehicle is being prepared to search the sea floor, but the batteries in the black box recorders are nearing the end of their 30-day expected life, making swift location efforts critical.

site_title: Vanke keen on investing in China SOEs' property units
summary: China Vanke Co Ltd, the country's largest listed developer, is interested in investing in state-owned enterprise (SOE) property units as Beijing opens up state-dominated industries to private capital. Vanke president Yu Liang stated that the company will make "big moves" in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) and equity investments. This comes after China's decision to privatize its bloated state-owned sector, with Vanke's total overseas investment expected to not exceed 10% of its overall investment over the next five years.

site_title: Correction
summary: A correction was issued regarding an article from April 5, 2014, stating that Innopac Holdings CEO Wong Chin-Yong had a previous run-in with the Commercial Affairs Department. However, Wong has clarified that he has no involvement with the department or the 2001 Link Islands case, and the original report was incorrect. The correction aims to correct this error.

site_title: Goods vehicle COE premium falls
summary: The premium for a commercial vehicle certificate of entitlement (COE) for Category C goods vehicles fell significantly, dropping $4,388 to $49,503, amid the government's decision to raise the COE bonus under the Enhanced Early Turnover Scheme. Passenger car COE premiums remained stable. Meanwhile, luxury car demand remained strong despite high COE premiums, with Mercedes-Benz models still receiving good orders. Dealers attribute this to "pent-up demand from wealthy people" and the limited COE quota.

site_title: Artivision surges after rights issue
summary: Artivision Technologies saw its shares surge 72% to 4.8 cents after completing a rights issue, which led to Ching Chiat Kwong emerging as a substantial shareholder. The two-for-five rights issue saw Mr. Kwong take up 17 million shares and 15.2 million unsubscribed shares of Algotech, increasing his stake to over 76 million shares, or 8.6% of the company. This comes after Mr. Kwong invested $5 million in Artivision via a convertible loan and purchased shares in the open market.

site_title: Greece prepares 500m euros of assets for sale
summary: Greece is preparing to sell a 500m euro property portfolio, including city buildings, homes, and development land, to investors by the end of 2014. The portfolio is valued at at least 350m euros and is seen as an opportunity for investors amid a growing economic recovery. The sale is part of a 240 billion euro bailout package and aims to raise 11 billion euros by 2016, with the Athens Stock Exchange General Index having jumped 175% since its 22-year low in June 2012.

site_title: Forestry a better investment: JES
summary: JES International, a Chinese shipbuilding firm, has shifted its investment focus from mining to forestry, citing a better deal. The company is acquiring a 51% stake in Scibois Co Limited, a timber extraction firm in the Democratic Republic of Congo, for up to $65 million. This move comes after JES put on hold its investment in a Chinese mining firm, Mineriver, due to the latter's limited exploration rights and operational challenges. JES aims to diversify its income streams and has agreed to provide management control and a profit guarantee for Scibois.

site_title: Barclays S'pore to move more staff to CBD
summary: Barclays is relocating 300 employees from its Tampines office to Marina Bay Financial Centre in Singapore by July, citing cost-cutting measures. The move follows a similar relocation of 200 employees earlier this year, as the bank aims to consolidate operations and boost profitability. Monthly rents at Marina Bay Financial Centre are now S$11 to S$12 per square foot, compared to S$10 to S$11 per square foot at the Tampines location, potentially resulting in cost savings for the bank.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's M1 is close to reaching 10,000 subscribers to cross-carry exclusive content, including BPL and World Cup matches. Temasek Holdings launched a special-purpose vehicle to reach a broader investor base. ICBC Singapore saw a surge in yuan clearing volumes, planning to roll out yuan futures products. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong mentioned Jurong East as a "very attractive" option for the High Speed Rail terminal. Chinese firm JES switched from mining to forestry for better deals.

site_title: Ezion in logistics tie-up with AusGroup
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore marine firm, has entered into a logistics tie-up with AusGroup, a company in Australia's resources and marine sectors. The deal, valued at $78 million, involves AusGroup's share placement and grant of share options to Ezion. The partnership aims to expand AusGroup's marine services sector and revitalize the company's prospects, which had faced losses and concerns over high cash burn rates. Ezion, which had previously failed to acquire a logistics supply chain business in Australia, sees the deal as a second attempt to make inroads in the market.

site_title: PDI-P claims victory in Indonesian polls
summary: The Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P) claimed victory in the parliamentary elections, with 19.8% of the vote, ahead of Golkar and Gerindra. Presidential candidate Joko Widodo may need to form a coalition to stay in the race, as he falls short of the 20% vote threshold needed to stand alone. Widodo had led opinion polls for president, but the results suggest a fragmented, multi-party coalition. The country's five Islamic-based national parties combined for 32% of the vote, slightly better than in the last election.

site_title: 14th floor of Samsung Hub sold for $3,030 psf
summary: The 14th floor of Samsung Hub, a 13,110 sq ft strata area, has been sold to a mainland Chinese company for $39.7 million or $3,030 psf. Arch Capital Management, a Hong Kong-based private equity firm, sold the space, which is leased until year-end to a law firm, to exit its 999-year leasehold office tower. The sale price is higher than the previous full-floor sale in the building, which involved the 16th floor in 2012, and suggests a moderate pace of office price growth at Samsung Hub.

site_title: Indonesia is a key market for many S'pore-listed firms
summary: Singapore-listed firms have a significant presence in Indonesia, with 80 companies reporting revenues from the country, accounting for 10% of listed stocks. Over a quarter of these companies name Indonesia as their largest revenue source. Companies like Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Bumitama Agri have a substantial market capitalization and year-to-date returns, with SGX offering Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) to track Indonesia stocks.

site_title: OCBC sells its first Basel III-compliant bond
summary: OCBC Bank issued its first Basel III-compliant bond, a US$1 billion 10-year fixed-rate subordinated note, under its US$10 billion global medium-term note programme. The issuance is expected to improve its total capital adequacy ratio by about 0.8 percentage point, enhancing its capital position and capturing growth opportunities. The bond features a loss-absorbing feature, aligning with Basel III rules. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, with orders reaching US$4.3 billion, with investors from Asia, the US, and Europe participating.

site_title: Architect's Pritzker prize puts new shine on his project
summary: Japanese architect Shigeru Ban's Pritzker Prize has boosted interest in his only completed New York project, the Metal Shutter Houses in Manhattan. Since winning the award, the US$7 million duplex has seen a surge in inquiries, with prices increasing by 20% to US$8.5 million. The building's unique design, featuring swooping lines and retractable walls, has made it a sought-after property among high-net-worth individuals. The Pritzker win has also led to increased interest in other projects, with developers seeking to hire Ban's firm to create luxury properties.

site_title: Resale condos mark higher prices, volumes in March
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore increased 0.2% in March, led by the Rest of Central Region, with 451 transactions registered - the highest resale volume since October. However, market watchers caution that it's too early to cheer as the market remains soft. Rental prices also declined 0.9% month-on-month, with leasing competition expected to heat up as newly completed private homes are put up for rent. Experts note that the improved numbers merely reflect a stabilizing market and that buyers' sentiments are still cautious.

site_title: Lufthansa to turn around Germanwings unit
summary: Lufthansa aims to turn around its Germanwings unit by 2015, with plans to break even. The airline has shifted large parts of its European network to Germanwings, shifting away from short-haul routes outside main hubs. This move is an attempt to compete with low-cost carriers like Easyjet and Ryanair, which have focused on service and lower fares. By expanding Germanwings, Lufthansa aims to increase profitability and avoid further losses on short-haul routes.

site_title: Malaysia's household debt is no big worry
summary: Malaysia's household debt, which reached 86.8% of GDP in 2013, has eased to its slowest pace since 2010 due to a sharp fall in nominal GDP growth. Despite the high absolute quantum, growth in household borrowings declined, and the central bank has more powers to deal with runaway debt. The Financial Services Act has also helped stem the rise in personal loans, and the quality of household loans remains sound. Concerns about Malaysia's household debt are overblown, and macro-prudential measures are working to address the issue.

site_title: Temasek launches special-purpose vehicle
summary: Temasek Holdings has launched Astrea II, a special-purpose vehicle (SPV) to diversify its investments and reach a broader base of investors. The co-investment vehicle has 36 private equity funds and Temasek is the largest investor at 38%. ARDIAN, formerly AXA Private Equity, is one of the six co-investors. A retail bond offering is also planned in the near future, allowing investors to access the diversified holdings. This move aims to increase transparency and accessibility to Temasek's investments.

site_title: Is Cofco deal short-changing Noble shareholders?
summary: Noble Group sold a 51% stake in its agricultural business to Cofco Corp for $1.5 billion, valuing the business at $3.22 billion. The deal is 1.15 times the 2014 book value of Noble's agricultural business. This has fueled Noble's share price by over 20% since the start of the year, with shares rising 10% in the two days following the announcement. However, some shareholders are questioning whether Noble could have held out for a better deal, citing a tender offer from Temasek Holdings for rival Olam at 1.4 times the book value.

site_title: Far East-Sekisui JV tops bids for Woodlands office site
summary: A joint venture between Far East Organization and Sekisui House won a state tender for a Woodlands office site with a top bid of nearly $634 million, or $906.29 per square foot. The project will feature two 16-storey office towers with strata units for sale and lease, as well as retail space. The top bid was 17.6% above the lowest bid, with the project expected to launch towards the end of the year or early next year.

site_title: IP owners can use patents as collateral for bank loans soon
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (IPOS) has launched a $100 million scheme that allows businesses to use patents as collateral for bank loans. The scheme, which shares the risk between the government and banks, aims to encourage the acceptance of intangible assets as collateral. Three banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - are currently participating in the scheme, with potentially more to follow. The scheme offers interest rates ranging from 3.5-7.5% and loan tenors of 1-6 years. The goal is to support knowledge-based companies and encourage them to grow both locally and overseas.

site_title: Royal Caribbean Cruises gets new COO
summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises has appointed Adam Goldstein as its new president and chief operating officer, succeeding him as head of the company's largest cruise line, Royal Caribbean International. Goldstein, who has spent 25 years with the company, will oversee various departments including human resources, IT, and commercial development. He begins his new role immediately and will assist in the transition for the Royal Caribbean International line, which is currently searching for a new leader. Goldstein's appointment aims to leverage his broad worldview and strategic insights to drive the company's growth and global leadership.

site_title: When bond funds think outside the box
summary: Non-traditional bond funds, which can invest in any type of debt instrument, have seen a significant rise in popularity among investors seeking higher yields. Assets in these funds increased 80% last year to $123 billion, but their average returns of 0.3% and 1.1% in the first quarter of 2014 were relatively low. Managers warn that unconstrained funds may take on too much risk, adding that investors should use the freedom wisely. To mitigate risks, investors should inspect the contents of the fund, understand the organization behind it, and consider operating costs.

site_title: S-EA offers huge opportunities for yacht industry
summary: A new study has identified South-east Asia as a lucrative market for the yachting industry, with 4,690 ultra-wealthy individuals worth US$625 billion. The region's 20,000 strong potential clients, including spouses and children, presents opportunities for growth. However, the industry faces challenges, including a low 7% of luxury asset spending on yachts, a high financial threshold for purchases, and lower liquidity among ultra-high net worth individuals in the region.

site_title: PM Lee: Jurong East a 'very attractive' option
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Jurong East is a "very attractive" option for the country's High Speed Rail (HSR) station linking Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. The government is studying the site alongside Tuas West and the city centre. Malaysia has chosen Bandar Malaysia near Sungai Besi as its terminal station. The 320km rail project aims to reduce travel time to 90 minutes and is set to be completed by 2020. However, key areas such as financing models and governance need to be worked out, which will test the teams of both countries.

site_title: Internet needs global stakeholder oversight
summary: The US plans to transfer control of key Internet domain name functions to ICANN, a global organization, as part of a transition from US government oversight. The move has sparked protests and concerns that authoritarian governments may take control, but experts argue that this could actually help prevent government overreach and promote human rights. A global multistakeholder governance framework is proposed to ensure the Internet remains free and vibrant, with the US playing a key role in shaping this framework at the upcoming Net Mundial meeting.

site_title: Boom in Spanish bonds, stocks shows market lacks reality
summary: Spanish government bond yields have fallen from 7.6% in 2012 to 3.2%, with a 46% capital gain. The IBEX 35 stock index has jumped 79%, with some stocks experiencing even higher growth. Despite this, economic reality in Spain remains bleak, with continued pensioner and jobless protests. A recent initial public offering saw the stock fall sharply on its debut, but its market capitalisation remained high. The situation suggests that foreign investors are out of touch with Spain's economic reality, potentially threatening the country's financial stability.

site_title: DBS charts steady course in transaction banking
summary: DBS Group has become a major competitor in Asian trade financing, growing its transaction banking business by 5% in 2013. The bank has focused on cherry-picking clients, particularly multinational companies and suppliers, and has a trade-loan book of around $60 billion. Despite concerns over China's economic risks, DBS is confident in its risk management and has a strong balance sheet. The bank expects to boost its trade-loan book further with Asian trade growth expected to reach $580 billion this year, and is targeting mid-teens profit growth.

site_title: SPH Reit's Q2 DPU of 1.39 cts beats forecast
summary: SPH Reit achieved a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.39 cents for Q2, beating its forecast by 4.5%. Income distributable to unitholders was $34.9 million, surpassing the forecast by 5.2%. The Reit's net property income increased 4.6% to $38.8 million and gross revenues rose 1.4% to $51 million. The two retail malls, Paragon and Clementi Mall, enjoyed healthy rental reversions of 13.6% and 5.1%, respectively.

site_title: ICBC S'pore sees jump in yuan clearing volumes
summary: ICBC Singapore has seen a significant increase in yuan clearing volumes, reaching 6.9 trillion yuan (S$1.4 trillion) in the first quarter of 2014, a 2.7 times growth from the previous year. The bank plans to roll out yuan futures products, further solidifying Singapore's status as an offshore yuan hub. Daily clearing volumes have risen to nearly 300 billion yuan from the initial two billion yuan, driven by increased trade finance and lending activities. This growth is expected to boost Singapore's economy and position it as a key player in the global yuan market.

site_title: Singapore port scores world first with bunkering mandate
summary: Singapore has become the world's first port to mandate the use of a mass flow metering (MFM) system for bunkering, aiming to eliminate malpractices and increase efficiency. The system, which measures fuel oil automatically, will be mandatory for all bunker suppliers starting January 1, 2017. Existing bunker tankers must be fitted with the system by December 31, 2016, and new tankers applying for harbour craft licenses after December 31, 2014 will also be required. The move aims to enhance transparency and productivity in the industry.

site_title: Darco requests resumption of share trading
summary: Darco Water Technologies, a Singapore-listed water treatment specialist, has requested the resumption of trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after its shares were suspended in 2012. The company has taken steps to address its financial issues, including appointing a chief financial officer and internal auditor. Darco's Audit Committee and board believe the company can continue to operate as a going concern for at least the next 12 months, with a positive net asset and working capital position. The request for trading resumption has received no objections from SGX.

site_title: Brazil falls behind in airport overhaul for World Cup
summary: Brazil's World Cup host cities risk overcrowding and confusion due to construction delays on new airport terminals, with only temporary canvas terminals set to be used in some cities. Despite the tight timelines, officials are preparing alternatives and assessing contingency plans, as the influx of over 600,000 visitors poses a significant challenge. The delays have raised concerns about the tournament's lasting investments, with critics arguing that the World Cup will leave few benefits for ordinary Brazilians.

site_title: Pacific Radiance JV to tap Aussie oil & gas industry
summary: Pacific Radiance is forming a joint venture with Westsea Marine to tap the Australian oil and gas industry. The new company, Westsea Radiance, will engage in ship ownership and offshore marine services, with plans to acquire two deepwater platform supply vessels. The investment is funded through internal resources, with no expected impact on Pacific Radiance's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Loss-making CCM to raise up to $143.5m
summary: CCM Group, a loss-making construction company, plans to raise up to $143.5 million through an 8-for-1 rights issue and bonus issue to address working capital and invest in overseas properties. The company has a net loss of $22.4 million for FY2013 and will allocate $10.8 million for property development investments. Chan Heng Fai and Hengfai Business Development will subscribe for their full entitlement of rights shares, with an irrevocable undertaking to pay for excess shares if the issue does not work out.

site_title: Lifetime achievement award for SSA chief
summary: Singapore Shipping Association president Patrick Phoon received the 2014 Seatrade Lifetime Achievement Award for his 40-year maritime career. Phoon, who has served the SSA for 23 years, has been a major contributor to the development of the maritime community in Singapore and Asia. He has held various positions, including deputy managing director of Evergreen Shipping Agency and director of the RTW Group of Companies. The award recognizes his dedication and achievements in the shipping sector.

site_title: Major shareholder makes exit offer for Gems TV
summary: A major shareholder, Mounting Holdings, is making an offer of 0.408 cents per share to delist suspended Gems TV Holdings. The offer matches the company's net tangible asset (NTA) of 0.324 US cents per share as of March 31, 2014, valuing the company at approximately $4.2 million. This comes a month after a planned reverse takeover fell through.

site_title: JES Int'l switches from mines to forestry
summary: JES International, a Chinese shipbuilder, is acquiring a 51% stake in Scibois Co Limited, a timber extraction firm in Africa, for up to $65 million. This move is part of the company's efforts to diversify its business and tap into the forestry industry. The acquisition is expected to be worth over $3 billion and will provide JES with a fresh source of income. The company is putting its investment in Mineriver on hold pending further negotiations.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: ST Aerospace recorded $460 million in new orders for Q1, with airframe maintenance and modification work, component processing, and engine washes. Tritech Group is exploring acquisitions, investments, and fund-raising options for its water business, amid a 47 million-share trading increase. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Global 'recovery is strengthening', says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has released a report stating that global economic recovery is strengthening, with forecasted world growth of 3.6% this year and 3.9% next year. This echoes the World Bank's recent report, expressing guarded optimism that the global economy can navigate monetary tapering in the US and other growth threats. The IMF's chief economist, Olivier Blanchard, described the recovery as "strengthening" and attributed the growth to a broader economic expansion.

site_title: CCM completes deal for 5 Texas land parcels
summary: CCM Group, a construction firm, has completed the acquisition of five out of seven parcels in a 55-hectare development in Texas. The company is confident of securing the remaining two land parcels and plans to seek bank financing for the entire project once they are secured. Following approval from local authorities, CCM will sub-divide the land into 545 lots. The acquisition is a significant step forward for the company, with the project expected to move forward once the remaining parcels are secured.

site_title: Asian airlines feel drag from weak cargo market
summary: Asian airlines saw a 2% drop in share values in March compared to February due to a weak cargo market. Despite this, global airline shares rose 13% year-over-year, outperforming the market. The International Air Transport Association attributed the improvement to rising demand and consolidation in the US, while passenger yields remained weak in other regions.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: DBS Group has established itself as a significant player in Asian trade financing, surpassing European banks in just five years. The bank's success comes as European banks focus on repairing their balance sheets and increasing fee income. Meanwhile, Singapore's port authority has scored a world first by issuing a bunkering mandate, aiming to reduce environmental impact.

site_title: HDB resale prices edge up, strong rebound in volume
summary: HDB resale prices edged up 0.3% in March, driven by a 0.5% increase in three-room units and 0.8% in four-room units, offsetting declines in larger flats. Transaction volumes surged 40% to 1,319 units, the highest monthly volume since October. Despite overall prices slipping 4.9% year-on-year, property consultants expect a rebound in resale activity as buyers return to the market.

site_title: Beijing office shortage fuels third-highest rents
summary: Beijing's office market is experiencing a significant shortage, driving up rents to the third-highest globally. Since 2008, office rents have doubled, with the average rent reaching 413 yuan (S$83) per square meter. Limited new supply, particularly from state-owned enterprises, has contributed to the scarcity. Corporations have rented 590,000 square meters of space annually, more than double the new workspace added, pushing rents higher. The vacancy rate is expected to remain around 5% due to limited supply, with a slight adjustment in the second quarter, according to real estate brokers.

site_title: Seeking silver linings in emerging markets
summary: Emerging-market equity portfolios suffered significant losses in the first quarter, with funds falling 0.6% and Asia-Pacific portfolios plummeting 2%. This decline was partly due to Russia's annexation of Crimea and concerns over Western sanctions and rising borrowing costs. However, some investors, such as those in the Ivy International Core Equity fund, are cautiously returning to emerging markets, drawn by undervalued stocks and lower price-to-earnings ratios. Despite the negative headlines, many believe that Russia's move will ultimately be viewed as a developed-world issue, rather than an emerging-market crisis.

site_title: Sembcorp expands wastewater treatment business to Hubei
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a joint venture agreement to build and operate an industrial wastewater treatment plant in Jingmen City, Hubei province, China. The project, valued at 98.7 million yuan, will be funded through a mix of equity and borrowings. Sembcorp will own 95% of the equity, with the remaining 5% held by the Duodao district government. The facility, with an initial capacity of 10,000 cubic meters per day, is expected to be completed in the first half of 2016 and provide wastewater treatment services to companies in the Jingmen Chemical Industrial Park for 30 years.

site_title: Talkmed, Sarine & Ezion: putting to rest the myth of non-performance
summary: Singapore's local stock market has been misunderstood as an underperformer due to its classification as a developed market in the MSCI Asia ex-Japan index. However, several "ten-baggers" have been found, with investors being able to find significant outperformers if they look hard enough. This challenges conventional wisdom that the market is unattractive for investors.

site_title: Molyneux scraps plan to buy Blumont shares
summary: Mining investor Alexander Molyneux dropped plans to buy a 5.2% stake in Blumont Group, citing no reason. The 135 million-share purchase, announced six months ago, was part of a plan to defend the resource firm's prospects after a massive share decline. Molyneux remains as a consultant and key adviser, but the deal is a fresh blow to the firm.

site_title: Good time still for equities despite some hurdles
summary: Investors can still consider equities despite current challenges, including Russia's foreign policy, China's bad debt issues, and monetary normalization. Despite a harsh US winter affecting data, the economic situation remains supportive for growth. The article maintains a constructive outlook for US and global economic growth this year, citing revenue/profit growth and ongoing valuation as key factors. However, monetary normalization is seen as a significant obstacle, and investors should be cautious in their equity investments.

site_title: FCT to acquire Changi City Point
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has entered into a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire Changi City Point mall for $305 million. The acquisition is expected to be distribution per unit (DPU)-accretive to FCT unitholders and will increase the trust's total assets by 14% to $2.4 billion. The mall, with a 97.8% occupancy rate, has a leasehold estate of 60 years and will expand FCT's suburban retail mall portfolio to six.

site_title: Midas wins deals worth 318m yuan
summary: Midas Holdings has secured contracts worth 318 million yuan (S$64.4 million) from CNR Tangshan Railway Vehicle Company for high-speed train car body components. This is the second time Midas has secured orders from CNR Tangshan, following a deal worth 167.5 million yuan in 2013. The contracts are expected to contribute positively to Midas' financial performance for the current financial year.

site_title: Consolidation seen in face of overcapacity
summary: Industry leaders in Singapore call for greater consolidation and collaboration among shipping companies, public and private sectors, to address overcapacity and other challenges. The world's container fleet has increased to 5,043 vessels at the end of 2013, with larger vessels further amplifying excess capacity. Consolidation and stronger alliances are seen as solutions to boost profitability and overcome issues such as talent shortages and environmental sustainability.

site_title: Some lessons from the MH370 mystery
summary: The search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370) has yielded some promising leads, including acoustic signals detected by Chinese and Australian ships. The signals are consistent with those emitted by the plane's black box flight recorders, which have a limited power duration of 30 days. However, despite extensive efforts by multiple countries, no concrete evidence of the plane's fate has been found. The incident highlights the importance of effective communication, multilingual crisis management, and robust aircraft security measures, including longer-lasting black box batteries and improved recording protocols.

site_title: Building, credit firms lead cashflow crunch
summary: Cashflow woes have returned to Singapore, with construction and credit firms the worst hit. The average time for companies to settle debts increased to 43 days, the longest since Q2 2012. Construction firms took 61 days to pay, up from 32 days, while credit firms took 78 days, up from 33 days. Experts attribute the slowdown to higher labour costs, a cooling property market, and a decrease in public sector construction demand. While the impact on the wider economy is uncertain, the slowdown in the property market is seen as a key factor.

site_title: Confidence in shipping sector picking up steam
summary: Shipping industry confidence has reached its highest level in almost six years, with an average confidence level of 6.5 in the latest Shipping Confidence Survey from Moore Stephens. Freight rates are expected to improve or remain stable over the next 12 months, while private equity funding is expected to have a major impact. This optimism was evident at the recent Asia Pacific Maritime event, with some respondents, such as offshore support vessel owners, expressing more positivity than those in the struggling container trades.

site_title: Government proposes changes to law to tackle Web piracy
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law proposes changes to the Copyright Act to better protect rights owners and internet users from web piracy. The proposed law allows rights owners to directly apply for a court injunction to block access to pirated material, bypassing the need for internet service providers to issue "take-down" notices. The changes aim to make the process more efficient and target those who clearly and blatantly infringe copyright, such as Pirate Bay and torrent sites. The public consultation on the proposed changes closes on April 21.

site_title: S'pore eyes more shipping sector capital issues on SGX
summary: Singapore aims to attract more shipping companies to its capital markets, despite Norway and the US dominating the sector. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore acknowledges a deficit in listings and is working with the Singapore Exchange to profile the exchange as a good listing destination. However, historical reasons and regulatory flexibility may hinder Singapore's efforts, with many shipping companies favoring established markets with experienced investors.

site_title: S'pore offers skills training for Iskandar Malaysia's needs
summary: Singapore has offered to provide skills training to meet the growing need for workers in Iskandar Malaysia, a joint project with Malaysia. Prime Ministers Lee Hsien Loong and Najib Razak welcomed talks on vocational training collaboration between agencies. The project aims to boost socio-economic development with a skilled labor force, with Singapore offering infrastructure, services, and industrial base to Iskandar Malaysia. The project also includes the development of a new tech park, creating jobs in high-tech industries and driving Iskandar Malaysia's growth.

site_title: Developing economies tipped to gain as global growth rises
summary: The World Bank has projected global growth to reach 3% this year, up from 2.4% last year, with developing economies in East Asia expected to continue growing at a steady pace. China is forecast to grow at 7.6% this year and 7.5% next year, while larger economies in ASEAN are expected to slow down. The report notes that the region has successfully navigated tighter global financial conditions and improving global trade, but warns that policy reforms are needed to maintain growth.

site_title: Hillview House site on the block again
summary: The former Hillview House site is back on the market with a freehold vacant plot asking $55 million, or $875 per square foot of potential gross floor area. The site, zoned for residential use, can be developed into a 10-storey condo project with about 83,630 sq ft maximum gross floor area. Located 730 meters from the Hillview MRT Station, the site offers unobstructed views of the surrounding landed housing area and nearby nature parks.

site_title: Big investors seek global standard for sustainability reporting
summary: Big investors, including Ceres and BlackRock, have submitted a proposal to the World Federation of Exchanges to adopt a global standard for sustainability reporting. The proposal aims to increase harmonization and disclosure of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) matters across stock exchanges. It includes specific recommendations for incorporating environmental and social disclosure requirements into listing rules for publicly traded companies. The move is seen as a step towards enabling investors to make more informed decisions and better value companies.

site_title: Poll: property pay packages differ in Asia
summary: Real estate professionals in Singapore saw a 9% salary increase, ahead of China's 7%, but lower than Malaysia's 11% and Hong Kong's 9.2%, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors and MacDonald & Company. The disparity in growth rates reflects different stages of market development in Asian markets. Despite this, Chinese professionals still have the highest average salary, while 62% of respondents are likely to change jobs due to underpayment or dissatisfaction with their companies. Economic activity is expected to increase across the region, with Singaporeans being the most optimistic.

site_title: Unwarranted 'halo' around yuan financing
summary: DBS Bank's Tom McCabe downplays the impact of yuan financing on trade financing in Singapore, stating there's an "unwarranted halo" around the renminbi. While the yuan's popularity has driven up fee income, McCabe believes the currency play is less critical, and what matters is working capital requirements. Arbitrage opportunities between offshore and onshore yuan markets may narrow as China liberalizes interest rates, but McCabe's division sees no impact on non-performing loans. The bank's focus remains on serving clients' working capital needs, regardless of the currency used.

site_title: POSH secures cornerstone investors
summary: POSH secures cornerstone investors Fortress Capital Asset Management and Hwang Investment Management for its planned Singapore IPO, taking up 85.6m shares. This listing, expected to raise between US$350 million to US$400 million, will be the first major IPO of 2014 in Singapore. As part of the deal, the investors demonstrate confidence in the shares, typically committing to hold large stakes for a certain time period. The IPO is set to be managed by Bank of America Merrill Lynch, DBS Group Holdings, and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp.

site_title: Australia home price surge may tighten lending
summary: Australia's housing prices are rising due to low interest rates, and banks may tighten lending standards if prices continue to surge, according to ANZ chief Philip Chronican. He cited low interest rates as a factor behind price increases and warned that lenders are preparing for a potential increase in interest rates by increasing buffers to account for higher repayments. This could lead to more cautious buyers and tighter lending standards, potentially slowing the housing market.

site_title: JK Tech shares soar on news of deal with Ezion
summary: Shares in JK Tech Holdings rose 143% after the company announced a proposed deal with Ezion Holdings, which could see Ezion taking a 29.81% stake in JK Tech. JK Tech plans to diversify into oil and gas exploration, issuing shares to Ezion at a 40% discount to its current price. Ezion's shares fell 3 cents as the deal was announced. Analysts suggest the move is an attempt by Ezion to separate its Australian marine supply business into a new entity.

site_title: NZ home price growth slows in March
summary: New Zealand's house price growth slowed for a fourth consecutive month in March, with a 8.8% annual increase in the residential property index, down from 9.3% in February. Lending restrictions and rising interest rates, including a 25 basis point rate hike, are contributing to the slowdown. The Auckland market, which had been driving national figures, is showing signs of slowing activity. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has signaled further interest rate hikes towards 5% over the next two years.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed a new build-to-suit agreement with Trinet Logistics Company in Japan to build a four-storey facility in Kobe, serving as its main distribution centre in Greater Osaka. Polaris acquired four UB One properties in Singapore worth $3.47 million for expansion. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for the second half of the year.

site_title: Carlsberg buys Asahi distributor
summary: Carlsberg Singapore acquired a 51% stake in MayBev Pte Ltd, the sole distributor of Asahi in Singapore, expanding its portfolio of international beverages. This partnership will offer customers a more extensive variety of brands. Meanwhile, TWG Tea expanded to 31 locations globally, with plans to double the number of stores by the end of the year.

site_title: Annica, Magnus hurt most by CAD probe
summary: Shares of Annica Holdings and Magnus Energy Group plummeted 33% and 22% respectively after Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) questioned three top executives and impounded their passports. The probe involves eight firms and is linked to share trading irregularities. Other affected companies include Ipco International, ISR Capital, Innopac Holdings, Blumont Group, and LionGold Corp, with losses ranging from 4% to 33%. The CAD's investigation is under Singapore's Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: Boeing may purchase Mercury Systems
summary: Boeing is considering purchasing Mercury Systems, a supplier of digital signal and image processing systems, for around $500 million. The deal would allow Boeing to save costs and increase its footprint in commercial aerospace components, while gaining access to Mercury's microprocessor business. Mercury Systems has a market value of $440 million and offers systems and services to major aerospace and defense companies. The auction is still in its early stages, with no guarantee that Boeing will proceed with a binding offer.

site_title: BG Group move a big boost for S'pore's LNG hub status
summary: BG Group has relocated its global headquarters for LNG and oil marketing from the UK to Singapore, boosting the city-state's LNG hub ambitions. The move comes a year after Shell set up its global gas headquarters in Singapore, and follows the company's decision to send over 70% of its LNG shipments to Asia. BG has projected global LNG demand to grow by 5% a year until 2025, driven by Asia and Latin America, and plans to increase its oil trading team in Singapore to meet growing demand for its oil shipments to the region.

site_title: SGX now clears non-deliverable ringgit, baht swaps
summary: SGX has cleared non-deliverable ringgit, baht swaps, allowing companies and banks to hedge against currency fluctuations directly at the exchange. This move benefits banks by reducing credit exposure and meeting regulatory requirements. The non-deliverable interest rate swaps (NDIRS) allow parties to exchange fixed or floating interest rate payments in one currency or across two currencies, providing a hedge against sharp currency depreciations and ensuring steady cash flow from overseas units.

site_title: Collision of vessels in Houston exposes risks in busy channel
summary: A vessel collision in Houston's Ship Channel last month exposed vulnerabilities in the critical energy network, where 400 vessels pass daily. The crash, involving a Liberian-flagged vessel and a US tugboat, resulted in a 4,000-barrel fuel oil spill and $1.5 billion in commerce disruption. Investigators are examining factors like speed, navigation, and visibility, with no indication of malfeasance or impaired mariners. The incident highlights the fragility of the channel, despite ongoing $35 billion expansion projects.

site_title: 3 health apps let patients chat with doctors
summary: BORDERLESS Healthcare Group launched three health apps, Smart Ageing, Heartsmart, and Health Abacus, allowing patients to contact participating doctors for medical advice via phone, audio, or video communication. The apps, which cost $49.95 a month, are available on mobile devices and will feature a global stable of medical specialists. The company aims to have 100 specialists on board by year's end and 100,000 to 200,000 subscribers. Participating doctors will receive revenue-sharing compensation for their time. The apps aim to empower patients with disease prevention knowledge and are not a substitute for medical consultations.

site_title: Tuas or Jurong likely site for S'pore-KL rail station
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has confirmed that the city's Tuas West or Jurong East area is likely to be the terminal site for the upcoming Singapore-Kuala Lumpur high-speed rail, which aims to cut travel time between the two cities to 90 minutes. The city center is considered a less likely option due to high land acquisition costs. Jurong East is seen as a compromise between cost and connectivity, while Tuas West offers cheaper construction costs but is farther from other parts of Singapore. The project, worth $15.6 billion, is expected to be completed by 2020.

site_title: OCBC trumps UOB, DBS as most regionalised bank
summary: OCBC Bank surpassed its peers UOB and DBS as the most regionalized bank, according to their annual reports. Despite being the smallest in market capitalization, OCBC's chairman retained the highest pay among peers. UOB's combined pay for its two chairmen was $1.68 million, while DBS' chairman Peter Seah took home $1.84 million. OCBC will also lose its only female director, Fang Ai Lian, at the upcoming annual general meeting, joining UOB in having only male directors.

site_title: Flash estimates: just a numbers game?
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry's advance GDP estimates have been questioned after three out of four quarter-on-quarter estimates in 2013 were off the mark, with the economy projected to contract when it actually expanded. The accuracy of these flash estimates has been a subject of debate, raising concerns about their relevance. The MTI introduced the estimates in 2000 to provide timely economic data, but their reliability has been compromised. This has led to a reevaluation of their usefulness for investors and businesses.

site_title: Growing apathy may dent voter turnout at Indonesia legislative poll
summary: Indonesian voters are expected to experience low voter turnout in the upcoming legislative election due to growing apathy, with some predicting that up to half of the electorate will stay home. Corruption scandals and disappointment in the outgoing administration have contributed to the decline in voter participation, with some specialists attributing it to missed opportunities for reform. Despite the emergence of reformist Governor Joko Widodo as a likely candidate for president, his party is expected to secure a significant number of seats in the House of Representatives, potentially leading to a thumping victory.

site_title: Ezion buying 29.81% interest in JK Tech
summary: Ezion Holdings is buying a 29.81% controlling interest in JK Tech Holdings, an IT firm, in a deal that could eventually see Ezion take over JK Tech. JK Tech will issue shares to Ezion and investment company SF Ventures, and also propose share options. The deal aims to diversify JK Tech into oil and gas exploration, citing challenging business conditions. Ezion plans to introduce opportunities in the oil and gas sector and enhance its long-term viability.

site_title: Resort development fuelling Macau property bubble
summary: Macau, the world's gambling capital, is experiencing a property bubble due to rapid resort development, with over 17,000 new hotel rooms to be built in the next three years. Meanwhile, only 4,000 affordable homes for locals are expected to be constructed. The average apartment price exceeds US$500,000, making Macau one of the world's most expensive places to buy property. Property prices are forecast to rise 10-20% this year, with the situation expected to worsen as new mega resorts open.

site_title: MH370 searchers detect 'most promising' acoustic lead
summary: Australian navy ships have detected new underwater signals consistent with aircraft "black boxes" from the missing MH370 plane. The signals, detected by a towed pinger locator, are considered the "most promising lead" yet in the month-old search. The signals lasted for 2 hours and 20 minutes, and 13 minutes, and are consistent with transmission from both the flight data recorder and the cockpit voice recorder. The search area has been adjusted to the southern end of the search zone, and the focus is on finding the source of the signals, which could indicate where MH370 might have entered the water.

site_title: QT Vascular on why it chose to list in Singapore
summary: QT Vascular, a US-based company developing devices to treat diseased arteries, plans to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to fund product development and expansion. The company, which operates in California and Singapore, has seen revenue double from $1.45 million in 2012 to $3 million in 2013. Its flagship product, the "Chocolate" PTA balloon device, has received FDA approval and has fewer post-surgery complications compared to regular balloons. The listing is seen as a strategic move to tap into the growing Asian market, with Singapore offering a "good bridge between the East and the West."

site_title: Cloud service provider plays developer card
summary: CenturyLink, a US cloud service provider, is shifting its focus to developing tools for developers to increase market share in the public cloud. The company aims to court developers and create a gateway to bigger ticket hosting contracts with corporations. After acquiring companies like Tier 3 and AppFog, CenturyLink is developing infrastructure-as-a-service and platform layers to provide a seamless experience for developers. This move puts the company head-on with competitors like Amazon Web Services and Rackspace, but CenturyLink hopes to leverage its financial backing and existing infrastructure to attract developers and eventually secure larger contracts.

site_title: Economists expect no change in S$ policy
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is expected to keep its monetary policy unchanged when it reviews its stance in a week's time, despite a sharp easing of inflation. Economists expect the Singapore dollar to continue appreciating to guard against wages-led price hikes later this year. The MAS has allowed the trade-weighted Singapore dollar to appreciate at a faster pace, and interest rates are expected to rise due to higher US bond yields. The government forecasts core inflation to rise to 2-3% this year, above last year's 1.7%.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's high-speed rail to Kuala Lumpur may originate from Tuas West or Jurong East, set to roll out in 2020. Indonesia faces growing voter apathy as a new class of lawmakers takes office. The Ministry of Law proposes changes to the Copyright Act to protect owners. Singapore aims to attract shipping firms to tap into its capital markets. Annica Holdings and Magnus Energy saw significant losses due to a share trading probe. China is expected to ease monetary policy to prevent an economic slowdown, while HDB resale prices edged up in March.

site_title: CRCT - China shopping malls
summary: China's first and only China shopping mall Reit, CapitaRetail China Trust (CRCT), is a promising investment opportunity. The Reit, which owns 10 malls worth $2 billion, has seen significant foot traffic, with 35 million shoppers passing through its largest mall, CapitaMall Xizhimen, in Beijing last year. CRCT's second most profitable mall, CapitaMall Wangjing, generated $26 million in net property income in 2013. The Reit's distribution reinvestment plan and high interest coverage ratio make it an attractive option for investors.

site_title: Razzle-dazzle revamps
summary: Three established hotels, The Scarlet, Thevar, and another hotel, underwent revamps to add a new gloss to their brands. The article does not provide details about the revamps, but mentions that they are part of a larger trend of hotels seeking to revamp their brands.

site_title: AGMs: What investors want to know
summary: At annual general meetings (AGMs), investors want to know about a company's strategic direction, board composition, executive compensation, risks and controls, and sustainability efforts. Investors are keen to understand how the company's plans and performance will impact its share price and dividend. Boards should be prepared to address investor questions on these topics, including transparency in executive pay and the adequacy of internal controls. Effective management of these topics can strengthen relationships with investors and ensure their continued support.

site_title: Ordering food via iPads speeds things up at Fish & Co
summary: Fish & Co, a Singapore-based seafood restaurant chain, has implemented an iPad-based ordering system that has increased staff productivity by 65% and reduced errors in order transmission. Introduced in 2012, the system allows customers to place orders on iPads while staff use iPods to transmit orders to the kitchen. This has led to a 90% increase in orders made through mobile devices, resulting in faster service times and improved customer experience. The system has also enabled the restaurant to maintain a "full-service" experience during peak hours.

site_title: Ships detect three separate signals in Indian Ocean
summary: Australian ships and planes have detected three underwater signals in the Indian Ocean, sparking hope that they could be from the missing Malaysian airliner MH370. The signals were detected by China's Haixun 01, and Britain's HMS Echo and the Australian ship Ocean Shield are being diverted to the area to investigate. The signals were detected on a frequency used for the plane's flight data and cockpit voice recorders, and are being taken "very seriously" by the search mission. The search area has been refocused on the southern end of the zone, where satellite data suggests the plane may have crashed.

site_title: Chief security officer role gaining in prominence
summary: At least 50% of companies will have a chief security officer by 2024, up from less than 1% currently, as a response to the increasing prevalence and severity of cyberattacks. Cybersecurity professions are emerging as companies realize they cannot deal with cybercrime on their own. The rise in cybercrime can be attributed to the proliferation of technological devices and the lucrativeness of these criminal activities. Singapore is taking a leading position in establishing a secure network, with the Cyber Security Academy providing realistic training environments for cyberattacks.

site_title: Maersk cuts emissions with fuel efficiency
summary: Maersk Line, the world's largest container shipping line, has cut its carbon dioxide emissions by 12% per container-kilometre in 2013, a year when its business grew 4.1%. The reduction was achieved through a major overhaul of 137 of its container ships, which saved the company $764 million in fuel costs. Maersk aims to cut CO2 emissions by 40% per container-kilometre between 2007 and 2020. The company also reduced sulphur emissions by 12% last year, and is preparing for the upcoming SOx regulations in 2015.

images.alt_text: Cleaner, cheaper: The boost to fuel efficiency from a large-scale overhaul of its container ships saved the company US$764 million in 2013 alone. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: US academic explains greenback's dominance
summary: US academic Eswar Prasad asserts that the US dollar's dominance as a reserve currency and safe-haven currency is unlikely to be challenged by the Chinese renminbi anytime soon. Despite the growing Chinese economy and increasing use of renminbi in international trade, Prasad notes that China lacks the transparent systems and institutions necessary to support a reserve currency. The dollar's increased attractiveness after the 2008 global financial crisis was driven by a surge in demand for safe assets from investors and foreign central banks, making it unlikely to be surpassed by the renminbi.

site_title: Making utilities a pillar in Sembcorp
summary: Sembcorp Industries' CEO Tang Kin Fei has played a key role in transforming the company's utilities sector, which now contributes $450 million in net profit, more than half of the company's total net profit. The utilities business, which includes energy, water, solid waste management, and logistics, was introduced in 1995 as a solution to secure recurring income and solve customers' infrastructure problems. The company plans to expand in emerging markets, particularly in China and India, where power and water demand is increasing due to economic growth. Sembcorp aims to take advantage of the new Chinese administration's emphasis on environmental and resource management, and is refining its utilities developer model to take a larger stake in overseas joint ventures.

site_title: NTT Data setting up innovation lab in S'pore
summary: NTT Data Corporation, a Japanese system integration company, has set up an innovation laboratory in Singapore, one of two in the region, to promote research and development. The lab aims to formulate and drive technology strategy for the Asia Pacific region, focusing on big data, analytics, and other emerging technologies. The lab will collaborate with local customers, government organizations, and research institutes to drive innovation and expand NTT Data's business footprint in the region. The move is seen as a strategic step for NTT Data to innovate for both regional and global clients.

site_title: Fine dining with a Japanese-French edge
summary: Lewin Terrace, a newly established restaurant in Singapore, aims to revive the era of fine dining with a Japanese-French fusion menu. Located in a restored colonial bungalow, the restaurant boasts an old-world ambience and tropical luxury-inspired decor. However, the cuisine is still a work in progress, with some dishes showcasing promise but others being too safe and lacking flavor. Despite this, the restaurant's earnestness and good intentions, combined with its unintimidating service and beautiful setting, make it a promising addition to the local dining scene. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: S'pore aims to be Asia's patent hub
summary: Singapore aims to establish itself as Asia's patent hub, with a robust IP regime ranking among the top four in the world. The country has revamped its patent regime to improve quality and speed, aligning with major markets like Europe, Japan, and the US. With increased patent activity, there's an urgent need for more qualified patent examiners, with IPOS seeking to upsize its workforce to meet the demand. Singapore's IP ecosystem has shown growth, with trademark and design applications increasing, and the country is now ranked 16th globally for patent filing volume.

site_title: No more security patches for Windows XP
summary: Microsoft will stop issuing security patches for Windows XP on April 8, leaving users vulnerable to cyber attacks. Despite being 13 years old, Windows XP still powers 20-30% of Windows machines worldwide. Hackers may exploit newly found security holes, putting users at risk. Small businesses and emerging markets are particularly affected, with automated teller machines potentially vulnerable to hacking. Users will need to fend for themselves or upgrade to newer versions of Windows, a costly and complicated process.

site_title: Market awaits earnings season starting tomorrow
summary: US stocks are expected to start earnings season, which begins tomorrow, with analysts estimating a 1.1% growth in first-quarter earnings for the S&P 500. If corporations meet or exceed this modest expectation, the Dow Jones Industrial Average could break through the 17,000 mark. The market has been stagnant since March, and investors are waiting for earnings season to gauge whether valuations are commensurate with underlying growth.

site_title: Asia may need to change priorities to reduce inequalities: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has warned that Asia's economic growth may not be enough to reduce poverty and income inequalities. The ADB's Independent Evaluation Department calls for new approaches to tackle the issue, citing a lack of understanding of what "inclusive growth" means. Several countries, including China, India, and Thailand, are launching programs to address widening income gaps and social tensions. The ADB's report comes as the region continues to experience economic growth despite high poverty rates.

site_title: High-tech imaging that saves lives
summary: Advances in non-invasive Computed Tomography (CT) imaging have enabled doctors to visualize heart arteries in three-dimensional views without inserting a tube, saving lives by providing accurate diagnoses. Unlike coronary angiography, CT scans can visualize the artery wall, detect soft or hardened plaques, and assess calcium deposits. This technology helps resolve discrepancies in disease interpretation between different imaging techniques, particularly in cases with diffuse plaque and narrowing, allowing doctors to determine the cause of the narrowing and make informed treatment decisions.

site_title: Rendezvous rebrands as arts-inspired hub
summary: Rendezvous Hotel in Singapore rebranded as an arts-inspired hub, offering a unique experience for guests. The hotel's transformation aims to provide a creative atmosphere with various artistic elements.

site_title: Socialbakers to chase social media spending
summary: Socialbakers, a social media analytics firm, aims to increase social media spending by companies to 10-30% of their digital marketing budgets by the end of the year. Currently, this spending is relatively low due to offline marketing dominating the market.

site_title: High tech haberdashery
summary: Online men's tailoring stores have emerged as a convenient alternative to traditional suit shopping, offering digital services from scientific measurements to webcams for clients who want a dapper look without downtime. Companies like Indochino, Tailor Me Online, and ButtonNStitch.com have revolutionized the industry with made-to-order suits, customizable options, and affordable prices. With the rise of online shopping, entrepreneurs are now offering consultations in-person or via webcam, combining the benefits of high-tech haberdashery with old-world tradition of tailoring.

site_title: Fortune Reit - HK suburban malls
summary: Fortune Reit, Singapore's first foreign Reit, has diversified its asset base since its listing in 2003, with 17 properties valued at HK$29.3 billion. The top contributors to revenue and net property income are City One Shatin, Ma On Shan Plaza, Metro Town, and Fortune Metropolis. The acquisition of Kingswood Ginza mall last October boosted earnings, but the Hong Kong real estate sector faces headwinds due to supply and income growth limitations. Analysts forecast a property slump by end-2015, but shopper flow from mainland Chinese visitors is expected to support the retail sector.

site_title: Small wonder
summary: The BMW 220i is a new coupe model, replacing the 1 Series Coupe, featuring a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine and a sleek, fun-to-drive design. The 2 Series has an extended body and longer wheelbase, making it longer and more lithe compared to its predecessor. It shares a platform with the current 1 Series hatchback and is 72 mm longer overall, with a profile that resembles a proper two-door model. The 220i is a small, compact car with a sporty appearance, offering a new take on the BMW brand.

site_title: Alibaba's success depends on its public-private model
summary: Alibaba, China's largest private company, relies on its public-private model for success. The company's e-commerce and online finance ventures have attracted significant assets, with its Yu'e Bao fund attracting more than China's five smallest listed banks. Alibaba emphasizes that its business aligns with China's government policy, citing benefits such as sustaining small businesses and liberalizing interest rates. The company's private status allows it to quickly exploit opportunities, but it must maintain good relations with the government to avoid intervention, a challenge also faced by Western internet giants.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Economists expect no change in Singapore's monetary policy, with the Singapore dollar likely to continue appreciating. The US dollar's dominance as a reserve currency is expected to remain, according to a Cornell University economist. US stocks finished flat, despite a tepid jobs growth report. Asia needs to shift development priorities to reduce income and social inequalities, according to an ADB report. Sembcorp Industries has made utilities a significant contributor to its profits, while Ezion Holdings is set to acquire a controlling interest in JK Tech Holdings.

site_title: Singapore targets investment in disruptive technologies
summary: Singapore aims to sustain its manufacturing sector by leveraging disruptive technologies such as 3D printing, automation, and robotics. The country's Economic Development Board (EDB) is promoting these technologies to attract companies like Rolls-Royce and Procter & Gamble, which have invested in research centers and partnerships with local universities. EDB wants to develop a regional manufacturing supply chain, focusing on engineering and design work in Singapore, while keeping labor-intensive work in nearby countries. The goal is to maintain a 20-25% share of manufacturing in Singapore's GDP.

site_title: An element of surprise
summary: Japanese architect/designer Oki Sato believes in creating designs with a twist to evoke a "!" moment. His design studio nendo is known for quirky yet functional products, such as a Starbucks collaboration mug that looks like a coffee drink when upside down. Sato's goal is to give existing products a new twist, rather than creating something entirely new. He draws inspiration from everyday life and believes that design is about solving problems, with a focus on finding the right balance between form and function.

site_title: Lippo Malls - Indonesian retail
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust offers exposure to suburban malls in Indonesia, an emerging market. The trust's properties in Jakarta are benefiting from tight retail space, allowing mall operators to negotiate better rents. The Jakarta government restricts new mall construction due to traffic issues and city planning efforts, further supporting the trust's position. As a result, Lippo Reit is a more attractive alternative to North Asian retail properties, with rents in Jakarta being among the lowest in the region. This trend is expected to continue, making the trust a potential investment opportunity.

site_title: Overseas retail Reits - risk or reward?
summary: Overseas retail real estate investment trusts (Reits) offer a potential risk-reward proposition, with a projected yield of 7% required to be attractive. These Reits provide a defensive investment option, as shopping will continue regardless of economic conditions, and also offer exposure to growing middle-class consumers in China and Indonesia. However, the risks of investing in foreign currencies and less certain political environments may clash with investors' intentions to invest in "safe" assets.

site_title: Vision for a Smart Nation
summary: The Infocomm Media Masterplan, a vision for a Smart Nation, outlines ideas for harnessing the power of ICM. However, the article does not specifically discuss the plan. Instead, it provides unrelated news articles, including Asean's stance on the Myanmar election, a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, and China's efforts to aid employment amid trade tensions. These news items highlight regional and global economic developments, but do not relate to the Infocomm Media Masterplan.

site_title: MH370 backlash could hurt Singapore, Malaysia tours
summary: Demand for combined Singapore and Malaysia tours has seen a 40% drop, mainly due to the backlash from the missing MH370 plane incident, particularly among Chinese tourists. Operators report a decrease in inquiries, with some expecting a 10-20% drop in demand for peak season. Tour operators are monitoring the situation and are open to making changes if necessary to reassure tourists, but a significant impact on the tourism industry is expected.

site_title: Cornucopia of local artisanal fare
summary: Singapore-based artisanal food businesses are thriving, with a diverse range of small-batch producers offering unique products. Mofo Chilli, Two Rabbits Smoky Chilli, Supershiok Sambal, Eastern Granola, The Edible Co, Bruneus, The Hunters' Kitchenette, A.muse Projects, Eng Natalie, 3 Bites Full, and GSH Conserves are just a few examples of the many local entrepreneurs creating high-quality, preservative-free products. These businesses cater to a variety of tastes and dietary needs, from vegan-friendly chilli sauces to gluten-free granola and specialty teas.

site_title: Craft food producers go #social
summary: Singapore's craft food scene has undergone a social media-driven revolution, with young entrepreneurs leveraging platforms like Instagram and Facebook to market their homemade products. Over six months, more than six new small-scale food producers have emerged, largely run by people in their late 20s and early 30s, and all credit online branding for significantly boosting their sales. These producers focus on all-natural, preservative-free production processes and incorporate Asian-inspired flavors into traditionally Western food products to stand out. Social media also helps them track consumer feedback and trends, but requires constant updating and a subtle hand to avoid annoying followers.

site_title: MGCCT - a large HK retail asset
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT), a HK retail asset, raised $1.7 billion in its initial public offering last year. The Reit's low cost of debt and investment-grade credit rating from Moody's Baa1 make it an attractive option for fundraising and higher gearing. MGCCT's main asset, Festival Walk in Hong Kong, contributes about three quarters of revenue and net property income, with 580,000 sq ft of retail lettable area and 214,000 sq ft of office lettable area. The trust's diversified portfolio includes Festival Walk and Gateway Plaza in Beijing.

site_title: Directors' acquisitions up while disposals drop
summary: Directors in Singapore recorded 29 purchases worth $6.16 million and 10 disposals worth $700,000 from March 31 to April 4. Buying rebounded from the previous week, while selling declined. Notable acquisitions include Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC) and Singapore Airlines, with OCBC buying 800,000 shares at $9.65 each and Singapore Airlines purchasing 2.646 million shares at $10.34 each. Independent directors also made significant purchases, including Pacific Radiance's Goh Chong Theng, Neo Group's Kevin Ng How Hwan, and Mermaid Maritime's Jan Skorupa.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: UIC Enterprise's offer to Singapore Land is deemed "fair and reasonable" by its independent financial adviser, citing a 33.1% discount to net tangible assets within comparable company ranges. Oxley Holdings is exploring restructuring its overseas business, including a potential listing on Catalist. Noble Group's subsidiary acquired a 28.29% stake in Inflection Energy for US$71.44 million. JES International's auditor flagged a going-concern issue due to significant liabilities exceeding assets by 422.6 million yuan.

site_title: Design coup
summary: The Jaguar F-Type Coupé, unveiled in Spain, combines elegant styling with technological innovation. With a fixed roof and rear hatch, the Coupé pays homage to the E-Type while maintaining a modern and distinctive design. Available with three engine options, including a 5.0-litre supercharged V8 delivering 550hp, the Coupé boasts advanced features such as Electronic Active Differential, Torque Vectoring, and Adaptive Dynamics. The R Coupé model offers exceptional handling and braking capabilities, making it a breathtaking driving experience.

site_title: OCBC has best paid chairman, lowest paid CEO among 3 local banks
summary: OCBC Bank's chairman, Cheong Choong Kong, received $2.26 million in 2013, the highest among the three local banks. In contrast, OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien received $8.82 million, the lowest among the three. The bank's board has no women directors, and only 8.3% of board directors at Singapore-listed companies are women.

site_title: US Navy 'black box' detector joins ocean search
summary: The US Navy's "black box" detector, a towed pinger locator, joined the search for MH370 in the Indian Ocean, with its signal set to expire in roughly 30 days. The Australian naval vessel Ocean Shield, accompanied by a British hydrographic ship, scoured the area with planes and ships, but no debris has been found to confirm a crash site. Despite extensive efforts, the search remains inconclusive, with Angus Houston warning that "crunch time" is approaching. The plane carrying 239 people disappeared on March 8 en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.

site_title: Budgeting for business travellers
summary: Hangout@mt.emily, a popular budget hotel in Singapore, is set to reopen in July after a $2 million revamp. The hotel, which previously catered to backpackers and budget travelers, will now focus on business travelers. The new design will retain its "no frills, just fun" atmosphere while adding amenities such as electronic in-room safes, high-speed WiFi, and a pantry. The hotel aims to cater to the growing number of business travelers in Singapore, with a 30% year-on-year increase in corporate bookings over the past three years.

site_title: MF Global starts final distribution to meet 100% of customer claims
summary: MF Global Inc, the defunct brokerage led by Jon Corzine, has started final distributions to fully satisfy US$6.7 billion in claims from former customers. The trustee overseeing the repayments, James Giddens, stated that cheques will be mailed to make all public customers 100% whole. This marks the final step in repaying customers after the company's bankruptcy.

site_title: Blumont gets more time to find new director
summary: Blumont Group has been given an extension to find a new independent director, ID Ng Su Ling, who resigned on November 18. The original deadline was February 17, but the Singapore Exchange has now set it to April 17. Blumont attributes the delay in finding a replacement to the complex nature of the mineral and energy resources sector, as well as the lack of suitable candidates. The company is also dealing with market scrutiny and the unanticipated resignation.

site_title: Weaving lyrical magic
